DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ECOLOGY, DIVERSITY AND SUSTAINABILITY) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to alter the constitution to ensure that when making laws the parliament takes into account the effect of such laws on certain aspects of the natural environment.
Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: There has been much agony over Constitutional change to include Federal powers in relation to the environment. It has been claimed that the Commonwealth already has almost all the power it needs to protect the environment. Alternatively, it has been said that it needs a specific head of environmental authority. The first group claims that what is lacking is the political will to use the powers that are there, the second that these powers are oblique to the central object of environmental protection and that specific powers would help clarify the proper role of the Federal Parliament.

Many feel that both Labor and Coalition Federal Governments have failed on occasion to use the powers that are available under the Constitution. Others feel that Federal Governments have often exceeded the exercise of its powers with respect to environmental protection. One is also aware of the difficulty in achieving Constitutional change in any area and that one that sought to extend Commonwealth powers is almost doomed to failure. Given this difficulty and the sensitivity of Federal and State Governments to `state rights' it seems highly unlikely that any attempt to write specific environmental powers into the constitution would be successful.

However, when the Constitution was written no thought was given to environment, the word does not appear in the Constitution and now, in 1995, it is time to bring the very basis of our law making up to date.

In 1994, while a member of a Parliamentary delegation to four southern African countries I became aware of the Namibian Constitution. Namibia has been independent for only four years so its Constitution is a new document. It is structured very differently from the Australian document with a whole section devoted to `Principles of State Policy'. This section sets out the broad principles that will guide the Parliament in the application of the specific powers which the Constitution provides. The principles deal with 12 areas including sexual equality, equity and access to education as well as the maintenance of ecosystems, ecological sustainability and intergenerational equity. While the inclusion of a section outlining the broad principles that should guide the exercise of specific powers seems an approach worthy of serious consideration this bill seeks the more modest aim of writing in only one principle that needs to be taken into account. If this change is successful perhaps other principles could be added later.
Section 51 of the Australian Constitution sets out the powers to be exercised by the Federal Parliament. It reads:
s 51: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:-
Then follows 39 subsections each of which confer a specific power.
For example:

PARA.TAB: (i.) Trade and commerce with other countries, and among the States:
(xx.) Foreign corporations, and trading and financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth: etc.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the quoted sections have been used to obtain environmental protection. Section 51 (i.) has been used to prohibit the export of minerals unless the written approval of the federal Minister is obtained. The High Court approved the exercise of this discretion by the federal Minister to prohibit the export of minerals from Fraser Island for environmental reasons. It decided that the Minister could have regard to environmental aspects of mining in refusing approval of export permits. This was an initiative of the Fraser Coalition Government and it lead eventually to the protection of Fraser Island as a World Heritage Area.

The Hydroelectric Commission in Tasmania was deemed to be a trading corporation when the High Court considered the appeal against the Federal Government's designation of SW Tasmania as a World Heritage Area. This was an initiative of a federal Labor Government. The decision of the High Court in the Tasmanian Dam Case extended the operation of this power under S 51 (xx.) so that the Commonwealth may control, having regard to environmental considerations, all manufacturing, production or extractive processes conducted by corporations, as defined in S 51 (xx), for the purposes of trade. This power does not extend to the operations of State Governments.

S 51 (xxix.) provides the external affairs powers under which the High Court has ruled that the Commonwealth may pass a range of valid laws, including laws to protect the environment, so long as they are in faithful pursuit of an obligation imposed by an international agreement and they are not in breach of other constitutional limitations such as S 92 imposes.

Powers with respect to race (S 51 (xxvi.) may be used to legislate the protection or conservation of a site of Aboriginal significance and this power was relied upon in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 passed by a federal Labor Government.

But these powers may or may not be exercised and the Constitution contains no guidance as to how and to what ends these powers are to be directed. A review of the occasions when the powers have been exercised in the defence of the environment indicates an arbitrariness difficult to justify on any objective criteria.

My bill does not add any new powers to the Constitution. It does not grant any new powers to the Commonwealth and it does not therefore interfere with the balance between the Commonwealth and the States. It adds after the last subsection of Section 51 a paragraph which reads:

PARA.EMPHASIS: When making a law under this section each House of the Parliament must take into account the probable effects of that law on:

PARA.TAB: (i) the maintenance of ecosystems and of essential ecological processes;
(ii) the biological diversity of Australia; and
(iii) the utilisation of the living natural resources on a sustainable basis for the benefit of all Australians, both present and in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not seek to give the Federal Parliament any new power and can not therefore be accused of usurping the role of the states. And I believe this will provide a less controversial way of getting these important principles into the debate which leads to the passing of any new legislation.

The Final Report of the Constitutional Commission 1988 recommended that the Constitution be not altered to give the Federal Parliament power to make laws with respect to the environment. It noted that the Federal Parliament had no express power to make laws with respect to `the environment' or `the protection of the environment'. The Advisory Committee to the Commission, the Distribution of Powers Committee, was disposed to giving the Commonwealth specific powers with respect to the environment but fell short of recommending such a power on the grounds that it would be difficult to restrict the exercise of such a power to matters of national concern. It noted that the concept of national concern is itself too vague and subjective to form the basis of an appropriate constitutional criterion which could be used to test the legal validity of legislation enacted in the exercise of this power.

The amendment sought in this bill achieves the desire of the Distribution of Powers Advisory Committee in that it provides a flavour to the exercise of the powers already in the Constitution but avoids the pitfalls of defining any new powers.

The Environmental Law Commission in its submission to the Powers Committee argued for the inclusion of environmental powers in the Constitution, pointing out that such a power `is capable of being adapted to the changing political circumstances of the nation' and `does not and should not produce fears of concerns that the localised interests of State governments will be put at risk' by its exercise. It would `vest the Commonwealth with the powers to influence and guide the performance of such functions within the States from a national perspective.

The South Australian Government favoured a much more limited role for the Commonwealth agreeing that some environmental power with respect to protection of major water ways with interstate distribution, land degradation, items of heritage value and areas of national significance might be areas for Commonwealth involvement. Other submissions disagreed with even this limited extension of Commonwealth power.

It is a serious defect in the exercise of power with respect to many environmental matters that there is not a clearly defined role for each of the levels of government. This becomes obvious when standards for water quality, air or chemical exposure are being set. Complex and very time consuming intergovernmental committees slowly thrash their way through disagreements and minimum standards. In several instances this has been resolved with the Commonwealth playing a leadership role and the States passing complementary legislation. The role envisaged for the Commonwealth by the Environmental Law Commission above has been fulfilled.

It is intended that this amendment to the Constitution will turn the minds of federal parliamentarians toward such a role for the Commonwealth while avoiding the realisation of the fears of those who seek greater control over environmental management at the local level. If the federal parliament continues to exercise the same powers it has always possessed but takes into account, in the exercise of those powers, the care and protection of the natural environment as defined in this amendment one can be hopeful that a better, but still cooperative system of management will develop.

The amendment does not use the word environment because the word has been used in so many unrelated contexts. Instead the amendment specifies those things the legislators should consider: maintenance of ecosystems, ecological processes, biological diversity, sustainability and the present generations responsibility to those generations as yet unborn. All these principles have been widely accepted by Government, Opposition, other parties and a majority of the Australian population. Every one of them has found expression in agreements and laws which have become part of everyday life in the last few decades. The ESD Committees took most of these concerns as a given, groups and committees working on greenhouse response and biodiversity have accepted these principles as their basis. Each has been written into various laws and into numerous government and party policy documents. There is nothing exceptional about these principles. Most present parliamentarians have expressed support for these principles during recent speeches. In this respect the amendment codifies what the majority support.

The amendment does not increase in any way the power of the Commonwealth, it provides a reminder that in passing legislation, the Commonwealth. as custodian of the nations natural heritage, has a responsibility to exercise its existing powers in a way which takes account of that heritage for both the present generation and for all future Australians.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have reached item 1 of government business, perhaps I could move that further consideration of this item be postponed to a later hour this day—
—Absolutely not.
—To enable us to resolve some ongoing discussion about the handling of this matter before we get back into it.
—You brought on the censure motion.
—I thought that might have been with the cooperation of the Leader of the Opposition.

—by leave—We have been most anxious to cooperate with the program, as was plain at the meeting last night. There has been a great deal of time between then and now. It is now 9.45 a.m. We sat at 9.30 a.m. Senator Gareth Evans leaves this on the Notice Paper. He brought in a censure of one of our senators. He will wear the consequences of having done that.

PARA.TAB: A number of our people want to speak on this motion, and they are entitled to. He can withdraw the censure motion if he wishes; we would probably agree to that. But I would want an apology. He can withdraw the motion, allow it to run its course or speak to us in a proper manner—not now, in here. This matter is due to go ahead. Senator O'Chee is sitting in the chamber waiting to make his contribution. Eleven of our senators are on the list, wanting to make their contributions, and I have told them they will be able to.

I told Senator Jones yesterday at the whips meeting that I expected, and we would try, to get this finished by lunchtime because we understand that your program is under pressure. It is your priority to go ahead with a censure of one of our senators, and it will proceed. If you have anything to say to Senator Hill about the management of the matter, then I think you should go and see him. Go around to his office. If you don't know where it is you might soon, but I will tell you where it is. You can tell him what you want to say and how you propose to deal with it. Meantime we are entitled to proceed to defend our senator who is under attack at your doing. It is inappropriate for you to come in here at a quarter to 10 and say, `Hang on, chaps. Pull it off for a bit. I want to sort something out.' That is not the way to run this place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I had a number of discussions last night and earlier this morning. Those discussions were proceeding. There was a chance that this matter could have been resolved in another five or 10 minutes of discussion. In the absence of any willingness on the part of the opposition whip to be cooperative in this respect, then that is fine; I will not pursue the matter. Senator O'Chee—go ahead.

—by leave—It is absolutely unreasonable for Senator Evans to suggest that I am not anxious to cooperate. I am. We have indicated to the government that we recognise there are bills that must be completed before tomorrow night. He obviously did not listen to a word I just said. We are anxious to cooperate. There is a way of raising the matter and discussing it with us that perhaps can resolve the matter, rather than just walking in here at a quarter to 10 and trying to put it off when the matter has just been called on. I believe that Senator O'Chee should be allowed to proceed with his contribution. If Senator Evans has anything to say, I repeat what I said. We are quite happy to listen to it. We are anxious to work out some means of completing this program. Do not accuse me of not being cooperative. We have been cooperating on this program for weeks. You are the ones who have not been managing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans's actions just now show what a farce this whole censure motion is, always was, and always will be. Senator Evans comes in here after having had the great idea on Monday that he would cut into Senator Baume, that he would have a go at besmirching Senator Baume with a censure motion which was poorly drafted, which was wholly inaccurate, which utterly disregarded any facts, which utterly disregarded any basic principles of natural justice and which utterly disregarded any principles of law. He got the chance to bring his censure motion on last night. Senator Evans was wholly and utterly humiliated in this place by Senator Hill last night in his address. There is not a skerrick of evidence, there is not one legal proposition, there is not one principle of natural justice that supports the case that Senator Evans brought before this chamber in this censure motion.

PARA.TAB: When that was demonstrated to Senator Evans throughout the debate last night, when it was to be demonstrated to Senator Evans and the Australian people again today, on a broadcast day, what was the response from Senator Evans? Was it to say, `We will seek to withdraw it'? No. Was it to say, `We have embarked on this course of action. We will let it run its course'? No. It was to stand up here at a quarter to 10 and say, `Sorry, everybody. I would like to put this off a bit while I try to plea bargain the fact that I could not draw the censure motion properly in the first place.' That was his response.

Here we have a man who fancies himself as Chief Justice of the High Court, ably assisted by Robespierre over there and the law clerk. That was the case we had last night. We had the Chief Justice, Robespierre and the law clerk. Together, all three of them, aided by one of the chief witnesses for the prosecution, could not come up with a case. Why could they not come up with a case? Because there is no case for Senator Baume to answer under this censure motion. It is highly extraordinary that there should be a censure motion of a back bench senator in the first place.

I will go to the motives of that a little later in the speech, but I feel it is important right here and now to show what a legal and judicial farce this has become. Let us look at some of the charges against Senator Baume in this censure motion. Some of these charges are absolutely absurd. This is great. Paragraph (b) of the motion says that the Senate should censure Senator Baume for:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)his commission of an act, the disclosure of Dr Macdonald's tax file number, which would have been a crime if done outside the parliament. . .

That is a great charge to have—except for one little problem: Senator Baume never knew he was disclosing, and never intended to disclose, that tax file number. Yet here we have a trumped up charge from the pretender to be Chief Justice and from Robespierre that says, `We are going to accuse a person of doing something he did not know he was doing. We are going to accuse a person of doing something even though he did not have the slightest intention to do it.'

PARA.TAB: If that is going to be the standard of accountability in this parliament, so be it. We will start to apply that standard of accountability to the people on the other side of the chamber, because every time a government minister has been accused of an indiscretion in this place, every time a government minister has been accused of doing something wrong, the defence has been from the other side, `Sorry, I did not know I had done it. My staffer did it'—the Miles Kupa defence.

Senator Baume is to be accused, tried and convicted of something he did not know he was doing. But I submit to the Senate that the first person for the high jump should have been not Senator Baume, but Senator Evans, for every time he has come in here and said, `I am sorry, my staffer did it. I did not do it. I did not know about it.' It is Senator Evans who should be on trial in this place. It is Senator Collins who should be on trial in this place. We only have to remember the pay TV fiasco when Senator Collins said, `It was not me. It was my staffer.' We only have to remember the TAAATS fiasco over which Senator Collins presided. Again, it was not Senator Collins's fault, because he did not know it was happening; it was somebody else.

The government is not saying, `We are going to abide by those standards, we are going to accept responsibility for things we do not know about.' Instead, this government is lovely; it is clever. It says, `We are only going to apply that standard to members of the opposition.' What a farce this government is. These are people who parade their credentials to believe in human rights, who parade their credentials to believe in natural justice. Where is the natural justice for Senator Baume? There is no natural justice. Where are the human rights for Senator Baume? There are no human rights, because human rights and natural justice rely upon a consistent legal standard.

Whilst this government applies a different legal standard to the charges it lays against Senator Baume as compared to the charges it wishes to acknowledge of its own wrongs, then natural justice and human rights in this chamber are a farce; and they have been turned into a farce by Robespierre, by the pretender to be Chief Justice and by the law clerk. What a ridiculous charge to trump up against Senator Baume.

Let us go into the facts of this matter. The facts of this matter are very clear. Senator Baume made a speech on Thursday night to which this government took exception. It did not like what Senator Baume had to say. It then alleged that the purpose of the speech, in part, was to disclose the tax file number of Dr Peter Macdonald. Let us examine whether the intention of Senator Baume's contribution on Thursday night was to disclose the tax file number of Dr Peter Macdonald. I submit to the Senate that it clearly was not to disclose the tax file number of Dr Peter Macdonald.

That was not his intention because, first of all, Senator Baume did not realise the document contained the tax file number. Quite coincidentally, Senator Crowley, who was the duty minister, did not realise that the document contained the tax file—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor did Senator Forshaw.

—Nor did Senator Forshaw. Nor did the other government senator, we assume, on the other side. I shall come in a minute to Senator Forshaw and his mate. Certainly Senator Crowley was given the document in advance of Senator Baume's contribution for the purpose of ensuring that no injustice was done to anybody with the tabling of the document. That is why we observe the courtesy in this chamber of providing other senators with copies of material to be tabled before we seek leave to do so.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley did not recognise that there was a tax file number there either. So, if Senator Baume is to be convicted of the charge of doing something he did not know he was doing, let us change the terms of this censure motion and add Senator Crowley to the list as well. Let us be fair about it; let us cut into Senator Crowley as well. If we are going to cut into Senator Baume for committing an offence he did not know he was committing and there was a tax file number on a document that was tabled, Senator Crowley ought to be included in this censure motion because she was given an opportunity to pick it up and did not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —As if she is not in enough strife already.

—Yes, as if she is not in enough strife already. We lay down this opportunity to the government: if it wants to amend the censure motion to include Senator Crowley and show it is interested in natural justice, we will give leave to amend it.
—What about Forshaw and the other one?

—That is right—what about Senator Forshaw? Senator Forshaw picked up this document from the Table Office. He could not wait to get his hands on it. Senator Forshaw raced off to the Table Office. He wanted to see what was in the document.
—You tabled it.
—You wanted him to see it.

—And he took it. Did Senator Forshaw realise that there was a tax file number on it? No, Senator Forshaw did not realise it either. So here we have the government saying, `We are going to accuse Senator Baume of failing to recognise there was a tax file number there, but let us forget about the fact that our people who also had copies of the document after it was tabled did not know either. Let us forget about the fact that our duty minister, who had a copy of the document before it was tabled, did not know either.'

PARA.TAB: The kangaroo court over there would like to draft the law so that it applies one standard to Senator Baume and members of the opposition and applies another standard to its own people. Maybe those opposite do need to draft the law so that a lesser standard of care is required on the other side of the chamber, because look at some of the galahs that sit on the other side of the chamber. If they had to observe the same standard of care that members of the opposition have to, there would be a censure motion in this chamber every day and twice on a Thursday because this government is totally and utterly inept.

This government could not even draft the censure motion properly. Senator Hill showed perfectly last night what a farce this censure motion is. Heaven help the person who drafted it. For example, part (d)(i)(c) accuses Senator Baume of a contempt of the Senate on the basis that he may have done something inconsistent with section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act. What does section 4 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act say? It says people are not allowed to impede senators or committees in the execution of their duty. Who did Senator Baume impede?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a single person.
—Not a single person. What committee was impeded in the execution of its duty by Senator Baume's speech on Thursday night?
—What did you mean by it, Gareth?

—What did Gareth Evans mean by it? Heaven knows! He does not even know. He was given the opportunity last night to prove his case on this, and he could not do it. He did not even want to refer to it. He put this in there. It sounds really great; it sounds legal. It might even prove his qualifications to be Chief Justice of the High Court, but heaven help anybody who looks at the charge.
—It shows why he didn't get the job.

—Maybe that is why he did not get it indeed. There was not a skerrick of legal ability in the drafting of this censure motion. If we are going to apply standards that say Senator Baume should be censured for making his contribution on Thursday night not on the basis that Senator Baume was wilful and not on the basis that Senator Baume had any legal intent to disclose Dr Peter Macdonald's tax file number, we ought to be censuring this government for incompetence every day, as I said, and twice on Thursday.

PARA.TAB: There is also another matter to be considered here. This motion accuses Senator Baume of having an unlawful intent. It accuses Senator Baume of having the intent to disclose a tax file number. Not only did Senator Baume not know there was a tax file number but, furthermore, when Senator Baume realised there was a tax file number contained on the document he took every possible step to ensure that that tax file number was not put on the public record.

What was Senator Baume's first response when he became aware that there was a tax file number on the document? He contacted the Clerk of the Senate and asked that the tax file number be excised from the document. The Clerk of the Senate said that he would need a request in writing. Senator Baume in a committee hearing wrote out a request on the first bit of paper possible, sent it to the Clerk of the Senate and said, `Please excise this tax file number because I do not want to release this tax file number which is contained on the document.' Senator Baume is being accused of having criminal intent by that side of the chamber when all of the facts are that, rather than having criminal intent, Senator Baume did everything he possibly could to ensure nobody got that tax file number.

What else did Senator Baume do? Senator Baume saw the Table Office and said, `Who has got a copy of this document because I want to contact them and make sure they do not disclose the tax file number.' He was told that the document was received by three journalists, all of whom he contacted and all of whom undertook to him that they would not disclose the tax file number, and it was received by two Labor senators. It was not until last night that we knew who the two Labor senators were. Were these two courageous defenders of Dr Peter Macdonald's human rights willing to stick up their hands and say, `I have a copy of document?'

TALK.START.PARA: —We only know one.

—We only know one. Still now we only know one. Those on that side of the chamber accuse Senator Baume of all sorts of foul intent, all sorts of misconduct, yet they do not even have the decency to put their hands up and say which of them have received a copy of the document. They do not want to say which of them may have looked at a copy of the document that somebody else has received—we did not hear about that last night—and they certainly do not want to tell what they have done with the tax file number.

PARA.TAB: What is the standard of reasonableness in this place? The standard of reasonableness from the other side of the chamber is utterly deplorable. There is a maxim in the law that you cannot go to the court of equity with dirty hands. Yet not only have those opposite got their hands in the muck, they also have their arms in the muck, right up to their armpits. Their hands are so dirty on this matter that it is unbelievable. Yet they have the audacity to come into this chamber and accuse Senator Baume, who did everything possible to ensure that that tax file number was not disclosed, of misconduct when it will only be disclosed if one of the two Labor senators who have a copy of the document releases that tax file number. There is no other way it will be released. I think they ought to be accused of misconduct for failing to say which of them has the document and what they have done with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Return it.
—And return it. Did we have an offer from Senator Forshaw last night to return a copy of the document that he had? We did not have a offer from Senator Forshaw.
—He has already done it, you goose.

—We did not have an offer. We did not have an offer from the other Labor senator who has a copy of the document. Of course we didn't. The crazy thing about this censure motion is that the chief witness for the prosecution last night, Senator Forshaw, did not do a single thing to protect the security of Dr Peter Macdonald's tax file number when he became aware of it. He did not do a single thing.
—Shameful.

—It is shameful and I think his conduct—remember, this is the conduct of the chief witness for the prosecution—ought to be compared with the conduct of the accused. The accused, Senator Baume, did everything he possibly could to protect the security of the tax file number, yet those on other side have the audacity to pull up as chief witness for the prosecution a man who did absolutely nothing for it, a man who had absolutely no regard for the security of the tax file number but who wants to come into this chamber and pontificate and accuse Senator Baume of all sorts of disgraceful misconduct. There is not one single area of misconduct which can be proved—not one single area of misconduct which can be shown.

PARA.TAB: Then we have the best charge of all. This is a beautiful one. I think Senator Evans must have picked this one up in Cuba. The second charge is this: that Senator Baume did something for political advantage rather than for public interest. When this chamber starts to judge the contributions of senators on whether they were for political advantage or for public interest, heaven help us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look over there.

—Have a look over there; worse still, Senator Chapman, have a look at the other place. There is no doubt that anybody who goes into question time in the other place will recognise that the contributions of our part-time Prime Minister (Mr Keating) are all for political advantage and not at all for the public interest. In fact, the best thing that our part-time Prime Minister could do for the public interest would be to resign. That is perfectly honest.

PARA.TAB: Here we have the trumped up charge that Senator Baume did something for political advantage and not for public interest. This really goes to the heart of the charge in the censure motion that is before us today. The government did not like what Senator Baume had to say—that is the height of the charge against Senator Baume. I make this point to independent senators: if we start to censure people because one side of the chamber or the other does not like what people have to say, all senators in this chamber will be subject to censure every time they get up to speak. It would be a gross violation of the privileges and the rights of each and every senator in this chamber—not just of Senator Baume—to represent their points of view if we were to pass a censure motion against Senator Baume saying that he was guilty of doing something for political advantage instead of for public interest.

Senator Baume believed, and still believes, that what he did was in the public interest. There are many people in this chamber who agree with him. Post facto, somebody could come along and say, `That was not really in the public interest; it was for political advantage.' Where do we draw the line between public interest and political advantage? Maybe the line is drawn by this censure motion today. Maybe the line is this: it is public interest if you have got the numbers; it is political advantage if you do not.

That is the lesson that Senator Evans learnt from Castro's Cuba when he was sitting in the hotel waiting for his glorious leader to come and meet him. That is the lesson he learnt from all the totalitarian regimes. All the totalitarian regimes across the world say they have a free and open democracy. You have a free and open democracy only if you have the numbers; if you happen to represent a contrary view point that does not have the numbers, what you are saying is not in the public interest.

This is a show trial which ought not be conducted in this Senate chamber. It ought to be taken back to where it came from and conducted in Castro's Cuba. If we ever censure a senator because we do not like what he happens to say, we limit the freedom of speech upon which this parliament relies; we limit the freedom of speech not just of Senator Baume but of every senator now and of every senator who will sit in this chamber to come.

This censure motion could make this one of the blackest days for the freedom of the parliament and for the right of people's representatives to voice their opinions in an open democracy. The government is saying in this censure motion that it is going to censure Senator Baume because it did not like what he had to say. If the government had the integrity and the honesty—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Exactly Senator Woods, I laugh too. If the government had the integrity and the honesty to come into this chamber and say, `We dislike what Senator Baume said. We think he is a naughty boy,' we might actually have some respect for its viewpoint. I probably would not agree with it, but at least I might have some respect for its intellectual honesty. Instead, those opposite come in here and say that they do not like what Senator Baume has to say so they dress it up that Senator Baume is somehow committing a contempt of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: According to this censure motion, it is a contempt of the Senate to do something you do not know you are doing, to fail to draw the attention of the Senate to something you do not know is there, and to give a speech which the government does not like because it says it impedes another senator or a committee in the execution of their duties. Let us give Senator Evans the benefit of the doubt for the moment—

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't deserve it.

—He does not deserve it. I have a lot of doubts about him, but I do not think I would give him much benefit of the doubt. Let us give him the benefit of the doubt. If Senator Baume should be censured because his speech impeded an honourable senator in the execution of his duty, then how much more should Senator Evans be censured for bringing a motion to censure Senator Baume? This censure motion is designed to intimidate honourable senators on the opposition side from revealing the truth. This censure motion is designed to intimidate Senator Baume because he has had the audacity, the courage and the integrity to come before this parliament not just on one occasion but time after time and expose the corruption, the rorting and the dishonesty of this government and how crooked and unaccountable it has become.

PARA.TAB: This is not a censure motion relating to the giving of Dr Peter Macdonald's tax file number. This is a censure motion about the Prime Minister's piggery. This is a censure motion about everything that Prime Minister Keating has never liked about Senator Baume's contributions in the Senate. How many contributions do you have to make before the Prime Minister takes exception to them and you get censured? Is it one, two, three, four or 14? Will Senator Evans tell us? No, because the government cannot draw the line and tell us what is reasonable conduct and what is not. It does not know what reasonable conduct is.

This is not—and heaven help us if it ever became—the federal conference of the ALP. This is not a place where you get the numbers and you thump the living daylights out of the people who do not have the numbers. Senator Sherry is sitting over there smiling. He is probably punch drunk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Baldwin.

—Yes, ask Peter Baldwin. This is not the federal conference of the ALP; this is the Senate of the parliament of Australia. This Senate has inherited hundreds of years of privilege. Through torture, persecution, imprisonment and, in some cases, loss of life other people have fought to ensure the freedom of the parliament. This Senate has inherited hundreds of years of Westminster tradition which says that parliamentarians should have an unfettered opportunity to bring forward matters in the public interest. Yet what this motion says is that you cannot do that if somebody on the other side decides it is for political advantage and not in the public interest. What test are we to apply?
—It will be the death of democracy.

—It will be the death of democracy. But what test are we to apply? Surely if an honourable senator on this side uncovers a scandal which affects the government by showing—and Senator Chapman may have an interest in these matters—that there has been corruption in government, that government ministers have acted improperly and that senior public servants have given favours to the mates of important ministers, that is a matter that is in the public interest.

PARA.TAB: Heaven help us, because no honourable senator on this side could ever raise those matters because senators on the other side could characterise the action as being for political advantage. Honourable senators will be prohibited under pain of censure from raising a matter which they believe to be in the public interest because somebody else can come in and say that it is being done for political advantage.

Here we have a situation where a censure motion can say that Senator Baume, Senator Chapman, Senator Brownhill, Senator McGauran or any honourable senator on this side of the chamber is not allowed to raise a matter of public interest if it is damaging to the government or if it damages the government's political interests. That is the heart of the charge before the Senate today: that Senator Baume did something for political interest.

Senator Chamarette, on the other side of the chamber, is a person whom I respect. There are many issues on which Senator Chamarette and I would disagree violently, and she acknowledges that. I respect Senator Chamarette's right to raise those matters which may be in her political interest and contrary to my political interest or the political interest of the people whom I represent. But if we say that this censure motion should be passed, Senator Chamarette and I will be censuring each other every day of the week, every time we have a disagreement.

This is not how the Senate should be conducted. This is not how a court of law should be conducted. This is not how the parliament of Australia should be conducted. Take the trial back to Cuba. Throw out the charges. Recognise that this is a witch hunt presided over by a Chief Justice, by Robespierre, by a failed witness for the prosecution and by a law clerk. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday night I was disgusted at what I had to listen to and see. I was one of the senators in the chamber during the adjournment debate. I felt, and still feel, that there was no need for Senator Baume to quote chapter and verse from a letter from the Australian Taxation Office to Dr Peter Macdonald, particularly as it would appear to transpire from listening to later material given on the public record outside of coward's castle that this was only half the story.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume obviously also waited until he could be one of the last speakers in the debate. He had done it a couple of nights previously. When the speakers' list was presented to the President, Senator Baume was at the top but he managed to find his way down to the bottom. So it was a very definite, deliberate act to make sure that the minimum opportunity existed for people to refute, rebut and correct what might have been said.

Nobody in this place is in a position to have any knowledge of the taxation situation of members in the houses of the other states. I always thought that that was the way it should be, but that was not what happened on Thursday night. When I went home on Friday and moved around in the community—and certainly on Saturday when I did a lot of work on polling booths—the one thing that people kept talking about was what had happened in the adjournment debate on Thursday night. They were appalled and disgusted that an independent person—somebody who was not a senator in this chamber—would have his tax matters thrown about willy-nilly in parliament under parliamentary privilege.

A lot of people are complaining and criticising us in the general public for what they see and hear as the standard of behaviour of members of parliament. They do not particularly like what they see and hear in parliament. What has brought us into even more disrepute out there in the general public is the attack by Senator Baume on somebody who was not in this house and therefore not able to defend himself, and the use of a letter from the tax office to that particular person which was not for the public record.

Some members of the opposition have a bit of a double standard whenever it comes to legislation that relates to privacy. I notice Senator Patterson has gone but she is one of the opposition's best advocates of privacy for individuals and it is a pity—

TALK.START.PARA: —She's back.

—She has come back, good. Senator Patterson would be one of the people I would admire most for her defence of privacy for people. I wonder how people like that feel when they see innocent people outside this place having their tax file numbers thrown willy-nilly, high wide and wonderful. Senator Baume has been around this place long enough to know that if a letter from the tax office has nine digits on it then it is a pretty good guess that that is the tax file number. We know that most of the tax file numbers have nine digits for the individual and I think it is eight digits—

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and they happened to correspond, as I recall, too. Isn't it amazing! But let us get back to what the attitude of people out there in the general public is. They are appalled and disgusted at the behaviour of members of parliament; they are appalled and disgusted at the things that are said and they feel that this is not the way that things should be done. It is disgusting to them. It is neither appropriate nor acceptable to them that this type of behaviour should go on.

PARA.TAB: What this has done is just to bring us into further disrepute with the general public. I think it is high time that the Privileges Committee looked at the behaviour of people in throwing around material that is confidential in nature, material that can harm people and material containing accusations and allegations about people who are not here in this chamber to defend themselves. The Senate does have a mechanism where people are able to make a statement to the chamber but very few people know about that and very few people would feel that they would want to even be bothered with the amount of disgusting behaviour that happens in this place. They do not like it. It is not acceptable.

Thursday night and the actions since then have done nothing to raise the view of the general public about the behaviour of members of parliament and that I deplore. I think it is appalling that we are not behaving to the standard we should be. On occasions we are all guilty of behaviour that is not as it should be. However, the behaviour on Thursday night reached a new low and for that people should support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this matter because the Greens take it much more seriously than the level of debate I witnessed last night from my room on the monitor and unfortunately at closer hand here in the chamber last night and also today. I must make it clear that I was happy to support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, because I feel it is a very serious matter.

PARA.TAB: However, I was pleased that Senator Baume gave his personal explanation on Monday after notice of the motion was given, and also his comments last night, and I acknowledge that he has said that it was an inadvertent disclosure. I think this happens to all of us. At times, in our responsibility for putting things into the public arena by tabling and using the privilege we have in parliament, we may inadvertently do things that we would not necessarily be happy about at a later stage.

In recognition of that and also in recognition of the fact that we have only today and tomorrow left to consider quite a substantial list of business that I believe it would be irresponsible of the Senate to neglect, I want to propose an amendment to the motion. I would urge the opposition, the government, the Democrats and Senator Harradine to consider supporting the amendment and progressing this issue to a point where we do two things. We need, firstly, to acknowledge that we have a very serious matter before us and, secondly, to get on with other matters. We need to resolve this matter and not get into party political point scoring. Both sides of this chamber are capable of doing things that, in the view of the other parties, are reprehensible. As I think Senator O'Chee pointed out earlier, we quite often do things that others in the chamber feel are reprehensible. We have the right to express that; we have the right to vote on it.

I am not sure whether my amendment has been circulated in the chamber. As I said before, I am proposing to move the amendment not because I am not prepared to support the motion but because I am not prepared to see the next two days taken up with the right of reply, which I believe the opposition legitimately has to a censure motion. So I am proposing this amendment in good faith.

I have discussed this matter at great length with the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), who I believe has discussed it with Senator Baume. I am not expecting the opposition to be pleased with the amendment, but I am offering it as a way of resolving this matter so that we can get on with dealing with the business of the Senate. I have also discussed it at length with Senator Evans. I do not think either party is particularly happy with it, but I am endeavouring to achieve a resolution which accepts that there is a kernel of truth in all the arguments that have been put forward in this place in regard to this matter and to progress the business of the Senate. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraphs (b) and (d), omit the paragraphs, insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: ``(b)deplores

TAB.TAB: (i)Senator Baume's negligence in tabling a document in which he inadvertently revealed Dr Macdonald's tax file number, disclosure of which would have been a crime if done outside the Parliament, and

(ii)his judgment in putting on public record for reasons of political advantage material to which the person had inadequate opportunity to respond, thereby denying him natural justice and an immediate right of reply''.

SPEECH.PARA: I am quite happy to speak to that amendment. I believe that the amendment summarises my concerns about the matter which would have led me to support the censure—that is, not only the revelation of the tax file number, which I know all of us acknowledge is a most heinous thing to do, but also the understanding that it was inadvertent and that it was overlooked by both sides of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I think it is adequate to simply deplore the fact that that occurred. Secondly, I believe that the timing of that disclosure could have had political ramifications that were very unfair. In respect of the subsequent disclosure, it appears that it, just like the tax file revelation, was inadvertent. There was an explanation offered which revealed that Dr Macdonald's taxation matters involved an inadvertent error too. I think there is a balance there. But I believe that making this available two days before an election at which Dr Macdonald was a candidate and not allowing him to have the same kind of privilege we do in this place is unfair. We have the chance of reply in respect of inaccurate material that is tabled.

That privilege was not available to Dr Macdonald. I believe therefore that we should deplore the timing of the tabling and the fact that there was a denial of natural justice in that there was no opportunity for an immediate response and no ability to contradict any matters of fact that might have arisen. I urge the Senate and my colleagues to respond quickly to my amendment as a way of resolving this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find Senator Chamarette's proposal an attractive way of resolving this issue and getting on with the business of the parliament. We have had the heat turned up considerably because of the fact that this is a censure motion and also because there has been some discussion about what it is that Senator Baume deserves censure for, if at all.

PARA.TAB: I like Senator Baume. I like his tenacity. This parliament needs people who are not easily discouraged from their perceived mission. I remind the Senate that I sat here in this seat for some years next to former Senator Paul McLean while he pleaded with the Leader of the Government and the Leader of the Opposition to allow documents to be tabled—documents which he had decided were in fact dynamite in terms of the public interest. These particular documents challenged the moral integrity of one of Australia's largest commercial institutions and were very dangerous. They clearly revealed exploitation of Australian citizens, the institution's own customers, and Australia's farmers and business people. Some of those people have been ruined by the actions of the institution. The institution was the Westpac bank and the documents were the Westpac letters.

Paul McLean had carefully read, cross-referenced, detailed and filed all of those documents and he knew that they were definitely in the greater public interest. We—that is, former Senator Paul McLean and I—were both amazed at the unwillingness of both parties to step outside the politicking and to really consider the greater public interest. Eventually the Democrats worked as a team across Australia and were able to table those documents in the South Australian parliament, and subsequently Paul McLean's efforts have been vindicated. I have learned from that example how difficult it can sometimes be to cajole this chamber into achieving something or acting in the greater public interest.

I recount that for the benefit of the Senate because it is sometimes necessary to be persistent, and persistent Senator Baume certainly is. But I have to ask in this instance whether the matter of concern was in fact in the greater public interest. I quote from Senator Baume's contribution last night. He told us: `I was so interested in the amount of tax avoidance I did not focus on the fact that there was a number on the document which was a tax file number.' I ask: what is it that was being tabled? It was a tax document. What should be on every tax document in existence in Australia? Surely it is not a tax document unless it has a tax file number on it. The very first thing you would look for would be a tax file number. All the communications I have had with the Australian Taxation Office have required the inclusion of my tax file number, and I would assume that to be the case here.

Now, whether that is true in all instances is not the point. I would have thought it would be logical to expect there to be a great likelihood of there being a tax file number on the document. I would be looking on any document that I described as a tax document for a tax file number. Whether Senator Baume took the trouble to scour that document or not, I suggest that there is another principle at stake as well. That is that for those people who seek to table a document in this place, there is a responsibility attached to the tabler, and that responsibility should be to ensure that the document is both accurate and legitimate and that it does not defame or make life difficult in any way that is not intended by the tabling.

Here we have a situation where Senator Baume was criticising a person who had prepared a document, or who had paid a third party to prepare a document, and had discovered that there was something wrong with that document. He had then taken retrospective action to correct it. Surely that is similar, even parallel, to the action taken by Senator Baume himself. Yet Senator Baume seeks to condemn Dr Macdonald for having done something, discovering that he had not done quite the right thing and then retrospectively correcting it.

Dr Macdonald was in a situation where no charges were pending. The Taxation Office was satisfied. The New South Wales Premier was satisfied. No further action was being contemplated by anybody. Yet Senator Baume says that he believes Dr Macdonald had a duty to reveal this to his electorate. Why was this forum chosen—this particular forum? If Senator Baume believed that Dr Macdonald had a duty to reveal this to his electorate, why not have it revealed in the New South Wales parliament or in a forum within which Dr Macdonald would have had an opportunity to respond? I repeat: why this forum? If revelation were to be especially undertaken in this place, a great responsibility attached to the accuracy of that revelation.

I think we have a situation here where, as I said earlier, a little bit of the sting can be taken out. I was very tempted by the original proposition put by Senator Gareth Evans. In listening to the debate from Senator Hill, I find there is cause for some correction to be considered. I was disappointed with the manner in which Senator Hill made his criticisms. I was reminded more of a school boarding house, with the giggling and cackling which accompanied the revelation of what was wrong. However, when one looked past the school-boyish attitude, the substance did have some appeal. I was seeking to challenge that substance and to look at a path which was not quite so vindictive.

We have here that opportunity. I am only sorry that I did not think of it. When I was listening to Senator Hill last night, I was distracted by the attitude being displayed rather than listening to the substance of the criticisms. It is unfortunate that we take something so serious and reduce it to the sorts of antics that we saw last night.

This is a serious matter. I tried to indicate that when I looked at the principles that are involved in tabling documents in this place. I treat it very seriously. I think, at the very least, the way that document was tabled should be deplored—and that is at the very least. We would support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have preferred to have had the last say. However, the amendment that has been moved by the Greens is in a form that we still regard as unsatisfactory. It certainly removes the stigma of a censure—and I am pleased to see that some commonsense has prevailed in that regard. But, when it deals in terms of deploring Senator Baume's negligence in tabling the document in which he inadvertently revealed Dr Macdonald's tax file number, I think it should be properly understood—and this is what Senator Bell in his gratuitous comments of a few minutes ago failed to appreciate—that the document did not refer to a tax file number at all.

PARA.TAB: The document referred simply to `file number'. But you came in here wanting to condemn him with a censure not only for inadvertently tabling that but also for inadvertently failing to appreciate that it was a tax file number when it did not say it was a tax file number. All that demonstrates is that this whole motion has been brought with malice. This is where the Democrats have got it again. They are so precious. The government does not come in here with any good faith in this matter. It is just a political hatchet job. We all know that. It is all in the environment that exists in Australian politics at the moment.

So the numbers are going to be here today, unfortunately, to resolve that Senator Baume be condemned for his negligence in tabling a document in which he inadvertently revealed a tax file number even though it did not specifically state that it was a tax file number. That is unfortunate, but I accept that it is a lot better than what the government was seeking, which was a censure.

I take it from Senator Bell's comments that he would have been inclined to support the censure. That tells me more about the Australian Democrats than anything else. Senator Chamarette said this morning that she was inclined to support the censure, although at least she had the goodwill to say that she acknowledged the apology Senator Baume had made.

We all make errors. No matter how much care we apply, we make mistakes. Generally, in the spirit of goodwill in this place if you make an inadvertent mistake and you then apologise, that is the end of the matter. Apparently that is not good enough for the others in this chamber, but it is at least better than a censure. I am glad that, although it has taken some time, at least that issue is resolved.

The second part of Senator Chamarette's amendment is that she deplores his judgment. This is the input into these matters concerning Dr Macdonald's understatement of his taxable income on the public record, she says without him having adequate time to respond. That is again a judgment for individuals to make. It is a balancing act. Even the motion as drawn by Senator Evans demonstrates that he recognises that it is a balance between what an individual senator believes should be on the public record in order that the public might assess the suitability of a person for parliamentary office on the one hand, and on the other hand any invasion of personal privacy that results therefrom.

Every time we intrude into matters relating to whether a person is fit and proper there has to be an element of invasion of privacy, but we accept that because we are in public life. There will always be a balancing act. But to come in here and try to turn that into a censurable offence was not well founded and Senator Evans knows that. It is just part of the politics of the time.

I am pleased that at least the numbers are such that a censure will not result in this place. That would have been deplorable. I regret that the numbers are still such that the Senate will apparently, despite our opposition, deplore that Senator Baume exercised his judgment so that the balance went in favour of public revelation, but so be it. Senator Baume certainly understands what it means; it simply means that the government and the minority parties have made a judgment that, on balance, personal privacy considerations should have overridden the public right to know. That is all it really amounts to. So be it.

I am particularly pleased that commonsense has prevailed to the extent that the attempt to send Senator Baume to the Privileges Committee over this matter is being abandoned. That would have been a disgrace and an abuse of the function of the Privileges Committee. Again it has taken a fair while to get to this stage but I am pleased the amendment deletes that proposal.

So we recognise that the amendment that is being moved is less offensive than the original motion, although we are still not happy with it. When it is carried and the substantive motion is put we will oppose the substantive motion and divide on it. But we put on record the fact that we are at least pleased that the potential of a censure has been abandoned and that the effort of the government to send Senator Baume to the Privileges Committee has also been abandoned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to intervene in this debate, but I suppose I had better do so, having listened to it for some considerable hours now, because I think it is a very important issue and one that needs to be considered by each and every member of the chamber. Having listened carefully to what has been said from all sides of the chamber, I am not in a position to vote for the censure motion.

PARA.TAB: `Censure', in the parliamentary sense, is the most vigorous and, I suppose, the most serious of all reflections against a member of the parliament; and the explanations that have been given by Senator Baume do not warrant that.

In my view, the action is to be deplored. Although it is acknowledged that the action was inadvertent, the action of tabling documents which contain a tax file number is to be deplored, despite the fact—and I accept what Senator Baume says—that it was difficult to identify whether it was a file number or a tax file number unless you were looking for the position. Nevertheless, it is a matter which is to be deplored, and I think Senator Baume has really acknowledged that in his letter to Dr Macdonald.

I have listened carefully to what Senator Chamarette said in respect of her amendment. She proposes to delete what has just been acknowledged by Senator Hill to be a rather bizarre situation; that is, after you have hanged a person you send it to the Privileges Committee and then, as I heard Senator Schacht say last night, he will have an opportunity of making his case before the Privileges Committee. My goodness, you cannot just hang a person and then send it to the Privileges Committee and say that there he has an opportunity for natural justice. That matter has been taken care of in Senator Chamarette's amendment.

However, Senator Chamarette's amendment does deplore the situation—I think the situation is something which we all deplore—and I believe that it is a reasonable amendment. I will be supporting that amendment, with a couple of minor amendments which I believe go to the factual situation. I foreshadow that I will be moving those amendments after Senator Chamarette's amendment has been, I hope, adopted and before the question is put. Paragraph (a)(iii) of the motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: (iii)that Senator Baume's only stated purpose in tabling these documents was to impugn the integrity of Dr Macdonald before the New South Wales State election in which Dr Macdonald was an independent candidate,

My foreshadowed motion would delete the word `only'. I listened to what Senator Baume said, and I do not think it is accurate to keep the word `only' there. The part of the motion which mentions `to impugn the integrity' should, in my view, be `to question the integrity'. The motion would therefore read `that Senator Baume's stated purpose in tabling these documents was to question the integrity of Dr Macdonald'. The next line of the motion says:
(iv)that Senator Baume, in seeking the leave of the duty Minister and the Senate to table the documents in question . . .

I would like the words `was not aware of and thus' inserted after that. The motion would then read `in seeking the leave of the duty Minister and the Senate to table the documents in question was not aware of and thus did not draw attention to the tax file number identified therein'. I think that is a more accurate reflection. I think it would be a reasonably strong motion if it were adopted with amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was not aware of whether or not he should have been.

—I am talking about Senator Chamarette's amendment. I think it is expressing the fact that we deplore that this has happened. Even Senator Baume deplores that this occurred. In a way it was difficult to ascertain whether they were file numbers or tax file numbers, but a situation occurred where they were tabled in the parliament, and that is something which we all should deplore. The government should accept, in my view, Senator Chamarette's amendment. I trust it will accept my further addendum, which clarifies the situation as a matter of fact. I believe that we should stick to the facts in this case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might briefly explain the government's position on this. The only attractive feature of Senator Chamarette's amendment is that it will enable us to get on with the business of this Senate, which has ground obviously to a halt as a result of the opposition's obvious determination to filibuster at least so long as the censure motion in its present form remains before us.

PARA.TAB: The government does not resile from any of the points made in the original terms of the motion or in debate. It may well be that Senator Baume's action in putting the tax file number on the record was not, as he said, deliberate or intentional in that respect. Whatever else I might think about Senator Baume, I do not doubt his intelligence, and it would have been a manifestly extremely silly thing to do to deliberately put a tax file number on the record. However, there is an issue of negligence. There is an issue of reckless indifference to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you accused me of doing it deliberately.

—I did not say that. I said Senator Baume deliberately sought to impugn the integrity of Dr Macdonald. I said that. I did not at any stage check the Hansard, check the terms of the motion. I did not say he deliberately put the tax file number on the record.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that, if you are looking for a criminal mental element to justify an offence being pursued through the criminal courts, as would be the case here had this happened outside, you can find that criminal intent not only in deliberate intention to do the act in question but also in a state of mind of negligence or a state of mind of reckless indifference as to the criminality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Negligence?
—Yes, extreme negligence. That can constitute the criminal element. Senator Hill knows that perfectly well.
—Negligence does not normally constitute that.

—Not normally. Not necessarily normally. It depends on all the circumstances of the case and whether it is a statutory offence, full scale and all the rest of it. There is a lot of law in all that, as Senator Hill would be well aware. The terms of the government motion did not go to that question of deliberation versus negligence versus recklessness. It just said that the dirty deed was done, and it was. So, accordingly, we do not resile from that.

PARA.TAB: Quite apart from the tax file number issue, the government's position has been and remains that it was a manifestly gross breach of Dr Macdonald's rights to make what were manifestly unfounded allegations about his moral culpability in dealing with his own tax returns. Obviously he had understated his income. The circumstances of that were not such as to be treated by the Taxation Office as justifying a penalty. It was unquestionably an impugning of his integrity, a deliberate impugning of his integrity, to put the matter on the record in the way that it was done, at the time that it was done, in the context that it was done.

I do not track back over all this. The points have been made. I simply make the point that that remains our position. All that said, the amendment still makes it clear that the Senate does deplore both aspects of Senator Baume's behaviour. That appears to be the most that is achievable by way of outcomes in this chamber at the moment. So be it.

When a government does not have a majority in this place, either for substantive matters or for procedural matters, then sometimes you just have to accept less than optimal outcomes and, as I say, so be it. The government will accept the amendment and accordingly, under these circumstances, will accept thereby that the point has been made and the government will accordingly get on with the legislative business now pressing upon us.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Subparagraphs (a)(iii) and (iv), omit the subparagraphs, substitute the following subparagraphs:

TAB.TAB: ``(iii)that Senator Baume's stated purpose in tabling these documents was to question the integrity of Dr Macdonald before the New South Wales State election in which Dr Macdonald was an independent candidate,

(iv)that Senator Baume, in seeking the leave of the duty Minister and the Senate to table the documents in question, was not aware of and thus did not draw attention to the tax file number identified therein, publication of which otherwise than under cover of parliamentary privilege was a criminal offence''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate for the record that the government is not inclined to accept these amendments. When you look at the purpose articulated by Senator Baume for tabling the documents, you find him saying that the reason for him doing what he did is that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Dr Macdonald's own taxation record shows a lack of integrity that must be of major concern to his constituents in Manly.

Senator Baume does not say, `These documents raise questions about his lack of integrity.' Senator Baume asserts that there was a lack of integrity and that it was demonstrated by these documents. I simply do not think Senator Harradine's amendment is factually accurate.

PARA.TAB: Sometimes you use the word `question' in a loose way, but it was not questions being asked here; it was assertions being made. I think the record ought not to be diluted accordingly. As to the word `only', Senator Baume did not articulate any other reason for doing what he did, so I do not think we should leave open the inference that there was some other reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said `public interest'.

—He said public interest. Okay. He said it, but whether he plausibly said it such as to justify amending the thing in this way is another question. As to the question of whether Senator Baume was not aware of the tax file number being there, maybe he was not aware of it but he should have been aware of it. That is the government's position. When you have got a document which says `file number' on it, you do not have to be Einstein to make the judgment that that is a tax file number. Someone who had long enough, as Senator Baume did, to look at the implications of the document should have made that judgment.

PARA.TAB: I do not pursue the matter. I do not pursue it to the point of division. I simply make the point for the record that the government does not believe these are simple matters of fact to amend the matter in the way Senator Harradine has proposed. We think a different interpretation applies but, again, I do not want to waste any time on it so I will not press that opposition to the point of division.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support the amendment; the improvements seem to be sensible. The minister can be put out of his misery.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gareth Evans's), as amended, be agreed to.
