PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Herron had moved by way of an amendment:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a)notes that the Pharmacy Agreement, which is the subject of this Bill and which is to take effect from 1 April 1995, is still being negotiated by the Government;
(b)notes that this is far from being the only instance of the Government legislating in anticipation of a set of circumstances which are still to be resolved; and
(c)condemns the Government for its continual treatment of the Parliament as a rubber stamp of executive action".

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now some weeks since I commenced my speech in this debate on the National Health Amendment Bill (No.2). It is somewhat concerning to think that the government has just delayed this bill. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia is very concerned about the delay that has been caused by the maladministration of this government. We have just seen another classical example of this. We spent all night last night and this morning debating a futile motion of censure. The government should get its priorities right.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, the National Health Amendment Bill (No.2) makes changes which will impact on the communities of rural and remote areas of Australia. I would have thought it was important to this government to have these changes in place. It has now left it to the deadline of Friday before the effect of this legislation will be felt by pharmacies right throughout the country.

Given that these areas are already greatly disadvantaged by the government's health policy, or lack of it, I am keen to make sure that their access to pharmacies can be guaranteed. It is not an optimal outcome that people have to travel hundreds of kilometres to visit a pharmacist. The reality of this government is that it does not seem to mind that it makes country people—particularly in my state of Western Australia—travel very long distances to pharmacies. All of the changes that it made many years ago ensured that that was to be the case.

Lack of community consultation on this bill contradicts the stated aims of the national rural health strategy, which sought increased community consultation and participation in the development and implementation of rural health strategies. As I also said earlier, people in rural areas already experience more pronounced health problems in areas such as mental illness, suicide, road trauma and substance abuse, including alcohol. These are described in the national rural health strategy, along with other health problems such as ear and eye infections, diabetes and respiratory disorders, which disproportionately affect the Aboriginal communities of Australia. The strategy also noted that, compared with their metropolitan counterparts, many rural residents experience significant problems of inequity with respect to access to and provision of health care services.

It is no secret that the Department of Human Services and Health is having a hard time trying to attract medical practitioners to country areas. This has been the case for some years now. What still concerns me—and I know it concerns Senator Herron, coming from a large state like Queensland—is that we are not attracting enough doctors into rural parts of Australia, particularly in the isolated and larger states such as Queensland and Western Australia. Although I must admit that it is an Australia wide problem, it is particularly pertinent to my state of Western Australia.

Yet for all the discussion papers and strategies, there appears to have been little noticeable effect on rural health, as evidenced by the recent paper from the ANU. The maldistribution of health services continues. I would hope that, as pharmacies are rationalised through amalgamation and closure, there is not a negative impact on rural and remote communities, despite the existence of safety net provisions to support the survival of such pharmacies.

Already the number of pharmacies in Australia has declined by 10 per cent, which is in line with the aim of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. It is believed that the number of pharmacies is now at a more viable level. We are yet to see that and make sure that country people are not disadvantaged. As to whether viability is synonymous with adequate service provisions, I would think rural and remote communities and the health interest groups within those communities should be allowed to be the judge of that in line with the government's stated policy on consulting with rural communities.

I certainly encourage the government to have more consultation with doctors, health professionals, pharmacists and those in the communities of country areas. Until this is taking place in an ongoing fashion, we can be assured of only one thing: that those in the country will continue to be disadvantaged, although they can no longer afford to be so. This has gone on far too long. I hope that this government makes a positive move to ensuring that consultation and following action occurs in the interest of country people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will spend a few minutes responding to the debate on the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 [1995]. I thank senators for their comments on the bill, and I will provide information on the matters raised.

PARA.TAB: The bill, in effect, makes relatively small changes to the National Health Act to allow a new agreement with pharmacies to operate if a suitable agreement is negotiated. The amendments in no way pre-empt parliament but simply set in place a structure within which an agreement can operate and, therefore, be negotiated. The administrative details of the agreement would be contained in determinations which are subject to parliamentary disallowance.

Obviously, it is very difficult to negotiate an agreement if the legislation is not in place for it to operate. The government cannot accept the amendment as proposed by Senator Herron. The government fully supports the authority of the parliament to come to its own decision on legislation, and I have explained the circumstances behind these amendments. Since part of the current agreement ends at the end of this month, the amendments are very important. Negotiations on the details of the new agreement are currently under way with the peak pharmacy groups.

The primary changes proposed in the amendments are as follows. Firstly, to terminate the payments currently being offered to pharmacists when handing back approval numbers. Over 600 approval numbers have been cashed in during the current agreement. The number and quality of approved pharmacies is, therefore, much more satisfactory, with many of the pharmacies which have closed being small, inefficient businesses.

Secondly, to permit the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to deal with matters wider than just dispensing fees. The amendments would allow the tribunal to consider allowances for other professional services which might evolve in the future.

I agree with the concern that the administrative arrangements for such allowances must be carefully worked out. The first allowance will be for a regular medication review of residents in nursing homes. The need and value of this service has been proven in many studies. At this stage, the allocation referred to in the memorandum only reflects this initial function. The allowance will not commence until the administrative details are finalised.

The Pharmacy Guild, the Pharmaceutical Society and the Society of Hospital Pharmacists intend to form a society of consultant pharmacists. This society will establish the training standards and the standards of practice for pharmacists to be eligible for consideration for professional allowances where they have a contract for medication review with a nursing home.

The third primary change proposed in the amendments is to continue incentive payments for pharmacies operating in remote areas. The current allowances have been very successful in encouraging pharmacy services in isolated areas. In discussion with the Isolated and Essential Pharmacy Association, it was agreed to continue the current two allowances under the new names of remote and isolated pharmacy allowances.

The fourth change is to have a body of practising pharmacists to advise on application for new pharmacies to supply pharmaceutical benefits and professional allowances. The body, the Australian Community Pharmacy Authority, would replace the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority. With a majority of members being practising pharmacists, it provides effective input by the profession into the circumstances under which an approval might be recommended.

Both the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, the two big organisations representing community pharmacy, have been involved in the negotiations for a new agreement. Obviously in the remuneration aspects of the agreement the guild is the primary body with which the government negotiates. At all times the primary objective of the negotiations for both pharmacy and the government is to provide good access for the Australian community to pharmaceutical benefits through a well-distributed network of approved pharmacies to the benefit of community health.

Valuable experience has been gained from the 4 1/2 years of the current agreement which has been used in formulating a new agreement. For example, it is intended to give much more flexibility in relocating approved pharmacies to places of need which will remove many of the tensions that have occurred with the current agreement. It will also remove such behaviours as leapfrogging where a few people relocated several short distances to get around the current requirements.

Without doubt, the current agreement has worked extremely well to provide a better distribution of pharmacies to supply pharmaceutical benefits. It has also provided stability and cooperation between government and community pharmacy. This has enabled community pharmacy to concentrate on improving health services and, therefore, health outcomes, which has benefited all consumers. The government is proposing one amendment to the bill and that is to permit a new agreement to operate up to five years instead of the four years as currently in the bill. The government has accepted pharmacies' view that five years is more consistent with business decisions such as the period of commercial leases. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule, page 11, Abstract, omit "26 Department of Defence . . . . 214 880 000", substitute "26 Department of Defence . . . . 13 339 000".
2.Schedule, page 11, Abstract, omit "Total . . . . 675 722 000", substitute "Total . . . . 474 181 000".
3.Schedule, page 15, omit "Department of Defence . . . . —214 880 000 214 880 000", substitute "Department of Defence . . . . —13 339 000 13 339 000".
5.Schedule, page 26, omit "181 Equipment and Stores . . . . —186 338 000 186 338 000", substitute "181 Equipment and Stores . . . . ———".
6.Schedule, page 26, omit "183 Defence Production . . . . —2 030 000 2 030 000", substitute "183 Defence Production . . . . ———".
7.Schedule, page 26, omit "Defence Facilities . . . . — 13 173 000 13 173 000", substitute "185 Defence Facilities . . . . ———".
8.Schedule, page 26, omit "Total . . . . — 214 880 214 880", substitute "Total . . . . — 13 339 000 13 339 000".
9.Schedule, page 27, omit Division 181, Equipment and Stores.
10.Schedule, page 27, omit Division 183, Defence Production.
11.Schedule, page 27, omit Division 185, Defence Facilities.
12.Schedule, page 27, omit "Total: Department of Defence . . . . 214 880 000", substitute "Total: Department of Defence . . . . 13 339 000".

The requests for amendments are simple. They change the totals on several pages—pages 11, 15 and 16—as a consequence of changes on pages 26 and 27. These changes are the deletion of the appropriations for equipment and stores, defence production and defence facilities. It leaves behind the administration and defence housing appropriations for reasons that I have already outlined.

PARA.TAB: The financial impact of these changes is to reduce the defence appropriation from $214,880,000 to $13,339,000. This is a saving of $201,541,000. It is a huge amount of money. I have already given the substantive arguments in the second reading debate and remind senators that these additional appropriations are for needs that have arisen since the budget. They are needs that result from decisions of parliament requiring additional funds for some minor variation, although the government has a responsibility to have a contingency reserve for such purposes in its annual budget. It is normally item 9(c) in the outlay section of the main budget papers. Item 9(c), the contingency reserve, was $228 million in the last budget.

Additional appropriations may also represent unforeseen demand and unrestricted services such as unemployment payments. They may represent exceptional expenses such as drought relief. Only the defence housing and administration section of the requests appear to represent anything like this situation.

The defence requests do not generally fall into any of these categories. I cannot see anything exceptional here or anything requiring urgent action. Several items should have been, and probably were, well known beforehand. If this is so, not including them in the budget is simply subterfuge to make the defence budget appear smaller.

In point of fact, in the last budget it was publicly announced that the defence budget would be smaller this year. Defence spending was supposed to be down. This may have been because of consistent criticism about the fact that defence seems to be immune to the cuts we see in other portfolios and the fact that many polls have shown that, while people are willing to pay more tax for services they value, they would like to see defence spending cut. In the last budget it was announced that defence spending would be cut by $163 million. Now we see that this was not true. There is an additional appropriation of nearly $215 million, meaning that defence spending did not go down, as announced; it is actually going up. There certainly appears little urgency or need to give this handout of over $200 million a few months before a new budget comes down.

In 1992 the combined defence budgets for Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines was $US8,471 million. In 1992-93 our defence budget was $9,435 million. With this additional appropriation, our defence budget this year will be $9,852 million. Next year the defence budget has been flagged to go up another four per cent, so it will be over $10 billion.

Much of this money is for equipment. There are problems with some of the equipment expenditures. In spite of what Senator Ray says, the issues I have generally raised are not philosophical questions about whether we should have such a huge Defence Force and put about 10c in every dollar into defence expenditure, although this question is worth asking. It is especially worth while asking in a time of peace when we are actively trying to sell weapons to our neighbours and are training them here and inviting them to our military exercises. It is especially worth while asking when both major parties express great concern over the budget and call for cuts in target areas such as child care.

I would like to point out that, in relation to the child-care rebate that Mr Beazley floated as an area for cuts, the entire program costs only $152 million—three-quarters of what Defence spends in this little extra top up before us. The proposed cuts in the child-care rebate were later toned down as `only means testing' which might conceivably save $1 million, yet here we are expected to hand over $200 million without a blink. It is $200 million here for equipment which is in addition to an annual budget for equipment of $3,677 million.

Next year the budget for equipment is estimated to be $4,152 million. That is over $4 billion a year, and just for equipment. By comparison, all public, primary and secondary schools got only $1,094 million this year, a reduction of 13 per cent, or about $200 million. When you add the public, primary and secondary schools costing about $1.1 billion to the $1.6 billion the federal government gives to private primary and secondary education, and add in all joint programs, Aboriginal programs and other types of programs for primary and secondary schools, the whole thing is only $3 billion, yet we spend over $4 billion on rifles, submarines and planes without thinking twice.

Let us look again at the figures for public schools, public primary and secondary schools, education for ordinary people between kindergarten and the end of high school. That budget is only about $1 billion. It went down this year by 13.3 per cent. Not only is the budget going down; last year's budget was underspent by $20 million. I hope no-one has the temerity to claim that this was because education is in such good shape. Class sizes are at record level and teachers are under immense pressure, with major strikes occurring in Western Australia over treatment and pay levels, and no matter what federal ministers say about state responsibility, the federal government is cutting funds and pushing its benchmarking and other `efficiency programs' which are only ways of saying that class sizes should go up as a way of cutting costs.

This year not unique. The infrastructure in schools has been run down for years. Things are getting worse rapidly. Education was a major electoral issue in the ACT, with both major parties promising relief for parents having to pay parent contribution and engage in continuous fund raising activities even to keep their schools going. Yet class sizes have been moving inexorably from the high 30s to over 40 children in a class. That is not efficient. Whatever economists say about increased productivity, the quality of education goes down and the time the children spend is less productive.

Appropriations are the area where the actual spending priorities and values of parliament are made quite clear. We do vote on these things and can question those priorities; we can recommend amendments. It is ultimately our responsibility that the education security of all children between the ages of five and 18, our future citizens, is given one quarter of the value that we give the need for new submarines and frigates.

We are saying clearly that the education security of our people is worth less than the ability to make war. We are saying that we need to build up our military force even further and spend four times what we do on public schools, when we already have the greatest military force in our region and at a time of peace when there are no potential threats. Let me make it clear that it is at the expense of our education system that we have decided to use resources in this way and not for education, health or even the environment.

Further, there is the general problem of the budget. At this time, senators and members from both sides of both houses are calling for fiscal restraint. They are demanding that portfolios, like education—basic primary and secondary education for our children—must suffer greater fiscal restraint, must keep moving to bigger class sizes and must try to raise more and more money for basic needs from cake sales and parents' subscriptions. Rural medical services are being shut down. Urban hospitals, such as Woden which is located just up the road, are at crisis point. Public housing is suffering. There is no money for crisis care.

Both major parties are calling for the next budget to be a ruthless one, with social infrastructure being cut even further. If anyone listened to the atrocious press conference on greenhouse, they would realise that the federal government is not prepared to put its money where its mouth is on greenhouse reductions. The current account figures have been characterised as a crisis. At the same time, those who say that there is a crisis requiring strict fiscal management also say that they will not consider any new taxes or revenue. In such circumstances, how can this Defence request be justified—a request of $215 million, which is nearly three times the request of any other department in any of the appropriation bills before us? It is a massive amount.

Sure, Defence might like this money, but is this really the best or most appropriate use for it? I can say in an unqualified way, I am certain that there are several other departments which would love to see this sort of money, which would use it to stem much of the erosion that has occurred. Health could use it easily. Housing and Regional Development could easily find worthy uses that would bring benefit in the future. Education would certainly use it. Why should Defence get it, without even offering a reason?

We have not been given reasons, neither here nor in the additional estimates, that meet anything like any proper process of accountability. We have been given a shopping list. I have serious concerns about some of the expenditure and feel that Defence has been largely obstructive in addressing concerns I have put in estimates committee and in questions on notice. Defence is generally extremely difficult to get any helpful answers from. I object to this. It does not give me any feeling that the hundreds of millions of dollars it now asks for will be well spent. For instance, ask Defence what the process is that it goes under to make these decisions, whether or not it does any kind of cost benefit analysis, whether or not it finds out whether its level of sourcing is actually leading in the right direction. Defence does not do it or, if it does, it is certainly not telling us about it.

We have a Defence department that is quite happy to go out and buy Blackhawk helicopters without bothering to specify how it will use them. They are mainly to be used for long range applications, with the result that most of them are on the ground requiring maintenance. This is not an efficient use of scarce resources nor a responsible acquisition program.

We have Defence deciding to make its own subs and frigates at a huge premium. When the Anzac frigate project was announced, the unit cost per vessel was given as between $240 million and $285 million. This was at a time when the total project cost was given as $3.5 billion for eight vessels. If the same relativities between unit and project costs were to exist today, the unit cost of a frigate would be $320 million, while the project cost—the cost of getting these frigates the way Defence is doing it—would now be $540 million per ship. This would be $220 million per ship above the unit cost.

It appears that the costs of the ships sold to New Zealand were substantially less than those for which the Australian government paid. There seems to be about $1 billion extra here that is essentially a subsidy to the industry and can be counted as a cost to the self-reliance policy, as it is implemented.

In addition, there are the sorts of problems that have been identified by the Auditor-General that may be characterised as excessive generosity to contractors, such as advances given on contracts, such as those that allowed the Australian Submarine Corporation to make $77 million in interest on government funds before it launched a submarine. I acknowledge that since the ANAO reports the defence capital equipment procurement manual has been changed to remedy some of these issues. But for me the problem remains that it is very hard to find out what is going on.

Defence never acknowledges a problem until it is publicly proved. With the Collins class submarines the total project cost is about $820 million per ship. In 1990, when the government was considering additional ships, the cost of these vessels was given as $400 million each. If we take this as the close to true unit cost of the submarines, converted to a current unit cost of $600 million we could say that we are again paying a premium of around $220 million per vessel, the cost of subsidising the defence version of self-reliance.

I have to ask about these things. I ask in estimates and get the run-around. I am told that no answer can be given about why it is a good idea to spend this money designing a unique Collins class submarine instead of achieving the same broad military objectives in some other way with conventional equipment we can buy off the shelf. I am told I cannot get an answer because the Collins is unique. I cannot get an answer as to what makes it unique or why we need these features. I am asked to specify each option I want a comparison with, although I am asking what a $14 million per annum policy unit has done and why it was decided that this very expensive path of building our own was the best way.

I have asked about the frigates and I have been told I could not get an answer because there is nothing unique about an Anzac frigate; it is a conventional design. This is the level of response I get when I try to find out why we are going about equipping ourselves in this way, when it seems an expensive way to do things. Not only do I not get answers; I get personal abuse along the way. I am not alone in this. I know Senator Newman has had some kind of run-around when asking about Blackhawks, or the purchase of helicopter support ships. It is extremely difficult to get a straight answer to a straight question. One has to be both a linguistics expert specialising in military jargon and a mind reader to ask questions in a way Defence cannot avoid answering. Otherwise you get evasion. Even if you do get an answer, it is always on the basis of minimising the useful information transmitted.

Not only do we get this sort of problem. There is the whole question of supported defence government business enterprises in the private defence industry. This involves not only the $14 million policy unit which decides what we need but commercial support programs in logistics that are designed to funnel to industry $400 million in new work each year. In addition, the areas that administer this program—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some real concerns with this appropriation, as does Senator Margetts. I seek some clarification from Senator Margetts regarding her amendment so I know whether to vote on the amendment. I have not seen any written amendment. Is a written amendment available? I have seen different figures proposed. I am not sure if she wants to knock out the $213,533,000 in program 6 that I have in front of me, or just what the amount is. I thank Senator Margetts. I have the amendment now.

PARA.TAB: In general terms we certainly would be in favour of the Greens' amendment, but we have some problems with specifics. The Democrats for some years have looked at cuts in the defence budget but we have tried to target them specifically to programs to which we have a strong objection. However, we are not saying that we want no defence force at all. We are seeking to design a defence force which is truly appropriate to Australia's defence and security needs. The current defence force we have certainly is not that. In the bill which I have before the Senate we have sought to have a public inquiry so that the real needs of Australia's security might be examined on an as wide as possible basis, but as yet that bill has not been debated.

We sought in our submission to the government last year to cut $90 million from the defence budget in the direction in which the Auditor-General has pointed to and identified possible savings. We would agree that the Department of Defence is simply not accountable, and that is one of the real complaints we have. We would obviously want to target things, as we have said previously, like the submarine program, but realise that that has advanced so far now that we wonder whether it is still a feasible target for cuts.

I seek that clarification and, after I have spoken, Senator Margetts may give us a little more help in that direction. I could be persuaded to support the requested amendments, I think, if I could get that, although I agree with Senator Margetts that she has problems in answering those questions because really the department should have given us much clearer indication of where these appropriations were needed.

The work that we have done certainly indicates that there are increases in the operating costs of all three services, as well as increased outlays on capital items. The causes of these increases are just too diverse to be very easily summarised here. It seems that some of the operating costs are due to unforeseen United Nations commitments in Mozambique and Rwanda. Others are due to additional joint exercises.

Again, we probably want to support additional appropriations for peacekeeping activities such as that involved in Rwanda, but I doubt that we would want to support additional joint exercises. I would agree with Senator Margetts that, if that means bringing soldiers from Indonesia to work with our Defence Force, we are opposed to that completely. Fancy teaching people who have butchered their own people how to do it more effectively! I just think that is an appalling proposition.

Here we have again a balancing act that we are trying to do on the floor of the Senate. I want to commend Senator Margetts for the work she did in the estimates committees, but I can hear her frustration: to have spent all that time working out questions and then to get fobbed off is a pretty frustrating exercise.

I note that the internal commitment to capital items is partly funded by an internal budget transfer, but it is unclear which areas of increase are due to project cost escalation. I would like to hear from the minister an explanation which would give us some indication of where some of these additional expenses are needed. I am aware—at least we were given some indication—that, for instance, there was an upgrading of the Orion aircraft to enable them to do coastal surveillance. Again, that would be one activity which we would support. It seems to me that that is something which is very much needed. But this is the problem: we are really trying to balance out information which is not available to us, which makes it very difficult for us to vote for the government's request for these increased appropriations.

I note in one piece of information I have on program 6 that, for instance, there is a reduction of $11,291,000 in new submarines, a reduction of $64,809,000 in the Anzac ships, but an increase of $90 million in the minehunter coastal ships. Again, we might approve of some of that reduction, but it is hard to do that. I note that there is an increase of $1,350,000 which is simply described as `increased provision in defence industry development activity'. What does that mean? I am sure I do not know. The sum of $107,000 is said to be for `miscellaneous minor variations'. I suppose that for the Department of Defence $100,000 is minor. It is certainly not minor if we can apply it to some of the activities which we believe are more appropriate.
So I have this problem. I wonder whether the minister could help us by indicating a little more clearly where these appropriations are needed and by giving us some reasons as to why they are needed.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Senator Woodley, I have been asked to inform you that the requests from Senator Margetts had been circulated on 1 February at 10.50 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —To clarify the situation for Senator Woodley—I thank him for his contribution—we had concerns in relation to the additional appropriations. We certainly did take out funding for administration of defence housing because we believed that, under the general guidelines for additional appropriations, that fitted into the guidelines. The concern with removing or voting against the other items in program 6—which entails such things as equipment and stores, defence production and defence facilities—is that it is not so much whether or not individual items for which these appropriations are being targeted have general support. Our concern is that the additional appropriations process and in fact the budget process are being abused by bringing these up as additional appropriations. These could be quite legitimately, and should be legitimately, in the next budget—in fact, as was foreseen, they should have been in the last budget—so that the truthful picture of government proposed expenditure could be seen.

PARA.TAB: If what is happening is that industry is driving the government's appropriations process, I think there is something wrong with the process, and that is why we are objecting. We obviously have philosophical objections. There are obviously whole bits of this program that we have concerns about—the way decisions have been made, what we see as decisions that may well have wasted hundreds of millions of dollars in that decision making process because that process has remained secret and because that $14-million policy unit is not accessible in its process.

We are asking that the government should not be able to abuse the process of additional appropriations. If the government has given no reason that this is appropriate in terms of using these particular expenditures as an urgent additional appropriation, the appropriate and right place for the government to put these requests is in the budget so that full public scrutiny is possible. That is the problem we have.

As I say, we have philosophical differences. The government and the opposition recognise that we have philosophical differences in approaches. We also have problems with the fact that any cuts seem to be to personnel and, unlike other departments, those cuts do not go into general revenue—they go into more war toys.

Those are the serious problems which we have. But what we are saying here is that the government has not given any of us a reasonable explanation as to why the rest of this expenditure, over $200 million, is urgent, has to be an additional appropriation and cannot wait until the proper time, which is the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rather than trusting my rather rusty mathematics, could Senator Margetts please advise the total amount by which she seeks the appropriation to be reduced?
—I had in fact mentioned this. The financial impact of these changes will be to reduce the defence appropriation from $214,880,000 to $13,339,000. So that would be a saving of $201,541,000.

—I thank Senator Margetts for that. I think it is a novel way to reduce the budget deficit. Heaven knows, the people on the other side probably need all the help they can get. Those of us on this side of the chamber are not normally of a mood to reduce the appropriation in this fashion. I merely make the point that I think many of us on this side of the chamber would disagree with Senator Margetts's philosophical viewpoint although we respect that she has a right to bring it before the chamber and.

PARA.TAB: I do find it rather hard, though, to sit here and accept the fact that the Democrats are now toying with the idea of supporting this reduction in the appropriation, given that after the last election, when the coalition sought to vote against tax measures which were contained in the budget which were not brought before the people of Australia, the Democrats accused the coalition of trying to block supply.

Here we have a situation where, out of the blue, Senator Woodley is thinking of supporting these reductions in the appropriation. There is no reference to appropriate mechanisms for dealing with these things. Just out of the blue, Senator Woodley is of a mind to support these things. I find that rather inconsistent with the frenzied cries we heard from the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Kernot, when the coalition quite properly sought to vote against tax measures which were not brought before the Australian public at the last election. Senator Kernot said, `You couldn't do that. That is blocking supply.'

I think Senator Woodley really needs to give some serious consideration to how the Democrats propose to deal with the budgetary process and how they propose to deal with additional appropriations if it is wrong to vote against an increase in taxes but it is fine, out of the blue, for Senator Woodley to come in here on a whim and say that he is seriously considering supporting the reduction in appropriation.

Maybe Senator Woodley is saying that because he wants to sound like he is interested but he is going to pull back at the last minute. That is a legitimate parliamentary tactic. We recognise that. We have seen it from the Democrats on many occasions before, but it is highly extraordinary. It does not seem consistent with the comments Senator Kernot has made in the past. Maybe it is a case of while the cat is away the mice will play. I do not know. I leave it to Senator Woodley to explain to the chamber what he and the Democrats are going to do, whether he speaks for the Democrats and how this fits into the Democrats' approach to the budgetary procedures. We want to know because there is another budget coming up and we want to know how the Democrats are going to deal with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is really quite simple, Senator O'Chee. The Democrats have indicated for many years in alternative budgets that we would favour increased taxes in some areas and we would favour reductions in appropriations and expenditure items in other areas. We have always presented a balanced alternative budget to the parliament.

PARA.TAB: One of the items which has always been in that alternative budget presented by the Democrats is targeted cuts in defence budget. This has been a Democrat policy for many years. I have given a Democrat policy document to the National Party because it has questioned our policies on many occasions. I suggest Senator O'Chee reads that because it gives a clear indication that defence cuts are always part of the consideration which we give—

TALK.START.PARA: —They include $21 billion of spending increases, don't they, Senator Woodley?
—I am talking about the defence budget, which is what is before us. If you throw out figures like that—
—You wouldn't put the defence of Australia at risk, though, would you?

—No. That is why we target these very carefully. I indicate that the Auditor-General, in his report two years ago, indicated that there were $90 million worth of identifiable savings within the defence budget. We therefore, on the last occasion we presented an alternative budget, which was last year, indicated that there should be a cut in that area so that we could agree with the Auditor-General and so that those cuts could be very clearly targeted. That is the explanation which I think the chamber needs to hear.

—I thank Senator Woodley for that. We now have it on record that the Democrats' attitude to the budgetary process is that they will vote for or against something provided that it is consistent with their alternative budget; that, in fact, there is no constitutional procedural basis for their refusal to support, for example, the coalition opposing unannounced tax increases. It is merely a matter of whatever suits their policies at the time. They are not guided in their actions by some overriding constitutional procedural purpose. We accept that. It is on the record. I say to Senator Woodley that, when Senator Kernot comes back, he is going to be in big trouble.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend a little time dealing with the points that have been raised. The government opposes the amendments moved by Senator Margetts. It is not an unusual procedure to have portfolio additional estimates statements. In this case we are concerned with the Defence portfolio but it is not an unusual procedure in respect of any port folio.
—Two hundred million is.

—I will get to the reasons in a moment. It is not an unusual issue in principle. There is no new groundbreaking exercise being carried out here by the government. This is done right across all portfolios that I am aware of. Senator Margetts, I do not know whether you sit at estimates committees. I have had the misfortune at times to sit at them. The proceedings concerned with additional estimates can be pretty lengthy. I can assure Senator Margetts that this is not an unusual procedure in any government department.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the details of the $200 million that Senator Margetts is attempting to wipe from the Defence budget—and that is effectively what she is trying to do—I have to say that she is pretty adventurous. I admire her capacity to totally disrupt the defence forces, which is what would occur as a consequence of her proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, we need that money for an honour guard for Paul Keating, don't we?
—No, it is not for that purpose.
—Isn't it? What was it for?

—I will go through it. First of all, let us take the $186 million in equipment and stores. Within that there is a service allowance provision of some $41 million for the servicemen and servicewomen in the armed forces. That is an entitlement. I do not know the precise reasons why, whether it is an increase or a new allowance or whatever, but we have to provide for the pay and conditions of the service personnel.

PARA.TAB: There is a reimbursement of some $38 million for the cost of fuel excise. There has been reprogramming of some approved equipment projects. There has been a variety of price increases and exchange fluctuations that we did not know about last year. Again, that is not an unusual matter. For a variety of reasons, the commencement or the completion dates of some of the construction projects have been put back. Therefore, it has been necessary to have the supplementary estimates before you today.

The Defence budget is determined and controlled largely on a global outlay basis, within which defence spending programs are to be accommodated. Within these global limits, there has traditionally been a degree of flexibility—it is not an unusual flexibility that we are talking about—to relocate expenditures to accord with changing priorities and circumstances. It is no new principle in terms of the budget estimates provisions. What has traditionally occurred when the preparation of budgets in all portfolios has taken place is an anticipation that there will be, depending on circumstances, additional appropriations. We do not, in effect, overestimate the moneys that will be needed in a particular budget departmental area.

Senator Woodley was criticising us for not being able to obtain the details—some of which I have just read out. I think it was quite pertinent that the chair of the committee pointed out to Senator Woodley that this resolution by Senator Margetts was put down on 1 February. I am informed that if at some time after that date and before today you had made a request for the details—some of which I have gone through today—you would have received that briefing.

I do not know whether you made a request after 1 February, but I am informed that if you had you would have been given a briefing of the sort that you wanted. It is a bit difficult to meet that request today. I think we have to appreciate the time factor involved. It would have been more appropriate to have done it in that way particularly given the time pressures we are under.

I think what is driving the concern of Senator Margetts and Senator Woodley is a philosophical problem with defence expenditure rather than any great new principle of budget appropriations. This is not an unusual approach. Whilst I appreciate the support of the Democrats in the budget process, the issue between Senator O'Chee and Senator Woodley is not relevant to the matter before the chair. Senator O'Chee's interpretation of what Senator Woodley said is only Senator O'Chee's interpretation and nothing more.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are a couple of explanations that are needed. The Australian Democrats tried to obtain a copy of the amendments last week, but we were told that they had not been circulated and were not available. I believe there has been a mechanical foul-up. I apologise to Senator Margetts that we were under the impression that the amendments were not available. We were told by the side office that that was so. I do not want to criticise anyone, but I simply say that there has been a mechanical breakdown.

PARA.TAB: I want to underline the issue of accountability. We believe that the Department of Defence is unique in that it does not have, in any shape or form, the kind of outside scrutiny by the Department of Finance which other departments are subject to. For that reason, I share Senator Margetts's concerns about this issue, particularly in relation to the process undertaken.

A philosophical argument is involved here and it will continue to be put. Alongside that argument is the real concern that there are few controls on defence spending and those controls are simply not rigorous enough. I do not understand why the coalition is prepared to allow $10 billion to be simply frittered away without any real control or accountability. It seems to me that it is being `Yes, Ministered'. I cannot understand why the opposition is not making the kind of protest we are making in supporting the amendments that Senator Margetts has moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found some of the remarks made by the parliamentary secretary patronising to say the least. Senator Woodley and others would know how many hours I have spent in Defence estimate hearings. In some non-sitting weeks it has meant me travelling from Perth and spending a day with Senator Ray and then travelling back the next day. I can tell senators that I know of better ways to spend my time. That perhaps gives you an indication of how seriously we take this current level of expenditure and accountability in this portfolio. We are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary secretary mentioned that the Department of Defence does not overestimate the amount in department areas. That is correct. What it consistently does in many areas of major expenditure is underestimate the costs. That is why we have Black Hawks that cannot fly. That is why we have other equipment that cannot be serviced and other major operations that cannot operate in an efficient way and are therefore wasting taxpayers' money. That is not a philosophical problem; that is a wastage and inefficiency problem. It is an ongoing problem. The department tries to give one impression to the taxpayers and then actually does something else.

It is true: Defence does not regularly overestimate its budget, but, funnily enough, most other departments do. In recent years a number of departments have underspent their budget. They have suddenly found at the end of the year that 10 per cent of their budget has not been spent. What a surprise! That means that they can go into the next year looking as if they are either keeping the same level of expenditure or increasing it, when, in fact, they are putting it down. So it is cuts by deception. But that does not happen in Defence; it is increases by deception, and that is the general trend.

That is what we oppose. We oppose this level of accountability which tries to do a mirror trick and convince the public. People are well aware. The EPAC survey should make the government well aware that people are very concerned about this. If there is an area which people think the government ought to do some belt tightening in and be more efficient in, it is probably defence—in particular, Defence expenditure on such things as war toys.

The reality is that there needs to be some changes. People in this parliament, who are elected representatives, need to get at least the same level and quality of information as those in the defence industry and the private industry. Those are the same principles. That is not cutsie, philosophical stuff. It is reality. It is about money. It is about hundreds of millions of dollars that may be wasted because we do not have the level of scrutiny that should be available and that is available in a number of other countries.

As I say, I do not appreciate the patronising. If Senator Sherry thinks I am not serious and if he thinks we do not go into some detail of finding out what goes on in Defence, he can check the amount of questions we asked in both estimates and question time and he will see the level of reply that we got. As I keep saying, it is not a cutsie philosophical argument. It is about dollars and cents. It is about hundreds of millions of dollars. If Senator Sherry thinks that is not important and is just a silly little green philosophical argument, perhaps he does not think it is worth having proper scrutiny on that amount of money. The public and the taxpayers have a right to know properly how those decisions are made and why they are being made in this way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts would have us believe that this procedure is unusual. Let me read out the appropriations for some of the other departments: Attorney-General's Department, $34 1/2 million; Department of Veterans' Affairs, $100 million; Department of Human Services and Health, $65 million; Department of Industry, Science and Technology, $43 million; Department of Social Security, $37 million; and it goes on and on. Defence is at the top of the list, and I admit that. Why is it at the top? I told Senator Margetts earlier that one of the reasons is the special $41 million increase in the service allowance that we did not know about when the budget was put together. The tribunal handed this down and we were legally obliged to pay that $41 million.

PARA.TAB: The other reason, which I have already gone through, is that the defence department is a department that has major capital expenditure. Because of movements in purchasing times and because of fluctuation in exchange rates—which has a very significant effect on those expenditures—the defence department heads the list. Senator Margetts, I am not being patronising to you. I will say that you are wrong and you have a philosophical difference with Defence expenditure. That is the basis of your queries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been reminded of the fact that, unlike other departments, when Defence does bring forward these particular appropriations it does not decrease its next budget. That is the difference. According to the invective that the parliamentary secretary has just come out with, I think he has forgotten that. There is a difference here. When we do have additional appropriations because some things are `brought forward' or `put back', we ask questions in estimates hearings as to whether or not that means that next year's budget will be adjusted accordingly, but the answer is no. That is where the difference is.

PARA.TAB: When you have construction projects put back—that is, when the timing is changed, when these additional estimates come out and extra money is moved in this way—there is a difference. It means you do not have that taken out of the next budget. It is still in the budget and they spend it on something else. That is reality. That is the level of accountability. That is why we are saying this.

As I keep saying, those kinds of questions would not occur in other portfolios and people would not be accused of being philosophically different. It is bad accountability. If it is a philosophical difference in terms of what the government thinks is appropriate accountability, then I am very proud to say we are philosophically different from the government.
Requests for amendments negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: ADVANCE TO THE PRESIDENT FOR 1993-94
ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE 1993-94

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:

That the committee approves the statement on the Advances to the President of the Senate for 1993-94 and the Minister for Finance, for the year 1993-94, of the Heads of Expenditure and the amounts charged thereto, pursuant to section 36A of the Audit Act 1901.
Advances agreed to.
Bills agreed to.
Advances and bills reported; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator Sherry) proposed:
That these bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my remarks by referring to what I said on behalf of the coalition at the time of the second reading debate on these appropriation bills. This is the third reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1994-95, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1994-95 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1994-95, which are commonly known as the additional estimates.

PARA.TAB: In the second reading debate I pointed out the fact that this was the first year in which we were following a set of parliamentary procedures for consideration of the budget bills consequent upon the budget being introduced in May rather than, as has always been the case in the past, in August. Because of that change in the timetable for the introduction and processing of the budget, there were a considerable number of changes made in terms of the way in which the parliament, and particularly the Senate, goes about its consideration of the appropriations. In particular, the significance of the additional estimates debates has been increased because it was only at the time of the presentation of the additional estimates towards the end of last calendar year that the full information on the government's spending proposals for the financial year 1994-95 became available. So we have had a greatly heightened increase in the significance of this additional estimates process and the ensuing debates, both in estimates committees and here in the parliament.

On 1 February this year, when speaking in the second reading debate, I pointed to the fact that many of the answers to questions that had been put to the government in the additional estimates hearings in November and early December were very late in being received prior to the supplementary additional estimates hearings that took place in February. I spoke in the second reading debate just a couple of weeks before those supplementary additional estimates hearings. I said at that time that we were very concerned that the supplementary estimates hearings were going to be frustrated by virtue of the fact that we did not have many of the necessary answers to the questions that had been put in the first set of hearings in November and December. My concerns, on behalf of the coalition, were heightened as events proceeded during February and March, and it was only last week that the supplementary hearings were finally concluded.

I would point out that we are finalising the passage of these bills today without having answers to many of the questions, which the government had to take on notice, that were put during the supplementary estimates hearings in February. To that extent, I would point out to the government that the coalition is being highly cooperative in facilitating the passage of these appropriation bills because, if one were strictly looking at the due processes that ought to be carried out before appropriation bills are passed—and that due process would involve receiving answers to all the questions that had been put during the consideration of the bills—then the government would not be in a position to ask for passage of these bills. Nevertheless, we are, in a spirit of cooperation, going ahead with facilitating the government's requirement.

Overall, looking at the whole process—going back to the early introduction of the budget in May last year and looking at the succeeding processing of the budget bills—the opposition is satisfied that the new arrangements have worked reasonably well to date. There certainly have been some hiccups along the way, not least, I must say, in the understanding by ministers—at least some of them—of the scope of questioning that was permitted in the course of the consideration. This was especially the case with the supplementary additional estimates hearings of the committee with which I am most involved—the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which deals with the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

The minister who had responsibility for the conduct of the supplementary hearings of that committee was the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus. He also, of course, represents the Attorney-General in this place. He tried to gag the committee's proceedings when it met on 16 February. We lost well over an hour of very valuable committee time arguing with the minister about his lack of understanding of the whole nature of those supplementary hearing processes.

The implication of what he was saying—he was totally misinformed but I give him the benefit of the doubt; I think his prevarication in the estimates committee was based on a genuine misunderstanding on his part—was that what could be done in the supplementary estimates hearings, which were very consciously and very deliberately designed to be a very important part of the Senate's consideration of the budget, was totally contradictory to the standing orders of the Senate that had been determined back in August 1994. In the end he acquiesced in that matter, and so the proceedings continued, but had he had his way, then much of the necessary debate and consideration of the government's spending proposals, at least in those departments, would have been totally frustrated. That was the first real occasion on which the Senate had had the opportunity to look at many of the proposals in the detail that was required.

So that was a very worrying hiccup that occurred. I hope that those bugs in the system are due just to the newness of the system and I am confident that we will resolve those next time around. With the budget coming up in May we will have had one full year of the new procedure and I hope that the proceedings of the parliament in terms of the consideration of the 1995 budget will build on the improvements that we started in 1994 but which will need further building on.
Last Saturday, we saw a remarkable by-election result in the seat of Canberra. I have no doubt at all that Paul Keating's Canberra—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Proper titles, if you do not mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —That part-time Prime Minister Paul Keating's Canberra of March 1995 will prove to be what was Gough Whitlam's Bass of 1974. The Bass by-election in 1974 or early 1975 set the inevitable scene for the demise of the Whitlam government—arguably the most incompetent government until this one in Australia's history. In last Saturday's result in Canberra there was a fall of 22 per cent in the Labor vote. That means that Labor's share of the vote fell by 22 per cent but, in fact, it fell almost in half when you look at the actual arithmetic. I do not think there is any doubt at all that the significance of that vote and the result, including, in particular, on the two-party preferred basis, will prove to be as significant as was the Bass result 20 years earlier which led to an essentially necessary change of government in 1975.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy for Australia from last Saturday's result is that the Prime Minister seems to have no idea of the reason for that result. There are many reasons for it. Right at the top must be two factors. First is the economic incompetence and policy failures of this government in its 12 years of office which have led to mainstream Australia being brutally savaged in economic terms through its standard of living and quality of life. Throughout all that time, the single architect of that misery has been the current Prime Minister, Mr Keating, because he was the Treasurer throughout virtually all the preceding time of the present government under the prime ministership of Bob Hawke.
Senator McGauran interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator McGauran says, there is great concern in the ranks opposite about the situation. There is great concern about the Prime Minister's total refusal to accept blame for last Saturday's result. Instead, if we believe the press reports today—I am certain that they are correct and on good authority—he blamed everyone but himself. He blamed Mr Speaker. Mr Speaker did not exercise enough discipline in the House of Representatives to make the Prime Minister look good so that the Prime Minister really did not have to thump the table and scream and shout in the most unparliamentary ways possible.

PARA.TAB: That Mr Speaker is having such difficulty in the House of Representatives is very importantly because of the sheer arrogance and brutality of this Prime Minister in his whole approach to the parliamentary process and his whole job. The Prime Minister blamed Mr Speaker. He accused the person who probably did more than anyone else to get him into the prime ministership of taking 30 pieces of silver to attack him. He has drawn attention to and blamed everyone other than himself. If he does not realise that it is as a result of his economic policies and the sheer arrogance and out-of-touchness that he displays in everything he does, and if he does not make a monumental change in his whole attitude and policy approach, there is no doubt that the massacre of Labor in December 1975 will look like chicken feed compared with what will rightly happen to Labor at the next election.

It is the complacency of the government, and the Prime Minister in particular, as to the economic situation in this country that is really of the very greatest concern. Yesterday in question time—this is but one of many examples that I could draw the Senate's attention to—in response to a question from my leader, Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, claimed this:

SPEECH.PARA: The economy is in a much sounder fundamental shape now than it was then—
in the mid- to late 1980s—
as a result of the decade long attention that we have paid to basic fundamental economic reform.

That statement is of the most outrageously inaccurate and misleading nature. The government never backs up these statements with hard facts. Look at the hard facts of the situation today—the fundamentals of the Australian economy—compared with the situation a decade ago in the mid-1980s, let alone the structure of the economy that this Labor government inherited from the Fraser government in March 1983. A comparison shows that it is simply not true—indeed, it is totally the opposite—to say that the economy is now in a much sounder fundamental shape than it was then.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at a few of the key statistics. The government has been making much of the fact that, according to it, more than 500,000 new jobs have been created in the last two years and that this beats its estimate of how long it would take to create that number of new jobs by one year. That sounds pretty impressive stuff, doesn't it? But, when you dig below the surface, you find a very different situation. The fact is that the level of employment in Australia today is only 248,000 more than it was at the time of peak employment in 1990. That was before the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister, Paul Keating, pulled the levers very deliberately, very brutally and totally unnecessarily that led to the worst recession in 60 years and the greatest level of unemployment since the Great Depression.

It would be almost inconceivable that a government would not have been able to see the growth of 500,000 new jobs in a two-year period at a time of recovery from such a low base as it had subjected the economy to. What we have seen is normal growth out from the bottom of a very low, depressed cycle. It was a depression caused by the total economic policy failure and mismanagement of the government.

The level of employment is not all that much more than what it was at its high level five years ago. The level of employment today is only 248,000 more than it was five years ago, which is an average of less than 50,000 jobs a year. When you look at the number of people coming onto the job market, you see that there is nowhere near the level of job creation necessary to provide sustained employment for the present work force and the newly emerging work force.

The situation is even worse when you look at the structure of employment. More than half of the 500,000 new jobs created in the last two years have been part-time jobs. The growth in employment has come from part-time employment—not full-time employment. There are not too many families in our nation who can operate a budget and keep their heads above the poverty line under the policies of this government in a full-time job, let alone in a part-time job. Let us hear no more of this absolute nonsense from the government about its so-called great success in job creation. It is greatly overstating the real situation and it is greatly understating the gravity of the employment situation.

That is reinforced when you look at the unemployment figures. More than 800,000 Australians are still unemployed. On top of that figure, there are at least another 800,000 to one million people who are underemployed. Those figures include those people who do not work for even one hour a week. If you have a part-time casual job where someone pays you for two hours of employment a week, you are not classified as unemployed. The official statistics grossly understate the seriousness of the employment situation in Australia. The job situation is extremely worrying, and it continues to be so. Nothing the government is doing is having any sustainable impact on improving that situation.

Yesterday, what Senator Evans said in response to that question from Senator Hill was wrong. I was going to say that he misled the parliament. I am not sure that I am allowed to say that he lied to the parliament.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Certainly not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then he very seriously misled the parliament, Mr Acting Deputy President. He said that interest rates in Australia at the moment are at historically low levels in comparison with the experience of past decades. That is simply untrue. It is a monstrous untruth. The fact is that, if we look at this whole spectrum of interest rates, real interest rates in Australia—and by `real interest rates' we mean the level of interest rates that we see quoted less the level of inflation, and that is the important figure—are the highest in the Western world. They are higher than they have been at virtually any other point in our history. There have been some times at which they were higher, but very few. It is simply not correct to say that interest rates in Australia are at historically low levels.

PARA.TAB: Also, there is the misleading implication that, in terms of the interest rate side of things, we are doing okay in comparison with other countries against whom our investors have to compete in getting a return on their capital investment in the production of goods and services, and so on. The fact is that this government has put our investors, producers and wealth creators in an increasingly tight bind, an increasingly difficult situation, to achieve what we all wish them to achieve on our behalf, because our interest rate cost structure is higher than that of virtually any of the other countries against whom we are competing in this highly competitive international world. So much for interest rates and the very false claims of the government pertaining to them.

The next issue to which I draw attention is the situation in relation to the balance of payments. The balance of payments—that is, our accounts with the rest of the world—is in as bad a shape as it has ever been. We are racking up deficits, debts to the rest of the world; we are going into hock to the rest of the world by more than $2 billion every month of the year. The government started off this year by saying that our deficit with the rest of the world was going to be $18 billion. It said that at the time of the budget last May when it was talking about the 1994-95 financial year. Then, subsequently, a couple of months ago, it revised that estimate to $26 billion—and at the rate we are going that will be an underestimate too. There is every possibility that the figure for the year will come in at $28 billion to $29 billion. That, as a proportion of our total national income, our gross domestic product, what we produce, is about six per cent.

There is no country in the Western world that has a balance of payments deficit as a proportion of its national output of anything like six per cent. The Americans are terribly worried about their balance of payments situation, and their deficit is, I think, 2.3 per cent of GDP. The only country in the world that exceeds us in the so-called Western world, or among the OECD countries, is Mexico. I think its figure is about 6 1/2 per cent—and we are rapidly approaching that figure. From the last few months we all know of the dreadful difficulties that Mexico has got itself into—how the peso has plunged, how the economy is in absolute chaos. That has all happened because of its external situation.

Paul Keating, the then Treasurer, said in May 1986 that we were heading into banana republic land; we were going down the Argentinian road. I would just say that, if we were half as good as Argentina is today, we would be doing pretty well. The external accounts of this nation today are as bad as they were when Mr Keating made those very sombre—and correct—statements of almost a decade ago.

The Leader of the Government in the Senate yesterday had the hide to come into this chamber and tell us that the economic fundamentals today are better than they were a decade ago. What absolute nonsense that is. I wonder what page of the foreign debt figures he was looking at. Doesn't he know that Australia today has a foreign debt to the rest of the world—we owe the rest of the world—more than $170,000 million. I repeat: $170,000 million.

When this lot came to power in March 1983, our debt to the rest of the world was $23,000 million. That was an okay figure. It was not the top of the tree, but it was a highly manageable figure. Our debt to the rest of the world today under Labor is eight times higher than it was when Labor came to office. No country in the world, I think I can say with confidence, has a larger foreign debt than we have. The one thing you can say with absolute certainty about foreign debt is that nothing reduces a nation's independence and sovereignty more than being in debt to other countries, to foreigners.

We have an arrogant, part-time, out of date, past his use-by date Prime Minister who struts the world stage and tells the chancellor of the strongest economy in the world how to run his country, how to plan his architecture. He shoves aside the Prime Minister of one of the Asian tigers who is really showing us how to go about doing business, the Prime Minister of Singapore, so that he can attack John Howard and Kerry Packer. A fellow like that is running the country and trying to tell us that he is supporting and working for a more independent Australia, yet he has been the chief architect of policies that have put at risk Australia's independence and sovereignty more than any other public figure in the history of this nation.

All of that comes together in the value of the Australian dollar—how it is valued in terms of other currencies. That is of critical importance to us because the value of the Australian dollar determines how much we can sell our goods overseas for and how much we have to pay for the goods that we buy from overseas. My colleague Senator Gibson in his comments will go into this in much more detail.

The policy failures I have been talking about have led to a major decline in the value of the Australian dollar. That has certain inevitable results. Putting downward pressure on the Australian dollar for all of those reasons greatly increases pressure to increase interest rates. If you have a falling dollar you have almost inevitably a rising interest rate. It puts upward pressure on inflation, so inflation is likely to rise inevitably as a result of it. It puts downward pressure on investment because the cost of investment becomes increasingly difficult. It causes a reduction in economic growth and an inevitable increase in unemployment.

None of those things are matters that this government and this Prime Minister want to talk about, but they are the things that affect mainstream Australia, that determine our livelihoods and the job prospects of our kids—their ability to pay their mortgage rates, to have a job, to make their way in life. The government has completely failed those people, has completely failed mainstream Australia and, indeed, all Australians. It stands condemned for that. That will be shown, I have no doubt, at the next poll. (Time expired)
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Order! It being almost 12.45 p.m., with the concurrence of the Senate I propose that we proceed to debate matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of over 1,000 severely drought affected farmers from the Upper Hunter district of New South Wales. These farmers and small business people have labelled the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, the most hated man in the district. They are at a total loss to understand why this Labor government has abandoned them to live without hope and in desperate rural poverty. The region includes Muswellbrook, Scone, Murrurundi and Merriwa and it remains in absolute and comprehensive drought. Farmers have now faced four consecutive years of this drought. Their plight is magnified because this ALP government has refused and continues to refuse to lift a finger to help with public policy. Minister Collins will not move to grant exceptional circumstance drought relief to aid these farmers.

PARA.TAB: On 1 February I led a delegation to meet him. He heard the desperate stories first-hand and he at that time appeared to react with compassion. He promised a response from RASAC, the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee, by early March. We are now in late March and nothing has happened. All my inquiries to members of the delegation this morning say that Collins is a do-nothing minister. Delegation members say that his promised access to household support—he promised this in his office—is still not available. Treasury has said that no more money is available for drought relief and Collins has strung along these Upper Hunter farmers in a disgraceful way.

The anger and bitterness in the Upper Hunter against Minister Collins are now entrenched as farm families have no option but to beg for assistance. This federal Labor government has turned its back on this region. It is the Hunter electorate and voters will not let Eric Fitzgibbon, the Labor MP, forget. His 14 per cent margin in Hunter was previously looking very safe but, after the Canberra by-election and the amount of heat generated up there about this matter now, there could be a very big swing to the coalition in Hunter at the next election.

No-one should doubt the extreme severity of the drought in the Upper Hunter. In January, when other areas got about six inches of rain, the Upper Hunter got under one inch. It has moved in this time from what has been called the green drought—that is, when you get some green pick that is not of much use to cattle at all because it is so short—to a dust bowl again, with most of the farm dams completely dry. The region now, on the natural pattern, faces a dry winter; and still no exceptional drought relief comes from this ALP government.

This means in stark terms that these people will be borrowing money just to put food on the table. They will have to accept welfare from Farmhand, if there is any money left in the fund, from the Samaritans and from other charities. They will be borrowing money to keep stock alive, to buy grain and fertiliser for cereal crop planting, and to agist breeding stock cattle. Farmers in this region already have massive debt levels, many above $200,000 since the start of the drought.

The minister cannot say that this is a no-hope area for viable farming. Prior to the drought most of the farms were 100 per cent viable and making money. This is some of the best agricultural and grazing land in Australia—but not during a drought; and we have no relief from the government. These people now need a drought interest subsidy, and the minister is denying this very vital lifeline that they need to stay viable and come back after the drought ends.

Let me cite an example from a member of the recent delegation to the minister. He is a beef cattle producer from near Scone and he was 100 per cent viable with nil debt before the drought. This drought and lack of federal aid have crippled him and his family financially. They are now $150,000 in debt. His herd has gone down from 600 to 400, with another 150 to be sold next week. The foundation of his future, his breeding heifers, has been decimated. He is now forced to sell his breeding heifers on a crashing cattle market in Scone, with prices falling to 15c a kilo this week. He is selling these cattle at a loss, having borrowed money to keep them alive and in some reasonable condition during this drought.

This scenario is repeated with a thousand families across the Upper Hunter. The Samaritans in the Hunter are trying valiantly to fill the mammoth gap left by the minister's callous disregard for their critical situation. Cec Shevells, from the Samaritans, says that the drought position in the Upper Hunter is worse than six months ago. The Samaritans are now providing 95 per cent of their relief effort to Upper Hunter farm families. Mr Shevells is astonished that this area is not included in the exceptional circumstances criteria. They are providing cash grants, deliveries of hay and water. They are also providing voluntary labour to farmers who are hospitalised.

This level of support cannot continue. This picture of real plight is desperate, and Collins must fix this up now. The money must be found from the finances of the federal government when these people are declared, as they should be, to be in an exceptional drought area. I demand in the Senate today that Minister Collins give a response to his undertaking made to farmers from the Upper Hunter on 1 February 1995. I will not rest in this Senate until this hideous wrong is corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to speak about the fact that last week was Seniors Week in many states and also Arthritis Week. I suppose there was an apt and timely connection between those two events, as many seniors do, after all, suffer from crippling and severe arthritis and other musculoskeletal diseases and disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, osteoporosis and ankylosing spondylitis.
