One of the greatest misconceptions, however, is that arthritis is restricted to the elderly population. It most certainly is not. Not by any stretch of the imagination can one close one's ears and eyes to the fact that a whole range of people of middle or young ages are severely disabled by this disease, which is by far Australia's most common.

PARA.TAB: Following Arthritis Week and given that this disease is one of the most under-funded of all, I would like to take a few moments to highlight this important matter in the Senate, especially given that the government does not seem to take too much interest in it in terms of research, facilities or practical care options such as the home and community care program. I have raised a number of these issues consistently over quite some time in estimates committees. I am concerned that no change is taking place and we are not seeing any increased funding for this very serious disease. The aim of Arthritis Week was to focus on Australia's most common chronic disease and to let Australia's two million sufferers know that they are not alone with their pain and restricted mobility.

Although arthritis is more common in older people, more than 100,000 people aged between 15 and 65 years are classified as being severely or profoundly handicapped by arthritis. The cost burden of this is not one which society can escape. At a cost to the Australian community of around $4 1/2 billion per year, it is clear that arthritis and similar diseases place a significant strain on health resources, particular when the disease goes unmanaged and when sufferers do not receive the information they need to manage their disease as best they can.

Once again, I come back to the role of Arthritis Week. It was especially important in this respect: people like Mr Bill Willcox, the National Director of the Arthritis Foundation of Australia, have an ongoing commitment—I commend them—to promoting better health for the sufferers of arthritis in Australia. Without such help, who knows what the statistics might be. The Arthritis Foundation is doing superb work in helping people to deal with the effects of arthritis.

Already there is cause for concern. Today I would like to quote a few of the statistics. Four million Australians suffer from some form of musculoskeletal disease, two million suffer from arthritis or rheumatism, 1.2 million suffer from disability as a result of their disease and more than 750,000 are handicapped as a result of arthritis. Musculoskeletal disease is the second most common cause of people visiting a doctor and accounts for nine per cent of all visits.

The Arthritis Foundation estimates that the government spends about 14 cents per sufferer on research into arthritis and similar diseases. The foundation would like to see this increase appreciably and believes that donations for medical research should be given the same tax treatment as investment in commercial research. Surely these are things that need to be very seriously considered by the government, considering the number of people who are so severely affected by this disease.

If I can make an interesting comparison in research funding, according to the most recent data available, which is dated September 1994, the cumulative total of HIV sufferers was 18,530 and, allowing for AIDS deaths in that period, the number was 14,704. A sum of $13.186 million was spent on HIV/AIDS research alone in 1994-95. That equates to $896 per sufferer, just in the past year. Of course, that does not take into account the other funds which are spent on state hospital care, blood transfusions and education programs. That is on research alone—simply on research. That is probably more funds than an arthritis sufferer would see in a lifetime. I think we really do need to look at the way in which arthritis is being funded, or underfunded, because these people are being severely affected in their day-to-day lives.

An ABS study of women's health has shown that the second most common cause of long-term ill health is arthritis. Among the seven most common complaints is unspecific back trouble and other diseases of the musculoskeletal system and connected tissue. The study also found that a total of 38.2 per cent of women with long-term ill health have a musculoskeletal condition. By the age of 15, back trouble is the most common cause of ill health in women and by 35, arthritis is the fourth most common cause. By the age of 45, arthritis is the second most common cause and remains so for all subsequent age groups.

For every 1,000 Australian females, 152.3 days were spent by female patients in hospital for obstetric matters. Hospitalisation for diseases of the musculoskeletal system and connective tissue totalled 95.7 days. This is a very serious problem. A study showing that hospitalisation for musculoskeletal diseases is second only to hospitalisation for obstetric matters for women really does start to highlight the problem.

In women aged between 45 and 54 years, this is the most common reason for consulting a doctor. Any of us who have known anyone, or know anyone now, who suffers from this disease, knows the pain and the suffering they are going through and knows that they really do quite genuinely need the help and the research to continue into this dreadful disease.

Clearly, we are not simply talking about a disease which is restricted, as I said before, to the elderly. It is one that is limiting the lifestyle of younger people, some of them very young. There are some children of only four, five or six who can hardly walk, who can hardly move. There are so many reasons why research needs to be extended. In the light of these alarming statistics, Mr Wilcox claims:

SPEECH.PARA: It is astonishing that a medical condition as prevalent as arthritis and with such a profound impact on society should remain as poorly served as it is by the health care delivery system and that perhaps it is that a completely inaccurate stereotype of discomfort and inconvenience exists. Perhaps it is that it is incorrectly seen as not causing death. Perhaps it is that it has simply not been defined as either wholly within the health care system or not completely within the disability service system.

A whole range of questions are being raised as to the way in which this disease is actually perceived and viewed in the community. Nowhere is this more evident than in the limited access arthritic people have to home and community care programs. At the last round of estimates, I was asked to provide examples of this limitation. I will repeat some of those examples here. These is a small, anecdotal collection of cases which have been gathered by the foundation's national director from a number of states. These are but a few of the cases.

PARA.TAB: Case 1 is of Mrs G, who is 45 years old and has rheumatoid arthritis. She needs care and assistance for normal daily activities, including help with the toilet and the shower. Her husband cannot afford full-time care for her. She can only get domiciliary care two days a week and her other alternative is to be placed in a nursing home and thus separated from her husband.

Case 2 is of Mrs M, who is 30 years old with a seven-year-old daughter and five-year-old twins. She has severe rheumatoid arthritis. When she moved to a new house, her home help hours were reduced and the reason given was that the new house had no floor coverings. Mrs M is wheelchair bound. She has had hip, knee and shoulder replacements and is awaiting elbow surgery. Her home help hours have not been increased.

Case 3 is of Mrs B, who has been assessed as needing home help but is still waiting for assistance 18 months down the track. Case 4 is of Mrs A, who has had three hip replacements and cannot bend down but has been refused home help on the grounds that she does not fit the criteria.

Case 5 is of Miss T, who is 48 and has suffered from rheumatoid arthritis for 33 years. Her mobility is severely restricted; she lives alone and has no relatives who are able to support her. Following spinal surgery, she required a night carer for six to eight weeks but limited funding reduced this period of care.

Case 6 is of Mrs J, who is badly crippled in the hands, knees and shoulders. She gets an hour and a half's assistance per week for house cleaning. She has a mentally retarded daughter who suffers from bouts of extreme epilepsy when she fits seven or eight times per day and vomits often. At this time she has asked for more help but has been told there are no more funds available.

I cite these as actual cases. I, for one, would not like to be in the desperate positions of all six cases to which I have referred. Of course, they are probably just the tip of the iceberg and many of us would know of other cases. Many people out there simply accept the decision not to grant home and community care services. They take it no further and they are the ones who suffer in silence. They are home and, sadly, many of them are home alone.

This is a subject on which I could speak for much more time than I have here today. I am glad that Senator Crowley is actually in the chamber today. She has also been present during the estimates committee hearings where I have raised the subject repeatedly. Sadly, it has become a bit of a joke in estimates that I keep on raising this subject; but I hasten to add that I will continue to raise this subject until we can see what is happen ing.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is still not listening.

—That is true. I am disappointed that Senator Crowley is not taking some note of this because these cases are real. I have said nothing yet of the number in the population who suffer from osteoporosis and the related fracturing of their honeycombed bones; I have said nothing of incorrectly managed sports injuries which fester away over the years before robbing people of their former lifestyles; I have said nothing of the children who suffer from extreme juvenile arthritis and who cannot walk, run or play like other children. There is so much to talk about that falls under the banner of arthritis.

PARA.TAB: In concluding my remarks today, all I can say is that I certainly wish the Arthritis Foundation every success in its endeavours. It is doing a fantastic job in helping arthritis sufferers and in the way in which it promotes a better lifestyle for sufferers. I hope that its pressure on the government for assistance, particularly in the area of research, means that it will be forthcoming. I would encourage it and I would encourage all members of the federal parliament to make sure that the government does understand the severity of this problem so that we can all start a fight for a greater slice of the health funds that would assure sufferers of some support for their extreme suffering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in the discussion of matters of public interest to speak about the tax implications of converting accrued leave entitlements to superannuation.

PARA.TAB: At the 1994 annual general meeting of the Queensland Professional Credit Union, a member asked the board to explain why the superannuation payments to directors had increased by 613 per cent for the 1993-94 income year. The managing director, Mr Gordon Rutherford, responded that it represented a payment to him for long service leave and annual leave which he had converted to superannuation. It seems that the leave entitlements that had accrued to Mr Rutherford had been converted and paid as employer's superannuation contributions to Mr Rutherford's superannuation fund. The member who raised the question thought that this was somewhat unusual and, subsequent to the annual general meeting, wrote to the chairman of the credit union's board to confirm that the transaction had been approved by the board and asked whether or not there were any tax implications. The chairman, Mr Lee, wrote back to the member advising that the board had indeed approved the conversion of Mr Rutherford's accrued leave entitlements to superannuation and that there were no tax implications.

Wondering whether the credit union had discovered a tax planning tool for executives, the member then wrote to the deputy commissioner of taxation seeking advice on whether such an arrangement had any tax implications. The tax office wrote back and advised:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not possible to make an effective salary sacrifice of an entitlement that has already accrued. Therefore if a person has an accrued [leave entitlement] a payment of any amount of that accrued entitlement to a superannuation fund will constitute salary and wages in the hands of the employee and would be an employee contribution to the fund rather than an employer contribution.

It appears that the only plausible explanation for such a conversion of accrued leave entitlements to superannuation is that the individual has somehow extinguished the personal tax liability, and the only tax paid is the 15 per cent by the superannuation fund. The tax saving to the individual is not trivial; if the individual is on the highest marginal tax rate, the saving is 33.4c in the dollar. I will leave it to honourable senators to work out the amount of tax saved on the payment of almost $80,000 in this case. The only problem is that such an arrangement is contrary to advice the credit union member had received from the tax office.

PARA.TAB: That member and two others were concerned that the credit union accounts for 1994 did not make sufficient disclosure about the nature of the payment to directors—that is, the conversion of accrued leave to superannuation—and that the credit union might somehow be in breach of tax law. These individuals then took this matter to the relevant regulatory body, the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision.

In relation to the matter of the conversion of accrued leave to superannuation, the QOFS wrote that it had investigated the matter. It stated that the `conversion' was approved by the board and that, in addition:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . independent professional advice was obtained from KPMG, Brisbane.
It added:
In relation to any tax implications this is a matter strictly between the Board and its auditors KPMG Peat Marwick.

Although the letter that the member had received from the tax office was also referred to the QOFS, the QOFS made no mention of the apparent conflict between the tax office view and the credit union's arrangement. I wonder why the QOFS seems unconcerned that the credit union had entered into an arrangement that may be in breach of tax law.

PARA.TAB: The credit union members also took the matter to the Australian Financial Institutions Commission, which similarly showed little concern about the apparent conflict between the tax office advice and the credit union's action. The commission suggested that as the credit union had acted on professional advice it had acted properly, and if that advice is subsequently found to be wrong then the credit union has the right to take action against its advisers. But that was not the point that these concerned members were trying to make.

There are a number of important issues that arise from the circumstances that I have outlined here. Of concern is the way in which the two regulatory bodies have treated the Queensland Professional Credit Union members' complaints. These two organisations, which have a watchdog role over the activities of credit unions and building societies, appear to be unconcerned that the QPCU may have entered into an arrangement that is in breach of tax law.

Although the attitude of these regulators does give cause for alarm, there is another aspect to this matter that is even more alarming. That is the significant policy implications for both superannuation and taxation, and perhaps even industrial relations. In fact, in terms of the industrial relations issue there are a number of questions which I would like to put on the record.

The first is: can an employee and employer change a contract of employment to swap one entitlement for another? I do know the answer to that: it is yes. That is why salary packaging is such big business. Can they repackage leave entitlements? That is more interesting, because leave entitlements are governed by state and federal legislation. In Queensland, for example, the minimum legislative requirements are three weeks annual leave per year and 13 weeks long service leave after 15 years service. These entitlements cannot be traded away or repackaged. Even the Victorian legislation of Jeff Kennett guarantees recreation leave and long service leave. As far as I am aware, these conditions apply for all employees, so the issue is that state industrial law and federal tax law may have been breached.

The other point worth making is that these sorts of deals will become more attractive because of the decision in the 1993 budget to tax accrued recreation leave and long service leave at marginal tax rates rather than at a concessional rate. The Democrats were generally opposed to the measure, but even in its amended form it is still intended to earn the government an extra $170 million plus from 1995-96 onwards. This money could be at risk. Let me emphasise that if employees are able to convert accrued leave entitlements to superannuation in order to obtain a major tax break then this could represent substantial tax revenue lost to the government. It would also introduce further inequities in the superannuation system. Those in the higher tax brackets stand to gain a lot more than low income earners. Also, it would be unlikely that low income earners would be given the option by their employers of making a payment to superannuation in lieu of taking annual leave or long service leave. Again, it is the high income earners who gain the major benefit.

Given the potentially widespread ramifications of such arrangements, I put the following question to the Treasurer. If an employee's accrued leave entitlements are converted to employer superannuation contributions, then is it possible for the converted amount to be assessed for taxation in the hands of the superannuation fund rather than as personal income in the hands of the employee? If the answer to this question is no, then I have a further question. As highlighted by the recent Goodman Fielder case, there are no legal requirements in Australia for public disclosure of detailed information about the salary packages of directors and senior executives. In the absence of full disclosure, and given that conversions of executives' accrued leave to superannuation are likely to be relatively difficult to detect, what mechanisms does the tax office have in place to detect such transactions when they occur?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the breadth and depth of concern about the continued logging of old-growth and other high conservation value forests in Western Australia, and the urgent need to provide for the permanent protection of these areas. I invite any of my parliamentary colleagues to view a video on the areas I am talking about from the south-west of Western Australia by tuning their Parliament House office monitors to channel 8 at 1.30 p.m. today. Anyone who is listening can contact my office to borrow the video or arrange a viewing. The video, called Western Australia's forests, has been produced by the WA Small Business and Enterprise Association. It shows some of the beautiful south-west forests scheduled for logging in 1995 and the devastation of areas that have been logged. Included are revealing aerial shots showing the extent of logging and clear-felling in the south-west. I am very glad I was able to speak before 1.30. If anybody has heard this part of my speech, I urge them to spare a few minutes to watch that video.

PARA.TAB: I also seek leave to table two pages of excerpts from two Western Australian newspapers, which illustrate the degree of concern about this issue.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The first is a copy of an advertisement, signed by 280 people, which appeared in the West Australian newspaper on Monday, 20 February 1995. The advertisement calls for a moratorium on logging and road construction in all forests with significant old-growth or wilderness values. Signatories, who also subsidised the cost of the advertisement, came from a range of community sectors, from 40 Perth suburbs and over 15 towns in the south-west and north-west of the state. The range of sectors represented includes media, business, tourism, the legal profession, the church, the arts, farming, sport, medicine, universities, science, local government and state parliament. Others, including people in the timber industry, made donations of support but did not want their names to appear.

PARA.TAB: The proclamation, under the heading `Save the old growth forests' stated:

Over the next three years tens of thousands of hectares of precious old-growth and wilderness forest will be logged and lost forever in the South-West of Western Australia. Most of the trees will be turned into low-value export woodchips.

SPEECH.PARA: These areas have never been studied for their exceptional contribution to Australian biodiversity. Old-growth forests cannot be replaced or regrown. They are unique, but we will never know what they contain after they have been clearfelled.

The National Forest Policy Statement, signed in 1992 by all State Premiers (except in Tasmania) and the Prime Minister of Australia, recognises `the significance of these areas to the Australian community because of their high aesthetic, cultural and nature conservation values and their freedom from disturbance.'

We, the undersigned, appeal to the State and Federal Governments to honour the agreement signed in the National Forest Policy Statement and implement an immediate moratorium on logging and road construction in all forests with significant old-growth or wilderness values pending a COMPLETE INDEPENDENT BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT of their conservation value.

I did not give my signature because I feel strongly that the national forest policy, even if it were being properly implemented, is not a sufficient protection for the values that we want to preserve in Australia. Since the publication of the advertisement, over 1,000 people have signed a statement of support. The South-West Forests Defence Foundation, which placed the advertisement, is currently still receiving about 20 responses a day.

PARA.TAB: The second page which I sought leave to table is the letters page from the Midwest Times of 18 January 1995. It just illustrates the diversity of people who are recognising the urgency of this issue. I will not go through it because I have tabled it, but I just mention that it is from a country newspaper and there are comments from a student of 17, Brad; Rona, a housewife 70 years of age; Tony, a business proprietor of 51; Marjorie, 77, retired of Cue; Rick, 36, a council worker; Barbara, 50, a Northampton housewife; Joan, 46, a shop assistant; Kim, 33, a mechanical operator; and Mel, 20, a compositor. I just feel that we need to be aware that the people in the community seem to have a greater sense of urgency about this matter than is demonstrated by the degree of political will on this issue in either state or federal parliaments.

Recent polls have made it very clear that, of all the states with woodchipping, the support for forest conservation is strongest in Western Australia. The AGB McNair poll conducted on 10 to 12 February found that 70 per cent of Western Australians oppose logging in unlogged forests, and 44 per cent were strongly opposed.

It is inevitable that the timber industry will have to go through changes when the available native forest runs out, which it is now. We need to begin now the transition out of native forests and onto existing plantations and tree crops on cleared farmland if we are to ensure conservation of the remaining forests and protection of jobs. Integral to this process must be a job security fund for timber workers, financed by the timber industry and the government.

I have written to Western Australian members of this parliament and I urge all my Senate colleagues to do all in their power to ensure that the federal government acts with vision and integrity, permanently protects the remaining 399 areas identified by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and puts in place the long-term measures necessary to protect all our precious forest heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, today I want to raise my concerns about responses I have had from the Australian Securities Commission to three complaints I have made in relation to the Keating piggery group of companies and actions by Mr Achilles Constantinidis, Mr Keating's 50 per cent partner in those companies until Mr Keating `disposed' of his interests to Mr Constantinidis in March of last year. Most of these actions relate to the period when Mr Keating was the half owner.

PARA.TAB: The first complaint I made to the Australian Securities Commission was that Mr Constantinidis held himself out to be an officer of Parkville Stud Pty Ltd, a company that is simply not listed on the Australian Securities Commission database as ever having existed under this or any other name. I sent the ASC copies of employment separation certificates for three workers signed by Mr Constantinidis on behalf of Parkville Stud Pty Ltd, a non-existent company. Of course, it is illegal to hold yourself out to represent a company that does not exist.

The second complaint was that Mr Constantinidis held out that this non-existent company, Parkville Stud Pty Ltd, was the employer at the Woodlands Piggery at Kootingal near Tamworth and this, of course, was evidenced—I always believe in providing the evidence—by taxation group certificates in three names for the income years 1992-93 and 1993-94. For all but three months of that two-year period, Mr Keating was the half owner.

The third complaint is that Mr Keating's partner, Mr Constantinidis, is listed as a director and secretary of a company named Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd. This does have an ACN number; it is actually a real company; the number is 059356946. When I wrote my letter to the ASC, this company had failed to file its annual return by the due date. This company is claimed by Mr Constantinidis to have taken over the Woodlands Piggery on 1 July 1994 and it was registered on 8 March 1993—that is, nine months after Parkville Stud Pty Ltd was held out to be the employer at Woodlands Piggery. It was due to file an annual return on 8 October 1994 but, according to the search that I made on 3 January this year, this return was still outstanding.

The failure to file an annual return means that the identify of the ultimate owner of Parkville Stud Pty Ltd had not yet been placed on the public record by the ASC, although this matter happened to be material in attempting to assess the position of three former employees who had taken action against the company in relation to wrongful dismissal. Clearly, it is of great relevance to other employees of the group.

As I pointed out to the ASC, these matters affect the integrity of the ASC's database and are of public concern. Clearly, the non-existent company cannot be dismissed as a clerical error, as Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd is only stated by Mr Constantinidis, according to a statutory declaration to the court, to have acquired the Woodlands Piggery in 1994, whereas Parkville Stud Pty Ltd, the non-existent company, is shown as the employer from 1 July 1992.
The response I got from the ASC was incredibly inadequate. It said, among other things, this:

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that one or more documents prepared under the name Parkville Stud Pty Ltd in fact are incorrect to the extent that no company by that precise name exists.
Thank you, ASC. You have confirmed what I knew. The ASC goes on:
As you have advised, there is a company called Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd. The ASC has been advised that Parkville Stud—
that is, the non-existent company—
was, at the time, a division of Browne and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd and, consequently, the employer name shown on the documents should correctly have been that company. The tax file number—
Goodness me! Do not tell me this is coming up again—
shown on that document—
which was not revealed to me—
in fact relates to Browne and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd.
I think the ASC has made a mistake. I do not think it means tax file number; I think it means group certificate number. The ASC goes on:
It is a breach of the Corporations Law to state that a company is a registered company if it is not. However—
and this is what really concerns me—

the ASC has taken the view that the context in which such offence occurred should be taken into account and in particular, regard should be had as to any consequences that might flow from such an incorrect name. Our judgment in this instance is that no particular damage was caused—
by this illegal act—

to any person as a direct result of the incorrect name being shown, particularly given that the tax file number was correct for the Browne and Hatton Group. The ASC does not, therefore, intend that any action be taken against any person in relation to these particular documents.
That is absolutely incredible. At the end of the previous paragraph, the Senate will note that the ASC said:
The tax file number shown on the document in fact relates to Browne and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd.
In the paragraph I have just read it says:
. . . particularly given the tax file number was correct for the Browne and Hatton Group.

A different company altogether. This is the problem that has been before the industrial relations court, why some workers of this group have been cheated out of proper payment. What intrigues me is the further remark by the ASC:
The regulatory philosophy of the ASC is designed to ensure compliance with requirements generally for the lodgment of documents to ensure an accurate database.
Here we have clear evidence of inaccuracy and the ASC failing to take action. The letter then says:
I note that other proceedings are either proposed or are in train by former employees of the Group.

In other words, the ASC acknowledges that this deception, this cheating, this pretending that a company exists that did not exist is of relevance and substance to the extent that proceedings are either proposed or are in train by former employees against the group and yet it pretends that no particular damage was caused to any person. I have never struck such nonsense from a government commission.

PARA.TAB: Concerning the assertion in the letter that the tax file number shown on the document relates to Browne and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd, the evidence I have is that the group certificate number of Browne and Hatton Rural Pty Ltd is 17577217, but that the group certificate number for the Browne and Hatton Group is 15434622—a totally different number.

I expect the Australian Securities Commission to get its act in order. This is not a matter that I just suddenly brought up. I have been raising the consistent breaches of the ASC requirements by Mr Keating's piggery group for years and the Australian Securities Commission still cannot get it right. The ASC goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has also followed up the returns of various of the companies in the Browne and Hatton Group and I am advised that 1994 returns for those various companies have all now been lodged with the exception of Poyntell Pty Ltd.
That is a company of which Mr Constantinidis is a director:
Several of those returns are subject to queries by the commission as to some of the information shown in the return.

The ASC is at it again. This group has consistently failed to report properly and accurately to the Australian Securities Commission and, quite frankly, nothing effective has been done to prevent it. Sure, the group has received penalty notices—I acknowledge that—and it has paid its penalties. However, there has been no prosecution. These are just automatic penalties, automatic to the extent that Mr Constantinidis did not pay his for something like 18 months until I raised it in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that there have been consistent, deliberate breaches of the ASC requirements by Mr Constantinidis and his group, both during the period Mr Keating was a half owner and after Mr Keating `disposed' of his half interest. It is interesting that he did not ever use the word `sell'. The ASC letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of the returns are already available for searching through the ASC database and it is anticipated that other returns will shortly be available upon receipt of the additional information. The non-lodgement of Poyntell is also being followed up.
The 1994 annual return for Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd was lodged out of time, as you had advised. A penalty notice—
another penalty notice—
for failure to lodge on time was issued to that company on 30 January 1995 in accordance with usual procedures of the Commission relating to the non-lodgement or the late lodgement of returns.

Is it not incredible that after all of that has gone on in this chamber, after all the revelations about this group—the Keating piggery group—consistently breaching ASC requirements, they are still at it. They still cannot get their returns in on time. Their returns still require further examination.

PARA.TAB: I am intrigued to note that the company which is shown in the documents as being the shareholder in Parkville Pig Stud Pty Ltd is called Spearhawk Pty Ltd. I must say that that is a marvellous name. Mr Keating's former piggery company is now owned by Spearhawk and that is what Mr Keating did to Mr Hawke: he surely speared him. I do not know what humorist selected that name. Spearhawk Pty Ltd is a two-dollar paid up company. It is entirely owned by another company called Sephrenia Pty Ltd. We know nothing of Sephrenia as it is an exempt audited company and is not required to provide any details.

The question is this: how can it possibly be that the ASC can refrain from taking action against a group of companies that are habitually in breach of its requirements? In particular, how can they pretend that no particular damage was caused to any person as a direct result of the incorrect name being shown? The fact is that these employees have been massively disadvantaged. They pursued the wrong entity for wrongful dismissal. That resulted in a day being totally wasted in the industrial court. The argument presented by the Keating piggery group was, `Nah ne nah, you've sued the wrong one of us. It was our fourth index finger instead of our third index finger.'

We have a disgraceful situation where workers who were employed by a company that was half owned by Mr Keating have been cheated by the use of this kind of device—that is, the wrong company name. The former employees were pressured by their union to accept an inadequate settlement because the cost of finding out the real employer was extraordinarily large. The employer was hidden by this improper use of a front company that did not exist. There have been costs and people have been disadvantaged. As I understand it, the matter will come up again before the industrial court next week. This thing has been dragging on for 9 months because of this fiddling, and the Securities Commission says that no harm has been done. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. You would no doubt be aware that last year, according to the Prime Minister, he asked his own departmental officials to look at whether the form of welcoming ceremonies was still relevant to contemporary Australia. Will you undertake to inform the Senate of the costs of establishing a permanent ceremonial honour guard; how many men and women would be seconded to this unit; and where their home base would be when not parading for Mr Keating and guests? Do you support Mr Keating's proposal? Can you inform the Senate whether Mr Keating has expressed any thoughts on the style of uniform he has in mind for his guard? Will gold braids, brass buttons, epaulets and plumes predominate, as befits the very model of a modern part-time Prime Minister? Or will he perhaps commission Lizzy Gardiner and Tim Chapel to design a gold Amex number to remind foreign visitors of how much debt his government has racked up on its international Bankcard?

—That is a question that barely deserves the dignity of an appropriate answer. On the question of the feasibility of some process of this kind being introduced to honour visiting dignitaries in the way in which we are honoured overseas, I think it is appropriate that I ask the Minister for Defence to respond on that question of detail.

—As this regards the Defence Force, it relies on me to put down that furphy and stupid question. The only thing the Prime Minister noted, which is something I have also noted, is that the quality of honour guards in Canberra is fairly mediocre compared with the rest of Australia and with what the Defence Force can do. There is a logical and rational explanation for that.
—There is a force structure review.

—Thank you, Senator Newman. The force structure review says that the major defence assets move north and west quite properly. That is absolutely no reflection on the honour guards we currently have. They are not in full-time training. The question the Prime Minister asked was: can we either improve that, or do we go to another form of ceremony to assist in greeting dignitaries who come to this country? So the defence department looked at all angles.

PARA.TAB: One of the angles was to ask: should we do what other countries do in terms of having a professional honour guard? The immediate response from the department, having raised the question, was: no, we will not, because it would be too costly and it simply would not fit the Defence mission.

This furphy has been taken off one newspaper article of today from a reporter who did not ring my office. I know why he did not ring my office—he would not have liked the response; he would not have liked this furphy, which fits the opposition conspiracy theories, to be deflated. He was told by the Prime Minister's office where this was all at. Again, he failed to properly put that in his article. This is a furphy. It simply came out of a view that the Prime Minister and I share that the honour guards that we turn out in Canberra are not of the same quality that we can turn out in Darwin, Townsville or many other military areas. One of the questions we were looking at is whether we should have them at all, or what are the alternatives. For Senator Alston to talk today about uniforms and all the other glib stuff is sarcastic nonsense.

I also say to him, because he is relying on one article in the Sydney Morning Herald, that there are also a lot of gratuitous comments about the upgrading of the VIP fleet. I might as well put that down right now. Some weeks ago, the Prime Minister indicated to me that he did not intend to have the 707 refitted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has changed his mind?

—No. This is where the gullible opposition would believe every newspaper article. He asked us to look at it and we allocated money for it, but he had some weeks ago rejected it. The same allegation and the same assertion that is in the Sydney Morning Herald could have been easily refuted if the reporter had checked with my office and had got a response. With the indulgence of the Senate, I indicate that the money allocated to changing one of the 707s we are now considering allocating to hush kitting the entire 707 fleet so that when they fly into cities like the one where Senator Tambling lives they will be much quieter. (Time expired)

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with interest the answer given by the minister that somehow Canberra is not quite up to the quality of other capital cities. The fact is that the Prime Minister said in a press statement today that he asked his officials to look at whether their form was still relevant to contemporary Australia—in other words, more cultural cringe. He wanted to know how we can upgrade so we can compete with the rest of the world in terms of pomp and ceremony and splendour? As I understand it from his press release, he said that your department advised that one option would be the formation of a permanent ceremonial guard unit, but this would be costly. Will the minister tell us what the cost was? How much effort was put in by all these officials in pandering to the whim of the Prime Minister? Why does he not concentrate on real issues affecting real people instead of turning his mind to something as inconsequential as this to ordinary Australians but obviously of paramount importance to his imperial highness?

—I indicate clearly to the Senate that the issue the Prime Minister raised was not whether honour guards should necessarily be upgraded or downgraded but whether they were the most appropriate way of welcoming visiting dignitaries. I have made no reflection on those honest defence uniform people in Canberra, whose main mission is not infantry or anything else, who have to turn out honour guards. It is not a matter that they train or practise for every day.

PARA.TAB: What we have here is just a reiteration by the opposition of its own fantasies and fanciful view of the Prime Minister. The opposition is trying to inflame prejudices in the community. It is quite appropriate for the Prime Minister, who has to greet many visiting guests, to make sure that that is done in the most appropriate way possible because that reflects on the way those people will form one of their many impressions of Australia. It is the same when any of us visit overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from Kiribati led by the Speaker of the House of Assembly, Mr Tamuera. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mr Tamuera was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I note that on the front page of today's Australian Financial Review there is a headline `Profits boom'. The article refers to the interim results of the Australian Stock Exchange and Australian Financial Review survey for 1994-95. The survey shows that for Australian companies, earnings before interest and taxes are up by 11.5 per cent and profits are up by a very healthy 19.2 per cent. Can the minister advise the Senate what these latest profit figures tell us about the economic outlook for Australian companies?

—These figures reflect what the Prime Minister has been saying: Australia has been enjoying 36 months of economic growth. We have the highest growth level of any economy in the OECD, and these figures reflect that. This is indicated in today's Australian Financial Review, which shows a survey of interim company profits for the six months to December 1994 carried out by the Australian Stock Exchange and the Australian Financial Review.

PARA.TAB: This survey of company profits and other recent indicators points to sustained economic growth for the future. It paints a very positive picture. Net profits for Australia's major listed companies in the six months to the end of December 1994 were 30 per cent higher than for the same period in 1993. This profit rise comes on top of three years of extraordinary growth in profits, where we had a trebling of earnings in the three years to 1993-94.

As the Prime Minister has often said, we have had 13 consecutive quarters of strong growth with very low inflation. There has not been such employment growth combined with low inflation and strong GDP growth over two years since 1965-66 to 1966-67. Australia is going through a period of very high growth historically. As the report says, this is proof of the strength of the recovery in Australia.

The strong rise in profits augurs well for continued strong investment growth in the period ahead. I remind the Senate that when we forecast in the last budget what the investment levels would be in the Australian economy, the opposition rubbished those forecasts as being unattainable. Now we are going to overshoot and over achieve on those forecasts, which just shows that the opposition's strategy is to rubbish good news in Australia, hail bad news in Australia and pretend that somehow it is making political capital out of it.

Business investment in the September quarter 1994 national accounts was 22.2 per cent higher than for the year earlier. The latest ABS figures indicate that spending on private new capital expenditure in the first half of 1994-95 was 23 per cent higher than in the same period a year earlier. The expectations were for a substantial increase for the whole of 1994-95. The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry-Westpac survey of industrial trends for the March quarter 1995 released earlier this week shows that respondents remain very confident about investment prospects, with 40 per cent of respondents expecting to lift capital spending over the next 12 months.

Other pointers to increased investment are reduced debt levels and higher rates of capacity utilisation. Sustained non-inflationary growth in the economy will occur only if investment is strong enough to prevent supply bottlenecks emerging. These latest profit figures and recent investment statistics indicate that capacity will not be constrained on future economic growth.

Other leading indicators suggest that demand is moderating to more sustainable levels. The latest ACCI national survey of business confidence for the March quarter indicates that economic growth is expected to continue over the course of this year but at a more sustainable rate than has been the case over the past 12 months. The survey also indicated that the investment recovery has maintained its momentum. Profits like those in this result come from the government's real economic policies for sustainable economic growth. You do not get sustained low inflation and half a million new jobs—as we have generated in the last two years—without good economic management.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. Within that overall very positive assessment of the state of the Australian company profit levels, can the minister outline the best performing sectors?

—Companies in most sectors of the economy increased profits. The best performers in the economy for profits were the transport sector, which converted a $103 million aggregate loss in the six months to September 1993 to a $75 million profit in the first half of 1994. Mining companies experienced a doubling of profits to $352 million. Building materials companies increased their profits by 139 per cent to $372 million. Property investors and property trusts increased profits by 228 per cent to $224 million. Other sectors to substantially increase profits were engineering, oil and gas, retail and banking. The message from this survey must be an overall endorsement of the government's economic policies, which have created the macro-economic settings in which these sectors and the economy in aggregate can grow its profit share and create funds for reinvestment in Australian development. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to his statement yesterday that he will be activating the backup detention facilities for boat people at Curtin air base in Western Australia over the next few weeks. Would the minister advise the Senate why he has found it necessary to take this costly step? Why has the government failed to meet the proposed March commencement date for the return of Sino-Vietnamese boat people, which was the premise for rushing Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) through this parliament last month? Is it because of difficulties with the arrangements and timetable agreed earlier this year with the PRC government for the repatriation of these people? If so, what are these difficulties? Is the minister's planned trip to China, I understand, starting tomorrow associated with attempting to resolve those difficulties?

—I think the statement Senator Short refers to is one I made earlier this year saying that we were hoping to return the boat people to China by March at the earliest. Let me say with respect to why they are still here that it goes very much to continuing discussions with the Chinese. Let me say also at the outset that those discussions have been both constructive and successful. We have had cooperation with them in terms of an agreement to return and we have also had cooperation with Chinese authorities as to a verification process.

PARA.TAB: I also say in this respect, when one looks at the time it takes such agreements to come into place and to get such cooperation, we have probably been much more successful on a time basis than any other country that has attempted the same sort of process. We have managed to get this far much faster than any other country in the same situation.

In terms of constructiveness, let me also put on record the fact that since last November when one officer of my department went to China to discuss this matter with Chinese authorities I am informed that no such boat carrying asylum seekers has left from the southern part of China to come to Australia. We quite quickly signed a memorandum with the Chinese authorities on 25 January this year to ensure a process for return of those verified as being Sino-Vietnamese from the southern part of China, particularly through the Baihai Port.

As part of that ongoing process, there have been ongoing discussions with officials. Some 522 biographical data has been provided to Chinese authorities and a verification process is being undertaken at the moment. Let me say to Senator Short and anyone else who has an interest in this that it does take time to verify and this is the process that is going on right now. That is precisely what is happening.

My trip to China was initiated some two months ago and approval was given some time ago. Part of the trip to China is of course to discuss continuing relations between Chinese authorities and the Australian government with respect to not only the number of people we have here now and their return but also any another boat that might be attempting to leave China. Those discussions will be conducted in the same constructive spirit in which we have conducted discussions so far. That trip will canvass that issue as it will canvass quite a number of other bilateral issues. For me it is an important issue. It is one that I have focused on consistently for a number of months now in terms of not only making sure we had the apparatus right in this country to ensure ready return but also the constructive relationship with Chinese authorities.

In terms of the legislation, it was important to have it on the books to ensure the process that we are undergoing now is a process that we could legally undergo. That is why that legislation was put into this place as a priority to ensure that we could continue to process these people and to make assessments with respect to them in accordance with law that would allow for speedy return if they were determined to be Sino-Vietnamese from the south of China. For that, Senator Short, I thank you for your cooperation and I ask you to note that that cooperation has not been misspent. It was a very important process and laid the foundations for the continuing process now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am not sure how to take a compliment from the minister.
—Be careful.

—Be careful, yes. The minister will recall his advice to me and to the Senate earlier this year that he considered the government had done a good deal with the Chinese government on payments associated with the repatriation of the Sino-Vietnamese boat people. I ask him whether he will confirm or deny reports that the PRC government is now requesting payment by the Australian government of $20,000 for each person returned to China and that, if this is so, the cost of returning the existing 690 people would be $13.8 million plus the cost of air travel involved. If this is so, why did his senior officials tell me in January that the total return cost of repatriation, including air fares, would be $2 million? Will the minister be seeking, during his forthcoming visit to China, to negotiate a final amount to be paid to the PRC government?
—I cannot either confirm or deny the $13.8 million.
—Can you confirm the $20,000?

—Hold on. It is something that has not been brought to my attention, so let me say I cannot confirm it. In that respect I can also say that the only assistance that we have been even contemplating, which I think comes up in the Hansard of the estimates that you might be referring to, Senator Short, was assistance to actually repatriate the people. That amount of money was something that, I must say, has not been anticipated from our side.
—Has it been put to you?

—It has not been put to me directly, though I will check to see that it has not been put to others. I am sure that if it had been put to others it would have been brought to my attention. Let me say that that sort of figure is something that has not been put to me. In terms of repatriation assistance, as far as I have seen, there has been nothing formally on the agenda, and I really do not anticipate it coming up in my discussions in China.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. My question concerns the involvement of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in the Australia Remembers commemorations. As the minister would be aware, this morning there was a photographic display, compiled by his department, opened at the War Memorial on the activities of the Australian Women's Land Army—and I would have to say that it was an excellent display as well. Could the minister please explain the significance of the display and also the significance of the contribution made by the Australian Women's Land Army?
—I thank Senator West for the question, but I also would like to particularly thank her for representing me today in launching a photographic display at the Australian War Memorial.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any dispute about that. I was going to go on to say, Senator Parer, that I am very sorry that I could not have been there myself because my mother was a proud member of the Australian Women's Land Army, and one of her proudest possessions to the day she died was a photograph of herself in her land army uniform that hung in our house.

PARA.TAB: It is very fitting that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy chose this particular aspect of World War II as its contribution to the Australia Remembers commemoration. The 3,000-strong Australian Women's Land Army was created specifically to meet the demand for labour in rural industries, particularly those necessary to feed, clothe and equip our military personnel. It also maintained maximum supplies of food for the general population of Australia by filling the vacuum created after farmers and their employees heeded the call to join the armed services. This, of course, immediately created a huge vacuum in a vitally important war industry which was filled by, among others, the personnel of the Australian Women's Land Army. The display will help provide long overdue recognition for the invaluable role that the women members of this group provided to agriculture and, hence, to the war effort of Australia.

The beginning of the war in the Pacific required a fundamental, immediate change to the way in which Australia grew and produced its fruit and vegetables. Prior to this period, market gardens provided all fresh fruit and vegetables. When Australia became the base for the Australian and allied services in the south-west Pacific, extensive expansion was necessary and the area under production had to be doubled almost overnight. Much of this expansion was due to the efforts of the Australian Women's Land Army.

The land army stabilised grape, wheat, maze, citrus, stone fruit and dairy production at pre-war levels, which was a significant achievement for 3,000 women. It increased the production of oats, raisins and currants, apples and vegetables and doubled the Australian production of potatoes and onions. The value of our poultry industry also increased under AWLA care. Thanks to the efforts of these women, a new product was added to the list of Australian agricultural output—flax—which was vitally important to the war effort, and there was also a rapid expansion of the canned food industry. The land army was also involved in the dehydration, the drying, of fruit and vegetables. This industry did not, in fact, even exist in Australia at the start of 1941 but, by 1944-45, dehydrators located close to the farms produced 20,502 tonnes of produce, which of course was all then exportable in its dried form for the provision of troops.

The land army's efforts were vital to the war effort and were accomplished under trying and arduous circumstances. Its legacy has endured through an expansion in rural industries and enormous structural changes over the years in response to market and other challenges. My hope is that the display will enable many to remember and truly appreciate what the Australian Women's Land Army achieved, both at home and abroad.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware that the Commonwealth department of the environment commissioned a report by Professor Jamie Kirkpatrick from the University of Tasmania on the impact of proposed logging operations on Tasmania's world heritage area? Is the minister also aware that that report identifies 15 planned coupes which, if logged, will have a high or very high adverse impact on Tasmania's world heritage area? Is the minister aware that only seven of these coupes are on the Prime Minister's list of areas subject to interim protection? Given your undertaking of 31 August 1994 in which you said that Australia would fulfil its obligations under the World Heritage Convention, what will the government do to protect Tasmania's world heritage area from the 15 planned logging operations?

—I am advised that the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories did commission Professor Jamie Kirkpatrick to produce a report on aspects of world heritage in Australia. The report was one of the sources of information used by the environment portfolio in preparing advice to the minister for the environment on areas of high conservation value, as you say.
—Won't you let Faulkner answer?

—I would be delighted to. I have an answer here which he may well wish to supplement. The advice of the minister for the environment to the Minister for Resources of 7 December 1994 attached a copy of that report and the advice was made publicly available in late December. So the findings of that report are no great secret.

PARA.TAB: As to the senator's question as to whether the certain coupes identified in the Kirkpatrick report are on any interim protection list, I am not in a position to comment on any unnamed, not more precisely identified coupes, nor do I think it is appropriate to pre-empt matters that are shortly to be considered by the cabinet. As to Australia's responsibilities under the World Heritage Convention, what I was referring to whenever it was that I gave that reply were our obligations, shared by all signatories to the convention, to commit ourselves to help in the identification, protection, conservation and presentation of world heritage properties. So it goes on.

That is the basis. It is to assist in that particular process. I do not think there is anything absolute involved, but certainly it is our intention to do everything we possibly can to give the fullest possible protection to those properties. But you will just have to wait and see how we handle the issue of these particular coupes that you are apparently referring to when we deal further with this later this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The government continues to work with the agribusiness sector to improve the competitiveness and market orientation of rural based industries. Can the minister advise the Senate of the industry development activities and approaches that are targeted through the agribusiness program?

—The agribusiness programs of the government are part of the comprehensive structure of positive assistance that this government applies for Australia's rural producers. The programs were introduced by this government to enhance the market orientation of Australia's agribusiness industries. Funding assistance is provided to promote strategic business planning, enhanced quality management and to develop, importantly, export marketing skills for agribusinesses. These programs are an important part of the government's overall approach to improving the international competitiveness of these important rural and, particularly, regional industries in Australia.

PARA.TAB: To highlight the effectiveness of this approach, we need only look at what is happening in the horticultural industries in Australia. Following the last election, the government established a horticultural task force under the chairmanship of Senator Nick Sherry to advise on future prospects for the horticultural industry in Australia. That report provided the groundwork for a comprehensive strategy to build a stronger and far more internationally oriented industry base in Australia.

My colleague Senator Sherry last week launched our horticulture 2000 program, which encompasses all the elements of our response to the task force report. But this does not stand alone. I advise the Senate that last week the Agribusiness Programs Board approved new funding of over $1.3 million to another five horticultural projects in Australia. This includes funding for a comprehensive benchmarking study of five major horticultural products to help drive improvement in export performance in these industries and specific funding to the Australian apple and pear growers, fresh citrus growers in the Riverina, the Australian Dried Fruits Association and the small winemakers, which is one of the truly dynamic industries in Australia at the moment. This brings total agribusiness funding to horticulture to in excess of $5 million.

These individual projects are extremely important. They give substance to the overall thrust of the government's policy approach to industry development, and they represent the delivery of change on the ground. This is yet another clear example of how this government is working with rural Australia for its future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. On Monday, in answer to a question of mine, the minister said that grain imported to Australia from Kansas and Nebraska posed a very low risk. However, his department's 1994 Bureau of Resource Sciences report identified plant pests of economic significance and quarantine concern, including eight fungi pests, one bacterial pest and a virus from Kansas, and six fungi, one bacterial pest and one virus from Nebraska.
—Are you going to declare your interest?

—I will declare my interest. This is nine out of 14 fungi, one out of two bacteria and one out of four viruses of the 20 identified plants of quarantine concern to Australia identified in the government's own report. The minister said that it `posed a very low risk'. How can he mislead the Senate in such a way when the long-term future of the grain industry could be seriously damaged by the wrong decision?

—I wonder whether Senator Crane could do himself and the primary industry community of Australia at least the courtesy of bothering to read the report that he has referred to the next time he puts out a silly press release containing the information he has just delivered. He clearly has not read it. The points he is trying to make form the greatest mishmash of nonsense in terms of the total gross misrepresentation he placed on the report. Unless he is congenitally stupid—I am sure that he is not—he could not have read the report and made those errors of fact in delivering this question.

PARA.TAB: In his assessment, Senator Crane has combined the risk that he has just talked about for all the diseases covered by all of the grain types in the BRS study. He should read the report before he puts out his next press release. In the case of sorghum—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's right here.

—He should listen, because these are the facts. In the case of sorghum, the BRS report identified only three diseases of quarantine concern, not the list that he has just read out or which was contained in his silly press release. I say to him again that in the case of sorghum, which we are sourcing from the safest states—the mid-western states of Kansas and Nebraska—the BRS report identified only three diseases of quarantine concern.

PARA.TAB: In addressing the risk posed by these quarantinable diseases, AQIS has sourced grain, as I said, from states where the diseases do not occur. For sorghum from Kansas and Nebraska, although historic records show that certain diseases have been recorded, more recent surveys by the United States government and university extension authorities—that is, agricultural extension authorities—show that these diseases have not been detected in these states for the past five years or in some cases longer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the document I have.
—Read the whole report, Senator Crane.
—I have.

—You have not. Risk associated with whole grain spillage and dust is being addressed through secure transport systems and dust suppression measures at discharge points in an operational manual that I referred to in my response to Senator Crane's previous questions on 27 March this year. A requirement that all grain be steamed on arrival is not an option for some end users. You also said quite falsely in your press statement that the reason it was decided to import grain `was to assist grain starved areas to feed their stock'. That was an important reason but not, as you have suggested, the only reason.

PARA.TAB: We have millers in Australia that need grain, as well as processors. I am amazed that you, Senator Crane, as a grain producer, have not caught up with this. We have established major export industries in Australia in the last 10 years that use significant quantities of Australian grain for processing and delivery to export markets. The problem with those markets—I am amazed that you, as a grain producer, do not know this—is that some of their processes cannot be carried out if you heat-treat the grain. If you heat-treat the grain, you cannot use some of these processes. This includes the malting of barley, the production of flour and some types of food manufacture. So you are wrong on all counts, Senator Crane.

There have been some grain imports under tightly controlled conditions, and AQIS and the BRS continue to work with the grains industry in developing safe systems for the necessary importation of those grains in order to keep viable a number of major industries, such as poultry production, pig production and feedlotting for beef, that employ thousands of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw the minister's attention again to renewed tensions in central Africa. In particular, I refer the minister to the continuing tragedy in Rwanda and fears that the slaughter which decimated that country could also occur in neighbouring Burundi. Could the minister report further to the Senate on the situation currently in Burundi and the United Nations Security Council's approach concerning that country. What is the attitude of the Australian government?

—The Australian government remains very deeply concerned, as does the entire international community, about the continuing political tensions and deteriorating situation in Burundi. Recent fighting in the capital Bujumbura between the ethnic Hutus and Tutsis has led to the evacuation of tens of thousands of Hutus. It has been estimated that 25,000 to 30,000 of these have crossed into Zaire since last Friday. We are particularly concerned that an estimated 200 to 500 people, predominantly Hutu, have been killed in Bujumbura in the last few days.

PARA.TAB: This follows a period of instability that has gone on for some time now caused by efforts of extremists to undermine the government. It led to the resignation of the former Prime Minister, the murder of two prominent Burundian leaders on the Hutu and Tutsi side respectively earlier this month, and recent fighting between the two groups in the north-east of the country resulting in the outflow of some 24,000 refugees into Tanzania.

Ever since the genocide died in Rwanda in April last year, the international community has been pursuing strategies at several levels to prevent a similar crisis in Burundi. The most important of these have been preventive diplomacy efforts undertaken by the UN Secretary-General, the Security Council and member states acting both individually and through regional organisations.

A Security Council fact-finding mission to Burundi from 10 to 13 February recommended that the Secretary-General establish an international commission of inquiry into the October 1993 coup attempt and the ensuing massacres and that the UN presence in Burundi be augmented to assist the government to improve the judicial system, civilian police training and the administration of provinces. I think I mentioned that in an answer here in February.

Most recently, a Security Council presidential statement of 9 March condemned those involved in undermining the power sharing arrangements outlined in the convention of government and endorsed most of the recommendations contained in that mission report to which I referred. The UN announced a few days ago, on 24 March, that the office of the special representative in Burundi would be expanded.

Since then, in the last few days, the Secretary-General and the Security Council have been considering the options for preventive deployment to Burundi. One suggestion has been to redeploy some of the troops of the UNAMIR mission in Rwanda, across the border to Burundi. Another possibility would be to deploy a new separate multinational force which would be under a national rather than a UN command to maximise the speed of the response.

The government's or at least my initial reaction to these options is that, if the situation deteriorates further and the violence continues to escalate, any intervention by the international community is going to require a peace enforcement capability, with a mandate under chapter VII of the UN charter. UNAMIR in Rwanda does not have such a mandate. It has a chapter VI mandate; it has been resourced and equipped—that is to say—to undertake peacekeeping, not peace enforcement.

The functions of UNAMIR within Rwanda are important in their own right and it is not clear that, as currently constituted, UNAMIR could meet those functions effectively as well as take on major new tasks in Burundi. Moreover, recent experience in Bosnia and Somalia has shown the difficulty of peace keepers assuming a supplementary peace enforcement role if they are not structured originally for that purpose. It would seem to be preferable if the deployment option is pursued accordingly for the Security Council to create a separate operation with its own mandate to use force as necessary.

The challenge for the international community here is to balance the need to act quickly with the need to have a workable concept of operations and an adequately resourced force. The UN has made a concerted effort to prevent conflict, as I have said, in the past 12 months, but the difficulty it faces in identifying a viable response to this current deterioration underlies obviously the need for it to develop a more permanent capacity to respond more rapidly and effectively to emerging crises.

AUSAID, the new version of AIDAB, is monitoring the situation in Burundi very closely. Beyond that, there is nothing more I can positively contribute to this discussion, but it is obviously a situation we are all watching very carefully.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Gareth Evans, Minister for Foreign Affairs and Leader of the Government in the Senate. With regard to the seriousness with which the government views its non-proliferation policy in which export controls on technology with civil and military application play an integral part and in light of the defence minister's statement yesterday that the Australian Federal Police were investigating a customs offence involving a Defence dual technology licence, can the minister give a guarantee that Australia's international obligations on the export of dual technology have not been compromised or jeopardised in any way?

—I am not aware of any conceivable foundation for a suggestion that those obligations, those interests, have been so jeopardised. I would want much more substantial chapter and verse from Senator Boswell before I made even beginnings of an acknowledgment of that kind. I am not sure what he is referring to in detail. If he has some more detailed information, he should give it to me and I will be happy to respond further, if necessary.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister could not give a guarantee. As foreign affairs minister, how will he explain the Australian Federal Police investigation to our allies; and, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, what steps is the government taking to assure the Australian people that Australia's export controls on military technology are not open to abuse?

—I am not in a position to respond specifically on that. There is nothing in anything that Senator Ray said yesterday to do anything other than quash the suggestion of some sort of misapplication of the government rules in this respect, so far as we are concerned. If there is any substance to anything that Senator Boswell has said, he should give us the information and I will respond accordingly. I am not in a position to give him any comfort on the basis of that flimsy bit of nonsense he has just offered.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Prime Minister is reported in the Age newspaper as having told caucus that he would not be diverted from his broad national policy agenda by the clamour for the government to `keep its nose to the sort of mortgage grindstone'. I ask the minister: why did the government renege on its election promise to allow workers to borrow for their homes against their superannuation savings; and would the government mind letting ordinary workers off their mortgage grindstone by allowing them to keep more money to pay off their family homes?

—The government, as has been said in this chamber many times, has concentrated on growing the Australian economy, on creating new jobs. The growth in the Australian economy is the highest of any economy in the OECD. Our job creation is now at half a million new jobs since the last election. Because the higher growth rates are now moderating to a more sustainable level and because inflation is low, job security levels must be higher as well. By decentralising, as we have, the wages system to the enterprise and having negotiations in the enterprise, the rewards of higher profitability—something I spoke of earlier in question time—can be better accessed by those workers who will help generate those levels of higher productivity.

PARA.TAB: It is in that setting of managing the economy so that it is sustainable and so that inflation does not ravage wages and undermine living standards that the issue of home mortgage rates arises. As a consequence of the Reserve Bank's decision to adjust the prime lending rate, most banks initially absorbed the change and did not pass it on to their mortgagees. There is now, due to the policies of this government, a higher degree of competition between banks. All this speaks to government policies directed to the needs of individual Australians, recognising the need to provide income, income security and access to the profitability of a burgeoning economy. That is what the purpose of the government has been.

In terms of the first part of Senator Harradine's question about superannuation funds, the government is addressing a major gap in the economy. Prior to the government requiring that there be payment of superannuation provisions for all employees, superannuation, as we inherited it from the conservative coalition, was only accessible by about 30 per cent of the work force. If you had a Public Service job or you were in a white collar occupation you got superannuation. The reform we have brought in is that all workers get superannuation and there is equity across-the-board. That is a significant Labor reform.

So the debate is about providing superannuation as a retirement benefit or being able to access superannuation earlier and reduce the advantage of retirement benefits that superannuation would bring. The issues I have referred to, I notice, are attracting heckling from the opposition—heckling from the opposition for a very good political reason. Opposition members have spent their time running around this country decrying every positive economic indicator and acting as saboteurs of the economy, talking the economy down, trying to deter investment and undermining real progress because they believe that economic good news is political bad news for them. It is a political tactic which unfortunately has some damaging consequences for those who listen to them. I think that is the answer to Senator Harradine's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —It really did not answer my question. Could I leave the past aside and point out to the minister, if he did not already know, that many working families, particularly those with children, are finding it impossible to make ends meet now on their incomes and keep up their mortgage repayments. I ask this direct question of the minister: could he put out of the question between now and the budget the suggestion that those workers will now be forced to pay a superannuation tax of three per cent of their wages and thus again reduce their capacity to get off the mortgage repayment grindstone?
—The government is mindful of the concern of ordinary Australians and identifies strongly with it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members horse laugh at that but they do not represent ordinary Australians. We represent ordinary Australians and are concerned about ensuring that their economic wellbeing is taken care of.

—The loudness of the denial indicates the insecurity of their position. I have been asked to rule in or, as in this case, rule out something, which obviously I cannot do before a budget is brought down.
