It is not for me to speculate or fuel speculation about what may be in or what may be out of a budget. No government does that. I cannot do that now. All I can say to those people who are concerned about it is to wait for budget day and they will see what the government's measures have been. To opposition senators, who have been in the business of trying to work out what the budget contains by asking for things to be ruled in or ruled out I say just sit there, sit up straight, behave yourselves and wait for budget night.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to the draft ruling changing the sales tax exemption on prescribed minerals and vitamins for doctors' patients. I also remind the Senate that vitamins and minerals have traditionally been sales tax exempt. Is not the purpose of the ruling process to interpret simplified sales tax law rather than to widen the sales tax net? Minister, why has your government made a decision that preventative medicines and drugs will no longer be tax exempt?

—That may well have been a very good question for all I know, but I did not hear the pregnant bit. I did not hear the bit in which Senator Watson raised his finger and began pointing at the same time as he said `why'. I ask Senator Watson to please repeat that part of his question.

—I am glad the minister is treating the question with the seriousness that it deserves. Minister, why has your government made a decision that preventative medicines and drugs will no longer be tax exempt?
—Answer it seriously.

—Senator Macdonald will get a serious answer if he behaves himself and stops breaching standing orders. Senator Watson refers to a draft ruling of the Taxation Commissioner, as I understand it, relating to particular drugs. I do not have any information before me about that draft ruling, but draft rulings are exactly what they say they are: draft and not final. The purpose of making a draft ruling is to hear views as to whether or not sections of the community and indeed of the industry affected regard the interpretation of tax law in the draft as being accurate.

PARA.TAB: For that reason, I think two things need to be said. Firstly, this is a draft ruling issued by the tax commissioner, not by the government. As Senator Watson would know, the tax commissioner is statutorily independent of us and has the responsibility and authority to interpret the tax act appropriately and everyone else has the opportunity to challenge that at law if they think he is wrong. Secondly, if this is a draft ruling, let us let the draft course of that ruling run its course and start dealing with the issue when it is finalised rather than start to conjecture and to speculate before it is finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the hundreds of thousands of Australians who will be living in fear and trepidation waiting for the process to take its course, cannot you give a decision that these items will continue to be tax exempt?

—I do not decry the hundreds of thousands or so Australians Senator Watson refers to, but I must say that I do not know that it is fair to depict them as living in fear and trepidation, as Senator Watson has. I think in all fairness and in truth most people would not know that the tax commissioner has issued that draft ruling. Aficionados of the tax system would know it, but I do not think everyone else in ordinary Australia would know it. I do not have any information before me about it.

PARA.TAB: So do not start dramatising and do not start scaremongering about what the possibilities of a draft are for the rest of Australia. As I said, the reasonable course to follow is for those who have views about the accuracy of the draft to put them in the appropriate way and have them dealt with in the appropriate way. If the final ruling that comes out throws up an anomaly in the tax act—I do not refer to only this case; I comment in general—that we do not intend to be there, we will deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer the minister to a commitment given by the Prime Minister before the last election to raise funding for medical research to at least two per cent of total health outlays by the year 2000. Given that it is now only five years until the year 2000, does the government have a plan for meeting that objective? If so, will the minister provide the Senate with a copy? Does the minister consider it acceptable that only one quarter of research grant applications were funded by the NHMRC last year? Does she acknowledge that this high rate of rejection is having an adverse effect on medical research in Australia? Finally, will the minister guarantee that this year's budget will deliver realistic levels of support for medical research or will at least set the government on track to meet the Prime Minister's commitments?

—The track record of this government on the support of medical research is clear. Funding for medical research through the National Health and Medical Research Council has risen from around $30 million in 1983 to a level of about $119 million in 1994. That is more than a doubling in real terms. In last year's budget, an additional $9 million was provided to the NHMRC, lifting research funding through the NHMRC to $128 million. The latest figures for total health research spending are for 1990-91 with an update expected from the Australian Bureau of Statistics this year for 1992-93.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the minister has been asked a question that is very important to the health of this nation. Senators, including the ministers opposite, are making it impossible to hear the answer. They are behaving like schoolboys. Would you bring them into line so we can hear the minister trying to explain away why her government has not done the right thing by medical research in this coun try?
—I agree with you entirely and I would ask members on my right to maintain quiet.

—I think I was explaining that the latest figures provided to government for total health research spending are for 1990-91. There is an update expected from the Australian Bureau of Statistics this year for 1992-93. It is therefore not possible to assess the effect of the additional funds the government has provided, in conjunction with increased industry funding, on the progress towards meeting the two per cent target.

PARA.TAB: The government will continue to monitor the situation and has clearly signalled that it will continue its strong support for health and medical research. It has also shown that it wishes to see an improved level of support for medical research from the private sector, and government industry incentives have led to substantial increases in this area in recent years. Discussions have been held with researchers about details of research funding through both the private and the public sectors and the government will be making a decision about further funding for the NHMRC in this year's budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer, but she is mixing the apples and the oranges all together in the one basket. She is mixing in public health research and social health research into the medical research basket. Medical research on its own is under one per cent at the moment. What is the minister's plan to get it up to the Prime Minister's promise of two per cent by the year 2000?

—As I say, the ABS figures and the new analysis will be provided to the government very shortly. If there is anything further to add to the details of that part of your question, I will take it on notice and get back to you.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Australian Tourist Commission was involved in its major European promotion effort to sell Australian tourism at the international tourism Bourse in Berlin while the Prime Minister was there gratuitously advising German leaders on how to redesign their city. Why did the part-time Prime Minister, Mr Keating, snub the 117 Australian companies represented at the Bourse and choose to have an afternoon off, instead of meeting his responsibilities of promoting Australia? Do Australian tourism's efforts to promote their major growth industry fail to rate as one of the great things the Prime Minister places ahead of more mundane problems like worrying about Australian families who have their noses to the mortgage grindstone?

—There is no more effective job that Paul Keating could have done for Australia in Germany than the one he did at Hanover in opening the CeBit exhibition, with 170 Australian high-tech information technology companies promoting and selling not only the immediate technology that they were engaged in selling themselves but also promoting a new image of Australia as a high-tech, sophisticated 21st century country, not the kind of country that is the subject of all the stereotypes which you mob find so comfortable.

PARA.TAB: That was the basic job that the Prime Minister was doing in Germany, along with the very significant and far-reaching talks that he had with Chancellor Kohl and other senior German ministers, talks that certainly did put Australia on the map as a country of sophistication and competence in political and economic management, with views of the world and of the region and of Germany's relationship with this part of the world which deserve to be taken very seriously indeed by the German government, and which were taken very seriously by the German government.

There are always multiple demands being made upon prime ministerial time in these trips. I am not aware of the particular circumstances that you are referring to. I am not aware whether any invitation was even given to the Prime Minister or whether there was any knowledge of his presence there by the organisers of that particular exhibition or conference to which you refer. If the Prime Minister has anything further he wants to add on this subject, I will ask him to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder if the minister could find out whether the Prime Minister deliberately ignored this major Australian tourism promotion. Or was he not wanted, reflecting the view of the majority of Australians today?

—That is an extremely tendentious way of putting the question, as no doubt Senator Parer was acutely conscious when he wrote it out before he came here. The situation is that the Prime Minister is acutely conscious, as we all are, of the contribution that tourism makes to the Australian economy, with an increasing number of people coming to the country not only from our own region, with Taiwan and Korea rapidly joining the numerical ranks of Japanese, so far as the significance of that is concerned, along with South-East Asia.

PARA.TAB: All of that needs to be supplemented by more substantial tourist input from Europe; that is coming from young Germans, young Swiss and young Scandinavians in huge numbers. That has been particularly significant for the lower end of the tourist market in Australia. There is, of course, a case to be made for continued very active promotion of this particular sector. You can be absolutely assured that the Prime Minister is very conscious of that and will continue to do everything he can to assist that industry. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time, Senator Short asked me a question about reintegration assistance in respect of boat people. I have had some clear advice from my department. I can say that Senator Short's claim that the PRC is seeking $20,000 per boat person is a furphy. I can also deny categorically that any sum of $20,000, or anywhere near it, has been either discussed or requested by the Chinese. I can advise that during discussions with the Chinese on the MOU—I think Senator Short has been briefed about this—they indicated that, since these people have been out for just a short time, they were only anticipating reintegration assistance of a relatively small amount. That point was made public at the time. Nothing has happened to change this.

—The day before yesterday, Senator Ian Macdonald asked me a question in respect of the better cities exhibition and why, as he claims, only Labor Party people had been invited to it. Mr Howe advises me that all state planning ministers were invited to attend the event. Several planning ministers from the state governments were invited to speak at the seminar. For instance, Hon. Richard Lewis, the Western Australian Minister for Planning, Minister for Heritage and Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport, was invited. He was represented by Mr Ian Osborne. Mr Tom Cleary, the Tasmanian Minister for Environment and Land Management, was also invited, as was Robert MacLellan, the Victorian Minister for Planning. I am informed that each minister was unable to attend due to other commitments. The respective planning ministers for the ACT and New South Wales were also unavailable, due to the elections being conducted. Once again, the basis of Senator Macdonald's question was wrong.

—Further to a question without notice from Senator Chamarette on 28 February, I table a report by Dr Arthur Johnston, Director of the Environment Research Institute of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The report provides information on scientific assessments and monitoring programs relating to the potential release of water from the restricted release zone of the Ranger uranium mine.

DEBATE.TITLE: POST-MORTEM ON SUSPECTED TOXIC SHOCK VICTIM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—further to the answer I gave to Senator O'Chee yesterday on the subject of tampon use and toxic shock, I advise the Senate that last night I made a public statement on the matter making clear my regret that I did not instruct the sensitive post-mortem material to be excised from the detailed document made available to certain specialist journalists and I unreservedly apologised to the family of the girl in question for any further grief, anguish or distress the release of this information may have caused them. My statement read:

SPEECH.PARA: In response to widespread public concern about tampon use and toxic shock syndrome—particularly following a 7.30 Report and newspaper stories in January about the death of a Queensland teenager last November—I sought a detailed report from the Therapeutic Goods Administration (Department of Human Services and Health) on the standards and safety issues involved.

A nine-page report I received from the TGA addressed these issues in considerable detail, making it clear that much of the media reporting had caused quite unnecessary alarm, and that Australian standards in fact led the world.

Announcing the TGA conclusions on March 13, I released a three-page summary of the report to the media at large, and made available a copy of the full report to several specialist journalists who asked for it.

Unfortunately, the detailed nine-page report contained, in its background section, a two-paragraph precis of sensitive medical information derived from the post-mortem report on the Queensland teenager. While the name and address of the girl was not mentioned, her identity would have been obvious to any person who had been following the public debate. I deeply regret the detailed version of the report was released without this material being depleted.
I unreservedly apologise to the family of the girl in question for any further grief, anguish or distress the release of this information may have caused them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of Senator Crowley's statement.
—On the understanding it is not going to be a protracted debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) for finally saying today what she should have said in answer to Senator O'Chee's perfectly reasonable question yesterday. On the minister's part, this has been a very tacky little exercise. Yesterday you were asked a very reasonable question that went to the privacy of a young girl who died, possibly from toxic shock or possibly from something else, and to the grief that the release of that personal information caused her family. You ducked and weaved and did everything you possibly could to avoid that but what you actually did.

PARA.TAB: You actually sought to say that the question did not relate to the release of the sensitive information but related to the safety of tampons in Australia, which it did not. You sought to evade the real question by answering a question you invented that related to the safety of tampons. As I recall, you had the gall to imply, when senators on this side said that you were not answering the question, that we were not interested in the safety of those products when, in fact, we were interested in the safety of those products and also what you did in releasing this information. That can at very best be described as a tacky little exercise.

Finally, when asked a supplementary question you were dragged kicking and screaming to the truth of the matter—that is, that you did release this information. You sought to justify that by saying that that information was in a further detailed statement that some specialist journalists had requested as if in some way that exonerated your activity and entitled you to answer no to the first question when clearly it did not.

When we sought to take note of your answer you tabled your three-page press release in order to imply that that is what you had done. You later referred to this other information that you had given out. In your case, it has been a tragedy of errors of judgment. Your first error was to leave the information in the report in the first place. Your second error was not apologising to the parents and admitting your mistake as soon as Senator O'Chee quite reasonably raised the issue in this place.

You compounded the error by making another error of judgment; that is, you tried to squirm out of your responsibility for your actions with these pathetic and deceitful claims that you made in your first answer yesterday. You made an error of judgment by not recognising your mistake and apologising for misleading the Senate in your first answer. There is nothing wrong with that. People misunderstand questions every now and then. They say, `I'm sorry. I've made a mistake. I thought you were asking me this; you were asking me that. I'll now give you the answer you want.' That was a further error of judgment.

You still refused to apologise to the parents. You had three opportunities in this place yesterday to do that: in the first question, in the supplementary question and when taking note of your answers. On each of those occasions, you could not be dragged kicking and screaming to apologise to the family. It was then compounded because you tried to imply that Senator O'Chee had some other motive and he was just raising the subject of tampons in general.

You went further than that on the PM program last night. I listened with care to what you had to say on that program, and I was pleased that you were prepared to apologise to the parents and at least say that you were sorry for the harm that had been caused. But I was somewhat surprised to hear you still try to squirm out of responsibility for what happened.

You tried to deny responsibility in two ways. In the first instance, you said that not only were you entitled to release this information but you had a public duty to release it. No-one on this side denies the public duty of any minister to release information on health matters that the public needs. But you cannot hide under that duty or behind that shield and use that as a reason for releasing the personal information about this girl. Again, you were trying to say that you had some responsibility to do this callous thing that you did.

Further to that, when the journalists saw through that and said, `Surely the details of this girl's post-mortem don't add to the sum of public knowledge on it,' you replied, `The TGA—the Therapeutic Goods Administration—thought it was relevant,' as if to say, `Let's blame the TGA.' You were still saying, `Hands off. I had nothing to do with this. This was not me. Let's blame the TGA,' without mentioning that that material was put in a private report to you as background information, and without mentioning that it was you who chose to release that report, to all intents and purposes, to the public. Last night's PM program was another opportunity—the fourth opportunity—for you to face up to your responsibilities.

One of your responsibilities was to apologise to the family. Thankfully, you had the brains on that program—probably after being pushed by your colleagues—to apologise to the family. But you still could not bring yourself to admit that you were wrong, that it was your responsibility and that you did it. That is in very stark contrast to your senior minister, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). That gives us some insight into why you are where you are and she is where she is.

When presented with this problem, Dr Lawrence said that she was not aware of this detail, and I believe the Hansard says that. Dr Lawrence had not only the political sense—because we are not complaining about Senator Crowley's lack of political sense; although that is so overtly obvious it would be pointless to remark upon it—but also the sensitivity and responsibility to say, `I am the responsible minister. I take responsibility for what has been done, and I unreservedly apologise.'

Why couldn't you do that when you first answered Senator O'Chee's question yesterday? Why did we have to go through this dragging and screaming exercise to make you realise what you had done, admit it and accept responsibility for it? Why do you have such a manifest inability to do that? That is the point that we want to make. In stark contrast to your minister—who, as I have said, indicated that she was the responsible minister and would take responsibility and unreservedly apologise—the first thing you have done is say, `I didn't do it.'

Then you said, `I kept away from all this. I did not want to release all this information.' Then finally in answer to the supplementary question you said, `Yes, I did, but that was not what I was asked. It is all too confusing.' It was confusing for you maybe but apparently not for your senior minister and not for anybody else on this side and not, I might say, for any of your colleagues. Then you tried to dump it on to the TGA saying it was all their fault. Then you tried to claim you had some sort of responsibility to release this detailed information.

If you think there was anything in that detailed information that made you have a responsibility to pass it on, you could have phrased whatever that was. Perhaps you think the detailed information reveals the possibility of an alternative cause of death. Perhaps you think that. If you do, you could have said quite simply, `Medical evidence indicates there is a possible alternative cause of death. Women around Australia should not assume that this is a toxic shock syndrome case.' That is all you had to say. It does not take a lot of wit to take out personal information about the young girl and to make that statement. In fact, that would be a more effective way of indicating your concern to Australian women.

It is on the last point vis-a-vis Australian women that I want to conclude. I indicated to Senator Evans that I would not go on at length. I do not think people need to highlight, by repeating, the level of incompetence you have displayed. I am prepared to leave that point there, but you have done Australian women no service at all. Your government, along with the opposition, believes that we need more women in parliament. You and I would say as we go to speak at functions in relation to women's groups that women can do it as well as men.

You know there are fewer women in parliament and you know every time one of us makes a big bungle like you have it does nothing for the younger women trying to come up, because all your mates will say vis-a-vis the next woman who wants to be a minister, `Hope she's not like Crowley and makes all those bungles.' You know. It is unfair, I know. The boys bungle but because there are fewer of us you have a responsibility to bungle less—a responsibility you are manifestly incapable of living up to. When women get to positions such as yours, since you see yourself as some role model, it would be handy if you could bring yourself to discharge your responsibilities in such a way that Australian women can be proud of you rather than mumble behind their hands that they wish you had not muffed this up as comprehensively as you did.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ignore the feminist dimension of Senator Vanstone's contribution coming, as it did, from the foremost exponent of the opposition's gender envy squad over there. We are familiar with that particular part of the deal. I do not think you should do anything other than stick to the issues involved in this particular matter.

PARA.TAB: As to those substantive issues as distinct from the cosmetic colour put on them by Senator Vanstone, let me say this: there is no reasonable case for saying that Senator Crowley in any way misled the Senate in her answer yesterday. She did not say anything at any stage that was factually false and that has not been made out by the opposition. It is perfectly true that it took her until she got a supplementary question to get the basic point that did seem to be being pursued by Senator O'Chee on the record, but she did get there. After all, that is the purpose of supplementary questions, to make sure ministers do get there in their answer. That is enough, I think, on the particular question of misleading the Senate. Saying that a minister has misled the Senate is a serious suggestion to make. There is no foundation for that in this instance.

As to the other issue that was the centrepiece of Senator Vanstone's contribution, it does need to be understood that Senator Crowley's handling of this matter has been motivated from start to finish by deep and sincere concern for the public interest in this matter. In particular, she was anxious to convey a very clear message to the Australian community—in particular, Australia women—that there was no basic safety or standards problem so far as tampons in Australia are concerned.

She wanted to get on the public record as much detailed information as she possibly could in support of that conclusion. It is on that basis that she made available the much more detailed report of the Therapeutic Goods Administration which overwhelmingly went to these standard and safety issues rather than any individual cases. It is for that reason that she wanted to get that out on the record to those specialist journalists who were capable of writing about this issue in an informed way and who were keen to do so.

One of the points I know that was particularly worrying Senator Crowley throughout her consideration of this matter was her desire to communicate the reality that toxic shock syndrome had not been clearly established as the cause of the young Queensland teenager's death.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can say that; you don't have to release details.

—She was concerned that there had been an automatic assumption that that was the case and that that was introducing a sense of real alarm among women in the Australian community, which was not at this stage justified. To the extent that she focused on it, I think it is fair to say that she took the view that detailed medical information making clear that this was still an open question was not inappropriate to be made available to those journalists who could be expected to write about this in a sensitive and competent way.
—In some ways that makes it even worse. You provide them with medical information so they can see what else there might be. Doesn't that make it worse?

—Senator Hill, if you will allow me just to get a word in edgeways, I am about to acknowledge that I think Senator Vanstone probably made a fair point, as did Senator Newman by interjection just a moment ago, that that point probably could have been made—that the cause of death being toxic shock was not yet clearly established—in those kinds of terms without the need to go to the detailed medical information. Certainly there was a serious downside involved, as you balance these competing interests, in invasion of privacy and putting on the public record medical material that was manifestly of an intimate and sensitive kind.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley—upon opportunity for reflection on the matter and understanding the points that have been made, considering all the issues that are involved in this case and considering again all the balances of competing interests that were involved—has come out with refreshing frankness and absolute honesty and put on the record an account of the situation as she confronted it and made absolutely clear that she would have preferred that the material had been excised. She regrets that that was not done, and she does apologise unreservedly to the family of the girl in question for any further distress or anguish that may have been caused as a result of the release of this information.

That is all any minister could reasonably be expected to do under those circumstances. She has done it, and I think that should be an end to this particular matter. She has been motivated throughout, as she always is, because she is an excellent minister, by considerations of public interest. There is no question of personal particular aggrandisement. There is no question of trying to score any quick political tricks on this matter. She was motivated by the public interest, and she has acknowledged that this particular question might have been handled better in a different way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Crowley had been motivated, as Senator Gareth Evans has told us, throughout this whole incident by a concern for the public interest, then I find it hard to believe that she would have tried to avoid answering this question when it was put to her in parliament yesterday. I find it hard to reconcile the image that Senator Evans portrays of a minister concerned always for the public good with somebody yesterday who was involved in an unseemly exercise in trying to avoid answering a question about why she revealed detailed intimate medical details about a poor 13-year-old girl who had died in Mount Isa. If she was interested and motivated solely by the public good, then why did Senator Crowley not immediately apologise to the family of the girl in question?

PARA.TAB: I see Senator Crowley providing her defence to Senator Cooney. I think Senator Cooney, before he hops to Senator Crowley's defence, ought to read the material that was contained in the further information that Senator Crowley released to journalists. I have got it. I have read it. It is sick. It is really disgusting. I just make the point to the Senate that I can only imagine how entirely upsetting the media coverage of this post mortem must have been for that girl's family.

The only thing for which I am grateful is that, unlike Senator Crowley, some of the journalists who received this information found it so disgusting and so upsetting that they refused to print it. But there were stories carried in newspapers in Mount Isa, Brisbane, Adelaide and elsewhere. I find that very hard to reconcile with Senator Crowley's assertion that this intimate information was only provided, according to her statement today, to specialist journalists. I am going to go through and find out every journalist who received a copy of that information and I am going to find out exactly how specialist those journalists are. If Senator Crowley released it to any other than very specialist journalists, I am going to be back here asking more questions about this.

I spoke to this girl's father this afternoon. I spoke to him this morning. I have spoken to him each day for a couple of days about this matter and he asked me to say in the Senate today that he wants Senator Crowley to have the decency to resign, to have the decency to accept that what she did totally breached any accepted standard of behaviour. He wants me—and I am happy to do so—to call on Senator Crowley right here and now to resign. The standard of conduct that she has shown is totally and utterly unacceptable. She is the Minister for Family Services, for heaven's sake! How can Senator Crowley continue as Minister for Family Services when this is the respect and the courtesy and the consideration that she gives to a grieving family? Senator Crowley has shown that she is totally insensitive to the feelings and privacy of this girl's family and totally and utterly incompetent.

If Senator Crowley had been competent, this material would never have been released in the first place. If Senator Crowley had been competent, she would have recognised that there was nothing in this material which added anything to the issue of whether or not this girl died of toxic shock syndrome.

Senator Gareth Evans, in his defence of Senator Crowley, has told the Senate that he believes Senator Crowley may have been motivated by a desire to show that there was an alternative explanation for the girl's death. In that case, I find it hard to understand why the three-page summary that Senator Crowley released on 13 March commenced with the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 November 1994, a 13-year-old Mount Isa student died while competing in a school swimming carnival. The cause of death recorded on the post mortem examination certificate dated 1 December 1994 is ventricular fibrillation due to or as a consequence of toxic shock syndrome.

If that was Senator Crowley's motivation, then I find no reason why that statement and that paragraph would have led to the three-page summary document that she released. Again, I reiterate that Senator Crowley's appalling conduct shows a total and utter absence of any standard of decency and I do not believe that Senator Crowley should remain as Minister for Family Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to read what was said in the Senate yesterday because the facts speak for themselves. Senator Gareth Evans, after Senator Vanstone had risen on a point of point of order, said:

SPEECH.PARA: On the point of order: Senator Crowley has responded to what was clearly a loaded question from Senator O'Chee with great dignity, great restraint, great sensitivity and great accuracy.
That is what you said yesterday, Senator Evans. You continued:
These are nonsensical points of order that have been made. Senator Crowley should be allowed to get on with giving what is a very clear, straightforward good and impressive answer.

The President then said, `It is just that.' I call into probity the President giving an opinion on an answer. The President is always saying that he is impartial and that he never casts an opinion as to which side he favours. He said, `It is just that.' To use Senator Evans's words, it is a `straightforward, good and impressive answer'. Senator Crowley then said:

What Senator Vanstone may not know and I certainly do is just how some of this material became public in Queensland. I was not prepared to put that on the public record, nor was I prepared to name this child. These things have not come from me.
She said yesterday, `These things have not come from me', yet this afternoon she told us that they did.

TALK.START.PARA: —The name of the kid did.
—Since Senator Evans has invited me, I will read from the rest of the Hansard. Senator Crowley later said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, Senator. I have told you the facts. You asked me whether a three-page report was given out. It had none of this information.
Senator Crowley said yesterday that it had none of this information.

PARA.TAB: This is not the first time that sliding over the truth has occurred. On 7 November last year, I asked Senator Crowley how much money the government had paid Professor Peter Baume at the school of community medicine since he left federal parliament. An answer of $13,000 was given on 10 February. I asked the supplementary question as to whether it also included other appointments. Through the estimates process, Senator Crowley said, `I was wrong last time. In fact, it was $488,000 plus air fares.' It was only because I picked it up. The difference between $13,000 and $488,000 was a mere slip of the tongue.

What concerns me most is that Senator Crowley thought that she got away it. Senator Gareth Evans should not wiggle his hand at me. I will speak as long as I want to in bringing out the attack and the truth of this matter. I want to draw an analogy between what Senator Crowley has done in misleading this Senate and what was done by Mr McLachlan in the other chamber. He resigned on noting that he had not seen a certain envelope that had some supposedly secret information on it. He resigned on that principle. The minister clearly said one thing yesterday and today has said another, admittedly with a drawn-out apology. She is still trying to say that what she said was correct when it clearly was not. There are double standards in this matter, and the minister should be drawn to account for them. It is not sufficient to just apologise. There are double standards throughout this government as exemplified by this minister. She must be drawn to account for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this issue because, like my colleagues, I am very concerned about what happened. I do not believe that the explanation of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) is adequate to explain why she would have released a nine-page document even to, as she said, specialist journalists. I presume she means by that those who write on medical issues. If she does not mean that, Senator O'Chee is quite right in examining whether they are specialist journalists. Obviously, from what Senator O'Chee has said, some of those journalists expressed concern about the contents of the TGA report.

PARA.TAB: Had the minister wanted to emphasise to the Australian community, and women in particular, that it was not necessarily the case that the tragic death of this young girl was attributed to toxic shock—that it was only suspected toxic shock and that there may have been an alternative explanation for her death—and wanted to back it up, there are a number of other ways that she could have done it. She could have sought assistance from some specialist gynaecologists or some other source or even from an independent extract. She could have asked the TGA to write yet another report which expunged the more sensitive and personal details from it to enable the journalists to then put the case that the death may have been due to some other reason.

Senator Crowley is very aware of my concerns about privacy, which I have expressed over and over again in this chamber, and of my constant questioning of bureaucrats about the need to maintain information in a way that does not release personal information about individuals. Here we have a minister who did not table the material here in the Senate; rather she gave the material to journalists. The family of this young girl found that offensive and they found that it invaded their daughter's privacy, in retrospect, and their privacy.

Minister, it really surprised me that you did not apologise on the spot yesterday. Minister Carmen Lawrence had the good sense and the good grace to apologise unreservedly, and she was not even responsible for it, apart from the fact that she is your senior minister. As Senator Vanstone said, you squirmed and wormed your way around. In fact, in your first answer to the question, you did not even indicate that you had given journalists a copy of the nine-page document. Senator Crowley indicated that she had given them a three-page document. The truth was squeezed out of her at the end of the answer to the supplementary question when she referred to that document, and that was the error.

I wonder whether the minister was not like Mrs Kelly. Maybe she looked only at the front of the document. Maybe she did not look any further, like Mrs Kelly with her environment booklet who said, `Well, I only endorsed the front.' Minister, when you release information like that, you need to be very careful. It was clear to whom that information referred. It referred to that young girl, although it did not have her name in it. I would have expected you, especially as a medical practitioner, to have been much more careful about the way in which you used that information. I would have expected you to resort to other methods and other measures to ensure that Australian women were informed that there was an alternative explanation and not start a mad panic about toxic shock syndrome, which is what I presume you were trying to do, but you did it in a very clumsy, very insensitive and very thoughtless way.

The minister compounded that insensitivity and thoughtlessness—she obviously does not want to listen to what I am saying because she is chatting to Senator Evans; obviously, this does not interest her—by failing to apologise in the Senate yesterday during question time. As Senator Vanstone said, she could have done it in her first answer to the question; she could have done it in the answer to the supplementary question; and she could have done it when members on this side were taking note of her answer. She had three chances. As Senator Abetz said, she had three opportunities. It was not until Carmen Lawrence crowed that she began to think that she had better do something about it. I believe she was dragooned into apologising, because I saw what was going on around here in the chamber last night. I think that is totally unacceptable behaviour.

Prime Minister Keating was demanding the resignation of our leader over the release of sensitive documents. That is just typical of Mr Keating. He has one standard for himself and his mates and another standard for the rest of Australia—in tax matters and everything else. Here he has one standard for our leader and our shadow minister and another standard for himself and his own minister.

I agree that, if Senator Crowley were to do the right thing, she would voluntarily stand down because she has shown great indiscretion, great insensitivity and great thoughtlessness. She failed to apologise as soon as it was pointed out to her that she had made a mistake. We can forgive people for making mistakes. All of us are going to make mistakes. But she would not apologise when she made that mistake. When it was pointed out to her that she had made a mistake, she did not have the grace or the wit—I am not sure which she needed; both—to apologise. I believe that is an error that warrants the greatest condemnation from the members of this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only two matters that I want to raise. The first is, bearing in mind that at least part of Senator Crowley's defence is that she supplied this material to specialist journalists in the public interest, I invite Senator Crowley to provide Senator Vanstone, before question time tomorrow, with a list of the specialist journalists to whom she provided that information, in order that we might also be able to make an assessment on that matter.

PARA.TAB: However, the other aspect I want to raise is not particularly directed to Senator Crowley but rather to the fact that this is yet another demonstration of the double standards of Prime Minister Keating. Picking up what Senator Herron introduced, in many ways there are parallels to the so-called McLachlan matter. I know Mr McLachlan resigned from the shadow ministry because he inadvertently mislead the House of Representatives. But he also was called upon by Prime Minister Keating, even while he was out of Australia, and by other ministers of this government who were in Australia, to resign because McLachlan, on their claim, by photocopying certain documents, had invaded the privacy of certain Aboriginal women. They said, `For the invasion of privacy alone, McLachlan must resign.'

In this instance there can be no doubt that there has been quite a shocking invasion of the privacy of this family, yet I have not heard anything from the Prime Minister in the form of a determination that Senator Crowley should stand down. This is the government that we heard last night talking about the way in which it stood up for privacy issues in condemning Senator Baume. But in this instance, of course, there is an alternative explanation that is satisfactory to the minister—and apparently it is because this invasion was deemed by the government to be in the public interest.

Let us hear the Prime Minister stand up and mount that defence. Otherwise, it must seem to anyone listening to this debate that in both instances there was invasion of privacy—on the Prime Minister's claim, Mr McLachlan invaded the privacy of certain Aboriginal women; and in this instance, Senator Crowley invaded the privacy of this family. If one standard applies to one, why shouldn't the same standard apply to the other? The Australian people are sick and tired of Mr Keating's double standards. They would like to see him provide an explanation for that obvious inconsistency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would make just a short statement. Senator Hill has taken the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to task, and that is a matter for comment and debate hereafter. I simply want to say a few words about Senator Crowley's position.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley has made a mistake. Everybody has said it is a mistake. She is being taken to task for not apologising as quickly as she might have. But she has sat here and accepted it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is called judgment, Barney.

—Senator Herron says that this is called judgment. I do not want it to be thought that there is no defence to be put for Senator Crowley in the context of what has been said here today, or that this side of the chamber does not support her—it does. But it has been her choice to cop what has been given to her.

PARA.TAB: I just have this to say: Senator Vanstone made a statement, poured a bucket—and I say that in a kind way. Something had to be said, given what Senator Crowley had done, and Senator Vanstone did it very effectively. But what happened then was that there was a series of people who followed Senator Vanstone. It is a question of when a fair tipping of the bucket turns into a political job being done on Senator Crowley. That is not a matter for me to decide; it is a matter for those listening to this debate to decide.But I emphasise again: Senator Crowley has made a mistake, she has apologised and she has copped what has been put to her. She has decided to sit where she is, rather than get up and reply to things that may have been put a bit loosely; she has let those things go through to the keeper. That has been her choice and it has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean she is not going to speak?

—No, she is not going to speak about this, and that is it. That is why I am saying what I am saying now. A lot of the things that were said were very rough indeed. She is willing to cop that in the spirit, hopefully, in which you intended it, Senator Vanstone. If it were to be replied to, people from this side would respond. I have explained to the people listening today Senator Crowley's position. I think she has acted in a most honourable fashion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fear that we are still on supplementary answers arising out of question time. There is one other matter I wanted to raise arising out of a question that was put to me by Senator Parer at question time about the Prime Minister's participation in the ITB tourism fair in Berlin. I am advised that the situation is as follows: the Prime Minister arrived in Berlin at 2.45 in the afternoon of 8 March. The ITB fair closed that day.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister flew directly from Hanover, where he had that morning opened the Australian exhibition, as I said, at CeBIT and had launched the Australia Abroad Council's Experience Australia 95 promotion at the Spaengle museum. The preceding day he had participated at the opening of the CeBIT fair itself in Hanover after flying from Bonn, where he had had discussions with President Herzog, Chancellor Kohl and Foreign Minister Kinkel. He also had a formal meeting with the Premier of Lower Saxony, Mr Shroeder. So there was no question of the Prime Minister having any spare time before he actually arrived in Berlin.

In preparing the program for the Prime Minister's visit to Germany, his office had made inquiries about his possible participation in the ITB in Berlin. But his department was advised by the Department of Tourism following consultation with the Australian Tourism Commission that because the ITB finished on the afternoon of his arrival, and exhibitors were starting to pack up, there was no point in the Prime Minister's attendance at that point. I hope that puts to sleep once and for all this little furphy that Senator Parer put into the public domain at question time today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the proposed use of RAAF Base Curtin as a detention centre for boat people.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take note of the answer given to me earlier today by Senator Bolkus in response to a question of mine which related to the minister's decision yesterday that the RAAF base at Curtin near Derby is to be activated for the purposes of being a detention centre for unauthorised boat people and his announcement that 171 people will be moved from Darwin and Christmas Island to that centre as soon as the facilities are ready, which it appears from the minister's statement yesterday will be in a few weeks time. The centre is to be activated over the next few weeks, to quote the minister.

PARA.TAB: I also want to thank the minister for his clarifying answer to my supplementary question today. I asked him, amongst other things, whether he would confirm or deny reports that the PRC government was now requesting payment by the Australian government of $20,000 for each person returned to China; that is, the Sino-Vietnamese people who arrived in Australia by boat late last year and early this year and for whom agreement has been reached with the Chinese government for their return to China. I asked him whether he would confirm or deny reports that the PRC government was now requesting payment of $20,000 for each person who was so returned.

I thank the minister for his answer clarifying that he was not aware of that. The report came to me from a source that I felt was of sufficient stature to warrant—in fact, require—me asking that question of the minister. I am glad that he has cleared that up, although I want to look in more detail at the fine print of his answer when that becomes available.

The minister did not really answer the main thrust of my initial question which was to the effect that it appears that the arrangements that the government of Australia has reached with the government of China for the return of the Sino-Vietnamese boat people may have stalled. In January I was told that the return of the approximately 700 people would commence in March. That has not occurred, and it does not appear that it will start to occur for some time yet. I think the minister, in his answer today, made that clear. If it were to start in the very near future, of course there would be no need to activate the Curtin base as a detention centre because space would be freed in Port Hedland, which is now at full capacity because of the Sino-Vietnamese people being there. That full capacity is about 750 to 770 people.

It appears that the arrangements between the two governments have been stalled. Certainly, these matters take time, as does all the detail that is required to be implemented and the consequential movement of people occurring. The department and, I think, the minister were quite confident in January, when they were advising the coalition on this matter—as a result of their advice the coalition helped expedite the bill which is to allow the return of these people to China—that there was to be a March start for the repatriation. That has not happened. There are a lot of questions that the minister needs to answer with respect to this: why has the delay occurred? How long will the delay be? What action is being taken to expedite the matter?

It is also incumbent on the minister to tell the Australian taxpayer how much the delay is costing. The cost of maintaining the detention centre at Port Hedland last year, when all costs were taken into account, was over $50 million. The minister is now talking about activating a new centre with a start-up cost of half a million dollars and monthly running costs of half a million dollars. A large amount of money is involved in this. The minister has an obligation to this chamber and to the Australian people to set the record straight and give us the details of just what is happening in this very important matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 and the Family Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1994. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the response.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney
Chairman
Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Com mittee
Parliament House
CANBERRA 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

I am writing in response to your Committee's report on the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 and the Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994. In order to provide the Government's response to you expeditiously, I now provide an interim response to the first part of the Committee's report, which deals with the Family Law Reform Bill 1994. The Government's response to the second part of the report, which deals with the Family Law Reform Bill (No 2) 1994, will be provided to you in the near future.

The Government welcomes the Committee's report, which is very supportive of the reforms to Part VII of the Family Law Act 1975. The reforms provide an entirely different approach to the relationship between parents and children of separated families by replacing the present anachronistic proprietorial concept of custody and access with the more enlightened concept of parental responsibilities for the care, welfare and development of children. This responsibility diminishes as the child becomes more mature and is able to accept greater responsibility for his or her decisions.

The Government also welcomes the Committee's support for the encouragement of the use of non-litigious dispute resolution mechanisms. The Government is committed to the extension of primary dispute resolution services of the highest quality and to ensuring that services are appropriate to both men and women. In relation to the concerns expressed to the Committee relating to professional standards and the confidentiality and secrecy provisions, the regulations will, as indicated in the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill, require disclosure by the mediator about the mediator's skills and qualifications to conduct mediation. The regulations will also make provision for instances where mediation is contra-indicated, such as a power imbalance between the parties which cannot be redressed, for example in cases of family violence. In addition, the Family Services Council is undertaking wide consultation on the development of agreed standards for mediators practising in government approved community based mediation services, and will be advising me on appropriate standards to be applied to these services.

I attach the Government's detailed response to each of the Committee's recommendations in relation to the Family Law Reform Bill 1994. I also advise that the Government will be moving a small number of amendments to the Bill in the Senate, to address matters of a minor policy, drafting and technical nature.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL LAVARCH

PARA.EMPHASIS: INTERIM GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT
THE FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 AND
BY THE SENATE LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL LEGISLATION COMMITTEE

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the provision now in the Bill which allows for the imprisonment of Registrars be deleted. (See proposed section 67P)

Response: The Government does not accept the recommendation. It notes however that the provision deals with the situation where a Registrar, or any other person who obtains the information because of its provision to the Registrar, discloses, intentionally or recklessly, to other than an authorised person information about the location of a child which has been obtained pursuant to an order of the court. In many cases, the child is living with a parent who has fled family violence, and information about the child's location has been disclosed to a Government department on the basis that it would be protected. Disclosure of the information may place that parent, the child, and others with whom they are living, at risk of harassment or violence.

The Family Law Council has recommended the imposition of the penalty. In its report `Power of the Family Court to Require the Provision of Information for the Recovery of Children' (September 1992) the Council endorsed my Department's proposal that a penalty, in the order of $12,000 or 2 years imprisonment or both, be imposed for the unauthorised disclosure of information obtained under the equivalent provision at the time (paragraphs 4.41-4.42). The Council's report noted acceptance of the proposal by the Family Court of WA, the NSW Bar Association and the Privacy Commissioner. In its Letter of Advice on the Operation of the (UK) Children Act 1989 (10 March 1994) the Council recommended that amendments to the Act in relation to obtaining information should "provide for a penalty for unauthorised disclosure" (p.19).

Consistent with other legislation, the Government believes that intentional or reckless disclosure of such sensitive information is completely unacceptable and should be the subject of a penalty including the possibility of imprisonment. Arguably, the Registrar would already be in breach of s.70 of the Crimes Act 1914 were information unlawfully disclosed and thus liable to a penalty of 2 years imprisonment. There is, however, a view that the Registrar may be exercising quasijudicial powers and therefore any disclosure not fall within s.70. This provision puts the position of the Registrar beyond doubt and covers disclosure by other persons. Should an intentional or reckless disclosure occur, the Crimes Act allows for a fine to be imposed in lieu of imprisonment, and imprisonment is only likely to be ordered for a most serious and intentional disclosure.

The Committee recommends that the 21 days now provided for in the Bill as the period during which a person is prevented from appealing against the decision of a Magistrates Court to interfere with a contact order made by the Family Court be reduced to 3 days. (See proposed subsection 68T(5) and paragraphs 1.29 and ff.)

Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation. The proposals in this division of Part VII of the Act were developed within the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to overcome the very real concerns being expressed by women that continued contact with a child of the relationship by a father who had engaged in family violence either against the mother and/or the children placed that mother and children in danger of further family violence. The proposals in this Bill, together with the complementary proposals in the State and Territory family violence legislation, are designed to provide a break in the chain of violence and enable a proper reconsideration by the Family Court of the desirability of continued contact between the perpetrator of the violence and the children.

In light of the Committee's recommendation the States and Territories have been consulted on the suggestion of reducing from 21 days to 3 days the barrier for bringing proceedings in the Family Court on a change to contact with the child ordered in family violence proceedings. The States are opposed to any such reduction.

It should be noted that the restriction on appeal applies only to a change to a contact order where the family violence order is an interim order. The change to the contact order only remains in force while the interim order is in force, or for a maximum of 21 days. The Committee's concern that the 21 day period would allow an unscrupulous parent having the residence of the child to effectively deny the other parent contact with the child for significant periods can be overcome by that contact parent challenging the interim family violence order in the court in which that interim order was granted. The barrier to appeal against the change to the contact order prevents there being 2 concurrent, urgent avenues of appeal against the interim family violence order and its attendant removal of contact.
The Committee recommends that the Family Court of Australia monitor parenting plans when filed in the Registry. The Court should make rules specifying the information required in the plan.

Response: The Government does not accept this recommendation. The Government notes that in the discussion that led to this recommendation the Committee referred to a capacity in the Family Court to scrutinise parenting plans lodged with it pursuant to s.63D.

The major thrust of the reforms is to allow parents greater opportunity for deciding what arrangements will be made in respect of their children and/or encouraging greater usage of non litigious dispute resolution mechanisms in settling arrangements where agreement cannot be reached. Provision for court scrutiny of such arrangements would defeat that approach. The Government notes that the Family Law Act currently provides for child agreements, which are registered with the court without any scrutiny.

The Government also considers it undesirable to require that particular information be in the agreement. If parents wish only to formalise particular aspects of their arrangements in an agreement, with more fluid aspects of shared responsibility left unspecified, it would add unnecessary complexity and expense to require them to include prescribed information. As with intact families, parents should have the flexibility to make whatever arrangements assist them in carrying out their responsibilities to their children without interference unless intervention is necessary to protect the children. The Bill contains such measures.

Should the court be asked to enforce any such agreement at a later time it could at that time examine the terms of the agreement and ensure that those terms are in the best interests of the child before making any enforcement order. If the terms of the agreement are deficient the court has powers available to it to make orders that are necessary in the child's best interest.
Subclause 63D(2) provides that the court may make Rules in relation to the registration of the agreements.
The Committee recommends, subject to Recommendations 1,2,3, that the Family Law Reform Bill 1994, as introduced, be enacted.
Response: The Government welcomes this support for the enactment of the legislation.

Senator Spindler in his additional report raised three areas which he considers merit further attention. In relation to the first, the Government considers that the appropriate balance between safeguarding the interests of children and assisting parents to reach agreements at low cost and without unnecessary intervention has been reached in relation to the scrutiny of consent orders and child agreements. In relation to the second, that of the balance to be achieved between family violence orders and contact orders, the Government considers that the agreement reached with the States and Territories will provide a significant improvement to the protection of families from family violence, whilst recognising the rights of children to continued contact with their parents, where this is appropriate.

Senator Spindler also expressed concern whether there were adequate safeguards for the provision of interpreters for court proceedings and, particularly, for mediation processes. The Government has funded the Family Court to provide interpreter services and the Court has policy guidelines on the use of interpreters which state that interpreters are available for all matters and that such services are free. The question of interpreter services outside the Court system will be considered in the context of developing a regime to apply to the approval of mediators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

PARA.EMPHASIS: AN ISLAND TIGER—REPORT OF AN UNOFFICIAL VISIT TO TAIWAN

Response to recommendation contained in paragraph 2.20 that the requirement for transit visas to be held by Taiwanese transit passengers be examined by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with a view to removing the requirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Nationals of certain countries listed at Part 3 of Schedule 9 to the Migration (1994) Regulations (Attachment A), are not required to hold a transit visa if transiting Australia for less than 8 hours provided they are en route to a third country and do not leave the airport transit lounge. Taiwan is not included in the list of countries at Part 3 of Schedule 9 to the Migration Regulations.
Historically, inclusion on the "concessionary list" of countries was governed by the following con siderations:
. Identification of certain countries as "low risk" ie, less likelihood of using the concession for easy access to overstay or work in Australia
. the need to foster Australia's foreign relations and ease restrictions as a gesture of goodwill eg, our bilateral relations with South Africa
. need to recognise Australia as a major transit point for tourists travelling within the South Pacific rim
. frequency of certain nationals needing to transit Australia for a significant proportion of their travel destinations eg, Papua New Guinea nationals.

The current concessionary list of countries was approved by the Minister in 1990. Certain countries were added to the list at that time because the Minister considered that the consequences for the integrity of the visa system did not outweigh the concerns expressed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade regarding potential harm to our relations particularly with the South Pacific and many nations in Asia.

Taiwan was not included in the list at that time largely because of concerns about the misuse of Taiwanese passports, more specifically, the use of fraudulently altered passports by non-Taiwanese nationals bound for the US and, to a lesser extent, the problems of adequate bona-fides checking in the absence of a post in Taipei.
DIEA corporate strategy provides for higher levels of visitor facilitation to support the Government's push for internationalisation of the Australian economy.
Under this strategy resources have been devoted to examining the methods, procedures and policies that affect visa issuance in all major visitor markets.
Taiwan, as one of the fastest growing tourist markets for Australia, has already been pinpointed as a market requiring higher visa issuance facilitation measures.

The concern relating to the inability to conduct adequate checking of transit passengers has been reduced after the opening of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office which works in conjunction with our office in Hong Kong.
DIEA has been considering recommending inclusion of Taiwan in the concessionary list as;
. Taiwan has recently implemented a new passport with upgraded security features—this will counter reservations which we have had about the integrity of the Taiwanese document.
. Taiwan is one of Australia's fastest growing tourist markets and the inclusion in the list will be seen as a positive step.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response to recommendation contained in paragraph 2.21 that the Customs Bureau issue customs declaration forms using traditional Chinese characters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Customs Service (Customs) has no objection in principle to the delegation's recommendation.

As part of Customs' overall access and equity obligations a review is being conducted of the methods by which information is made available to international travellers, particularly those of non-English speaking background.

Options being considered include the translation of the Travellers Statement (or Customs declaration) into a number of languages, including traditional Chinese characters. Other options are to make translations of the questions asked on the form available on international aircraft in a number of languages with the Travellers Statement itself remaining in the English language (and therefore able to be understood by Customs Officers).

Customs is aware of the increasing traffic from Taiwan and the need to use traditional Chinese characters for Taiwanese people. This will be a factor in deciding on the most effective way to ensure international travellers are made aware of Customs requirements when arriving in Australia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response to recommendation contained in paragraph 2.25 relating to inquiries into the overseas activities of Australian banks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer considers that an inquiry into the overseas operations of Australian banks is not warranted. The overseas activities of Australian banks are matters for the commercial judgement of individual banks. Decisions on whether to operate in particular Asian markets are taken by the bank's management in the context of the overall strategies for growth in the region and operating environment of Asian countries. Banks report on these activities to their shareholders in their Annual Reports. For these reasons, the Treasurer considers that such an inquiry would serve little purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues entitled The Child Support Scheme—an examination of the operation of the effectiveness of the scheme, and I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the response.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon. Roger Price MP
Chair
Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr Price

We refer to the report of the Committee's Inquiry into the Operation and Effectiveness of the Child Support Scheme which was tabled on 5 December 1994. The Government is pleased to note that the report acknowledges the success of the Child Support Scheme in improving the welfare of affected children and in changing community attitudes to the ongoing responsibilities of parents in separated families. The Government agrees that there is room for refining the Child Support Scheme, and thanks you for your contribution to improving its operation.

The Government remains committed to the principles of the Child Support Scheme and to improving the Scheme's operation. In developing a final response to the report the Government's primary concerns will be to ensure that the interests of the children affected by the Scheme are served and that the principles of the Scheme are upheld, particularly that parents share in the support of their children according to their capacity to pay. These were also two of the general principles that the Access to Justice Advisory Committee recommended should apply to child support as stated in its Report, Access to Justice: an Action Plan, May 1994.

Your report contains a large number of recommendations, many of which deal with sensitive issues and have budgetary implications. Accordingly, the Government will make a full response to your report at a later date, when all issues have been properly considered. Some recommendations have implications beyond the Child Support Scheme. We believe the Government should seek expert advice, both legal and technical, from bodies such as the Family Law Council and the Privacy Commissioner before making a final response to these recommendations. Your report is currently being considered to determine which recommendations are capable of early implementation.

A large number of your recommendations relate to the administration of the Scheme by the Child Support Agency (CSA). Over the last year the CSA has made substantial improvements in administration and a number of matters highlighted in your report are already well underway. They include improvements to staff training, to phone systems and correspondence, as well as the allocation of additional staff to tackle outstanding debt. The Child Support Registrar has moved quickly to address most of your remaining administrative recommendations. Attached is advice from the Registrar outlining action taken in response to a range of the recommendations in your report [Attachment A]. The Registrar has also made a commitment to introduce a Child Support Charter, and consultation with client groups has already begun on this exercise. The Government hopes to finalise the Child Support Charter in the second half of this year.

The Government has begun a detailed examination of the remaining recommendations of your report, including your suggested changes to the child support formula. These recommendations require careful consideration of complex equity and workforce incentive issues. They also require regard to the costs to be incurred by taxpayers if there is any redistribution of the costs of children to taxpayers through Social Security outlays. While that work has already begun, the Government does not expect to have formed a view on the best way to progress these issues until later this year.
We expect that most of the remaining recommendations requiring Government decision will be addressed in time for a final response to your report to be tabled in the first half of 1996.
Yours sincerely
GEORGE GEAR

Minute Paper
Response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues—Matters for the Child Support Registrar

Purpose: To provide advice outlining action the Child Support Agency (the Agency) has taken or proposes to take in relation to those recommendations that are within the responsibility of the Child Support Registrar and do not require Government decision.
BACKGROUND
The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues (the Committee) tabled its report concerning the operation and effectiveness of the Child Support Scheme (the Scheme) on 5 December 1994.

Many of the recommendations relate to the administration of the Scheme. Fifty three of these are within my statutory responsibility and can be addressed by the Agency without budgetary, legislative or policy implications, or decisions by other agencies. The improvement agenda already underway within the Agency combined with action taken in response to these recommendations will lead to significant improvements in the management and administration of the Scheme.

The remaining 110 recommendations will require careful consideration by the Government as they have budgetary, legislative or policy implications. Some of these recommendations concern the administration of the Scheme but, if adopted, would require additional resources or legislative changes. For example, there are recommendations relating to the process for review of decisions, the use of private collection agencies, system changes and community awareness campaigns which require further consultation before the Government can decide how best to respond to them. The Agency will continue to work closely with the Department of Social Security, the Attorney-General's Department and other interested parties to provide further advice on these remaining recommendations.

I have attached detailed advice on the 53 recommendations requiring my attention and the action the Agency has taken or intends to take in respect of each one. You may wish to release my advice at the time the Government makes its response to the Committee's report. I support the majority of these recommendations and, where the Agency is departing from the recommendations, I have endeavoured to address the Committee's underlying concerns.

In preparing this advice, the Agency has consulted with other agencies, client representatives and community organisations. In particular, I have consulted the Registrar's Advisory Panel and can report their general support for the approach the Agency has taken.
MAJOR ADMINISTRATION ISSUES ARISING FROM THE REPORT

The Committee's report identifies a number of areas relating to the administration of the Scheme that are of particular concern. These include the management of the Agency, the level of service we provide our clients and the effectiveness of our enforcement activities. Since I was appointed Registrar, my focus has been to ensure the Agency has strategies in place to improve its performance in these areas. There are positive signs that the Agency is making the right decisions in responding to the challenges identified through the Committee's inquiry. For example, in terms of debt collection, during the current financial year the Agency has collected more than $30 million of the total debt outstanding at 1 July 1994. In addition to the attached advice, I would like to provide some general comments on these issues.
Managing the Agency

I am committed to making sure the potential benefits of locating the Agency within the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) are maximised. Over the last 12 months, I have significantly strengthened the senior leadership team of the Agency and ensured that the ATO provides greater corporate support for the Agency. Service agreements specifying the level of support required from other areas of the ATO are being put in place.

The Agency is also preparing a business plan, in consultation with the Registrar's Advisory Panel, that will outline an improvement agenda that will carry the Agency through to the year 2000. Through this process the Agency will prioritise and provide firm timetables for the action identified in this advice. The business plan will incorporate the commitments I have made in this minute but go further to outline broader improvement strategies.
