A one year plan will be completed by May 1995 and a five year plan will be completed by July 1995. The plans will be available to the community through the Panel, thereby providing another avenue for accountability. These plans, of course, will be the subject of my annual report to the Parliament.

Through this investment in the management of the Agency we are already providing much greater guidance and support to our Branch offices, with a particular emphasis on achieving greater consistency of policy and practices throughout all our operations. Nevertheless, one of the major challenges that lies ahead for the Agency is to consistently implement national policies and procedures. Consequently, I have asked the staff of the Agency to make this one of the very highest priorities across all areas of our administration.
The Agency's relationship with its clients
The Agency has improved its client focus by:
establishing links with its clients through the Registrar's Advisory Panel and regional advisory groups and outreach activities
commencing research to better identify the information needs of clients and their level of satisfaction with services currently provided
undertaking a job and work design process to ensure that work practices are formed around the needs of clients
implementing a comprehensive training strategy focusing on improving technical skills and providing quality client service.

The Agency acknowledges that the way in which we deal with our clients remains a major challenge. The Agency's telephone service performance has dramatically improved and I believe the introduction of a national voice messaging service will enhance the level of service provided. However, the Agency's efforts to improve the quality of correspondence are yet to deliver their potential benefits. Furthermore, the Agency's client education strategy has had its successes but clearly needs to be better targeted to the needs of all our client groups, particularly people from non-English speaking backgrounds and non-custodial parents.

Some of the Committee's recommendations, such as the recommended code of staff conduct and client service standards will be progressed through a Child Support Charter. The Charter will go further by providing a consolidated statement of the rights and responsibilities of the Agency's clients. Extensive community input to the development of the Charter has been received following national newspaper advertising. A draft of the Charter is currently being developed and will be progressed through the Panel before being presented to you for Government approval in the second half of this year.
Debt collection

The Agency has put in place strategies which, combined with additional resources and the implementation of appropriate training programs, are expected to improve its debt collection performance. The ongoing increase in case numbers and the difficulty experienced by the Agency in collecting the full amount of many liabilities as they fall due, given the low income levels of many liable parents and the unwillingness of others to pay, means that managing the absolute level of debt will remain a major challenge.
COMPUTER SYSTEM SUPPORT FOR THE AGENCY

In addition to the issues identified by the Committee, there is another key area which has a significant impact on our ability to improve the administration of the Agency in the short term. Most if not all of our interactions with clients depend to some extent on the smooth operation of the Agency's computer system. Given the importance of the computer system, I would like to make the following comments.

The Committee has identified the need for consistency in the application, registration and collection process and pointed out the difficulty clients have in understanding the process. Similar concerns are raised in the context of the payment of child support. Processing delays also feature in the Committee's concerns about these issues.

While there is much the Agency can do to improve how it explains the collection and payment processes to clients, the Agency faces a major challenge in re-developing its computer system to ensure these processes meet the needs of the Agency's clients for accurate advice and timely action.

The computer system that underpins these processes needs substantial redevelopment and enhancement in order to cope with the work volume that now exists, and to support the level of service that clients properly expect. Significant improvements have been made to the accounting system but much remains to be done.

The Agency is currently developing an information technology improvement program, in tandem with our business planning process, to redevelop its computer system. This improvement program will identify improvements that can be made progressively over the next five years. This program is likely to have significant resource implications that will require Government consideration.
WHERE TO FROM HERE

My staff have taken a keen interest in the Committee's report and, through their input into this advice, have expressed a commitment to improving our relationship with our clients. A major priority for the management of the Agency will be to ensure that staff have the training and other support they need to successfully implement the improvement agenda.

Members of the Registrar's Advisory Panel have accepted my invitation to work closely with the Agency in the development of the Child Support Charter, our business plan, and in monitoring our progress in implementing our improvement agenda.

The Agency is well advanced in meeting the administrative challenges it faces. However, as the Committee acknowledged, the Agency deals with people at one of the most sensitive and traumatic points of their lives, that is, immediately following family breakdown. There will always be inherent tensions in the Scheme that make it difficult to meet the expectations of all our clients.

I am confident that the Agency's improvement agenda and the action outlined in the attached advice relating to the Committee's recommendations will go a long way to ensuring that the Agency collects a greater amount of the child support owing whilst taking account of the needs of all its clients.
(Michael Carmody)
CHILD SUPPORT REGISTRAR
14 March 1995
Attachment
Response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues
Child Support Scheme—an examination of the operation and effectiveness of the scheme
Matters for the Child Support Registrar
March 1995

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes, as a matter of priority, national policies and develops the necessary guidelines and manuals to ensure uniform practices are observed in all areas of Child Support Agency administration and in accordance with the child support legislation
The Agency supports this recommendation and had, prior to the report being tabled, set up a number of mechanisms to develop and implement consistent policies and procedures.

The Agency recognises that it must be consistent and fair in its dealings with all clients if it is to administer the Scheme in an effective and equitable manner. The Agency's Policy Development Unit was established in January 1993 to tackle this issue. This Unit promotes consistency in understanding and application of national policies and procedures by issuing discussion papers, policy guidelines, Child Support Determinations and Child Support Rulings. Matters requiring policy development are identified and prioritised by conducting regular surveys of Agency staff and external stakeholders. The process for developing policy documents is a consultative one involving the same internal and external stakeholders.

The Agency is monitoring the implementation of national policies and procedures to ensure they are applied consistently. To support this process, the Agency has established regional structures to identify inconsistencies in practices. A Deputy Registrar in each region has responsibility for child support matters in his or her region. A regional executive forum consisting of the regional Deputy Registrar, branch office directors and a staff association representative meets regularly. One of their responsibilities is to ensure that policies and procedures are applied consistently in the region and to take remedial action where this is not happening.
The Agency also holds national conferences involving all branch office directors. One role of these conferences is to contribute to consistency of practice and procedure.

All staff now participate in a legislative training program which is conducted co-operatively across each region to improve consistency in understanding and applying the legislation. This also promotes consistency in procedures across the Branches.

One factor critical in promoting consistency is the level of staff access to policy and procedural information. To improve the level of support provided to staff, the Agency is currently examining the possibility of using electronic document folders to provide staff with easy and consistent access to Agency policies and procedures.
The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts due under default assessments be included in the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate
The Agency has included debts due under default assessments in the calculation of its collection rate since 1 July 1994. No further action is required in relation to this recommendation.

The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts paid pursuant to private collection cases registered with the Child Support Agency be excluded from the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate
The Agency has never included these debts in calculating its collection rate. No further action is required in relation to this recommendation.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes a nationally co-ordinated approach to identify, assess and introduce as revised national practice, administrative improvements from local branch office initiatives and from best practice in the public and private sector
The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to implement it.

The Agency has established a Business Improvement Unit to coordinate the Agency's approach to developing best practices for national implementation. As part of an ongoing program, all branch offices of the Agency were asked in December 1994 to share improvement initiatives/best practices by providing details to the Business Improvement Unit. That unit will disseminate information about these best practices to other branch offices. Initially, branch office directors will be regularly contacted to identify best practices.

Improvement initiatives will be assessed as part of a process of continuous improvement within the Agency and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) as a whole. The outcome of this process will be the development of national best practices.

In relation to public/private sector best practices, the Agency has embarked on a long term, systematic and integrated process of continuous performance improvement consistent with a general move within the ATO. Input to the Agency's continuous improvement process has come from experienced practitioners in the ATO, the ATO Continuous Improvement Team, and from leading organisations in both the public and private sectors.

Employees are often the best source of suggestions for positive change. They are in the best position to know what is going wrong and frequently know how to improve the work system. Through a national health and productivity program, staff are encouraged to identify workplace barriers to administrative efficiency and effective service to clients. An action plan is then implemented to resolve identified issues at national, regional and local levels. The program embodies continuous improvement and Industrial Democracy principles and promotes staff health and productivity.

In addition to this national approach, a regional Deputy Registrar has been appointed in each administrative region to work with the branch office directors in these regions to identify best practices regionally. These best practices are then presented to the CSA Executive and consideration is given to national implementation.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:

PARA.TAB: (a) ensures that training has an appropriate focus on client service;
(b) evaluates the effectiveness of the training provided by measuring the transference of skills learnt by staff into the workplace;
(c) introduces a national program for validating and accrediting all training material and training received by staff of the Agency;
(d) adopts progressive and innovative approaches to training and abandons the Child Support Agency's reliance upon `in house' and `on the job' training; and
(e) recruits more staff with experience and qualifications in client service oriented disciplines to assist in changing the current predominantly tax and finance oriented staff culture

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency has acted to implement parts of this recommendation.

The Agency's National Training Unit is responsible for identifying training needs, setting priorities, developing appropriate training strategies and coordinating the development and presentation of training. This Unit has undertaken an extensive planning process to identify immediate training needs and priorities and, as a result, is concentrating on training in the following areas:

1.Technical training—the CSA Tech 1-2-3 program is a comprehensive program covering all aspects of the child support legislation and related legislation. CSA Tech 1-2-3 is aimed to ensure the provision of accurate and consistent technical advice

2.Client service training (incorporating the Client Contact Skills program)—all Agency training should focus on being sensitive to clients' needs and staff will have access to training and resources capable of providing the interpersonal skills to confidently impart technical advice

3.Arrears and compliance training—is focused on constructive client contact through improved understanding of the law. This will enable a consistent approach to assessments and provides technical skills for debt collection. This training will be incorporated into CSA Tech 1-2-3.
Paragraph (a)—ensure that training has an appropriate focus on client service
The Agency's National Training Strategy, released on 15 August 1994, contains the following statement in relation to the client service focus in all areas of training:

`Agency National Training will initially focus on front-line staff, to achieve the earliest and best responsiveness to client needs. Front-line staff have the most direct contact with our community. Their performance strongly influences the quality of service delivered. Staff interactions with clients should leave a lasting perception of ease and competence with which the Agency can act on their behalf and resolve their difficulties.'
The principle in this statement is built into the design of all training products produced and cleared by the National Training Unit.

The Client Contact Skills program is a specific program aimed at improving the client contact skills of Agency staff. The pilot of the program was completed in February 1995 and all Agency staff who have direct contact with clients will undertake the program by 31 December 1995.
Paragraph (b)—evaluate the effectiveness of the training provided by measuring the transference of skills learnt by staff into the workplace

The effectiveness of all national training is tested before national implementation. The National Training Unit also provides support to branch offices to allow for evaluation of training provided locally.
The effectiveness of all national training in transferring skills into the workplace will be evaluated. For example, the effectiveness of the CSA Tech 1-2-3 program will be evaluated in three phases
participant knowledge will be assessed at the end of each module
an evaluation of Trainer Training and the design principles will take place when all modules are released
evaluation of the transfer of learning and changed behaviour will be conducted when all branches have delivered the training and there has been time for changes to happen.
Paragraph (c)—introduce a national program for validating and accrediting all training material and training received by staff of the Agency

All national training programs are piloted and tested before being formally introduced. This allows the Agency to detect any deficiencies in the package and make sure that the best possible product is ultimately presented.

As Agency staff are also employed by the ATO, they have the opportunity to participate in the Taxation Officer Development (TOD) program. Steps have been taken to integrate child support specific topics into the TOD program. For example, Agency staff who complete certain CSA training courses can gain credit towards completion of the TOD program. The TOD program has been formally accredited.
Paragraph (d)—adopt progressive and innovative approaches to training and abandon the Agency's reliance upon "in house" and "on the job" training

The Agency's training strategy recognises that it is necessary to have a mixture of in-house and external resources. The Agency does not rely exclusively on in-house training but will use its own expertise where appropriate. It is important to use the best source of information, knowledge and skills in developing training materials. The Agency will strive to use the best available resource wherever that may be located.

For example, in developing materials specifically dealing with child support legislation or procedures, the Agency is confident that the most appropriate source of information is available internally. However, if the required knowledge or skills are not available within the organisation, the Agency will engage external consultants. For example, a consultant was engaged to develop the Client Contact Skills package which is currently being piloted. The Agency may also choose to use subject matter experts from other areas of the ATO where they can provide the best available resource.

The Agency has also developed source materials which can be used in a variety of ways. This allows for the same material to be used for self-paced learning, in workshops involving small groups of people or in more formal classroom training sessions depending upon the needs of particular staff members.

On the job training can be a valuable way of reinforcing knowledge and skills first learnt in more formal training. In some cases, on the job training is the most effective way in which a particular training need can be met.
Paragraph (e)—recruit more staff with experience and qualifications in client service oriented disciplines to assist in changing the current predominantly tax and finance oriented staff culture

The Agency has, as part of an industrial agreement under enterprise bargaining, undergone a Blueprint process, in which it has examined its current branch office structures to standardise those structures and work practices. Following on from this process, the Agency is currently working on an extensive work and job design process. All jobs in the Agency will be examined to define the duties to be performed and a general description of the job. In that process, the Agency is looking at the skills required as well as the skills that can be developed by working in the Agency. There will be an enhanced emphasis on client contact skills. This will allow the Agency to attract people with these skills, or who have the potential to develop those skills, to work in the Agency. The criteria used for selection for positions within the Agency will then be redeveloped around these duty statements and job descriptions. This will ensure an appropriate emphasis on client service skills in selection processes.

The Agency is committed to recruiting staff with the skills identified through the Blueprint process. As a major part of the Agency's work involves debt collection, it is important to have staff with an appropriate mix of client service and debt collection skills.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces dedicated case officers, with assigned responsibility and accountability for individual clients

The Agency is moving towards client based multi-function teams each with their own identifiable group of clients, with a combined team client ownership and individual case management approach. The Agency does not intend to introduce dedicated case officers with assigned responsibility and accountability for the bulk of its individual clients as this would not be an efficient use of its limited resources. Members of the Registrar's Advisory Panel and regional advisory groups recognised this and supported the Agency's approach.
As part of the Blueprint process, the Agency considered a number of models for case management and came to the following conclusions:
1.Case ownership will provide clients with better service and will improve compliance only if targeted correctly and supported by an appropriate infrastructure.
2.This arrangement should be team based with provision for client ownership to rest with individual staff within each team for specific and current issue management.

3.The introduction of individual case ownership should be seen as an enhancement rather than a solution. It should be a longer term goal for consideration after more systemic issues have been addressed and a period of consolidation has occurred.

The proposed approach will provide responsive and robust client service where all members of the team are available to attend to their clients' needs as they arise. The service will not be dependant on the availability of an individual case officer. The team will have a richer pool of knowledge and experience with greater capacity to deal with a range of issues than one individual may have, and the capacity for individual case management is available as problems or issues arise.

As the needs of individual clients can be diverse, each multi-function team will be able to provide most of the services their clients require from within the team. The remainder will be undertaken within a specialist team whose functions need to be performed separately for reasons of specialisation and accountability. The Agency has recognised the need to address issues of quality service and clear lines of responsibility and accountability. These issues have been given high priority throughout the Blueprint process.

A team based approach also offers the Agency the flexibility to adjust staffing arrangements as the need arises without significantly disrupting client/staff relationships, as would be the case with individual client ownership.
The team based approach to case management will be developed further and implemented consistently in all branches during 1995 through a process of work and job design.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces a reference number system to ensure accountability for the advice given to clients and to enable follow up on commitments and the provision of feedback to clients

The Agency agrees that it needs to ensure that its staff are accountable for advice given to clients. The Agency believes that this recommendation would not be necessary if the current procedures for recording advice and commitments are followed.

The Agency has an internal system for recording details of advice and commitments given to clients by telephone, in person or in writing. Under the ATO's Agency Agreement, Agency staff have agreed to identify themselves to clients. These two measures will ensure that staff are accountable for advice and commitments they give. The Agency acknowledges that advice and commitments are not always properly recorded. In light of the concerns raised by the Committee, the Agency undertakes to improve the consistency of recording advice and commitments.
This commitment will be supported by the Client Contact Skills program, the Child Support Charter and the move towards team based case management.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency, as a matter of urgency, develops national guidelines for the identification and administration of cases where there is a history or risk of domestic violence and/or child abuse
The Agency supports this recommendation and has commenced work on these guidelines.

The Agency's Policy Development Unit is preparing guidelines for the administration of cases involving domestic violence or child abuse. The Agency is consulting a wide range of external stakeholders including client representatives, community groups, legal services and other agencies such as the Department of Social Security, the Attorney-General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner in preparing these guidelines. A draft guideline is expected by 30 April, with a final guideline in place by 31 July 1995.

The Joint Committee recommends that within 6 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency conducts a study of the information needs of its clients and identifies shortfalls in current representation

The Agency agrees that the identification of its clients' information needs is a priority. In order to be able to identify these needs, the Agency will need a specifically designed process to explore the most effective way of providing information to a diverse client population. In preparation, the Agency has started collecting and analysing data from a number of sources.

In March 1995, the Agency commenced a client survey aimed at establishing the level of satisfaction with services currently provided by the Agency. An integral part of this survey is the establishment of some base data for age, education levels, ethnicity and socio economic backgrounds of the Agency's clients. Information is also being drawn from the Agency's Client Relations Officers in each branch through their work with diverse client groups and a range of community organisations. A client profiling project, which is currently underway, will provide information on sources of income of clients.

In conjunction with the above research, the Agency will also commence a research project looking at the specific information needs of some of the key client groups. Research undertaken to date has indicated that specific client groups have a poor understanding of their rights and obligations. Advice from the external advisory panels has also supported this view.

As a first step in this research program, the Agency will be looking at the information needs of clients from non-English speaking backgrounds and the non custodial parent groups. Part of this research program will include research undertaken in the 1994-95 year on current and potential clients from non-English speaking backgrounds or who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people.

The Joint Committee recommends that within 12 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency reports to the Assistant Treasurer on the costs and benefits, including savings to community organisations, of introducing an advisory function to meet the information needs of its clients. This is to include:
(a)a nationally co-ordinated `outreach' program targeted to the information needs of Child Support Agency clients, especially those clients in remote locations;
(b)making greater use of the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network by establishing full time Child Support Agency advisory staff in these offices; and
(c)making advisory staff available on a short term, permanent or rostered basis in remote locations in community legal aid, the Department of Social Security or other offices

The Agency supports paragraph (a) of this recommendation and has begun to implement it. There are some difficulties with implementing paragraph (b) as recommended and the Agency plans to consider these difficulties. Recommendation 19(c) requires further consultation with the Department of Social Security and other relevant government and non-government agencies
Paragraph (a)—a nationally coordinated "outreach" program targeted to the information needs of Agency clients, especially those clients in remote locations

A Client Relations Officer has been appointed in each branch office. These officers are working under national direction to develop and conduct a nationally coordinated outreach program targeted to the information needs of Agency clients through community based organisations.

Local outreach programs are currently being implemented by branch offices. These programs focus on general information about the Agency which the broader community may need and frequently takes the form of public information sessions.
Some branches of the Agency have very recently set up local arrangements with community organisations in their area. For example:
the Dandenong branch has been working with the Springvale Legal Service/Springvale Community Aid and Advice Bureau
the Brisbane branch has, in conjunction with staff placements in the Toowoomba regional office of the ATO, been working with community and professional groups in the Toowoomba region
the Pulteney branch has begun investigating the possibility of working with community groups around the cities of the Spencer Gulf

the Northbridge branch has commenced liaison with the Aboriginal Legal Services of Western Australia and associated community groups to identify specific needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients in Western Australia, in particular those in remote areas.

The Agency will be evaluating these initiatives as they develop within the national program. This evaluation will start in June 1996. As these initiatives are new it is necessary for a reasonable period to elapse to enable an effective evaluation.
Paragraph (b)—making greater use of the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network by establishing full time Agency advisory staff in these offices

Where there is an identified need, a number of branches have been sending staff to regional offices in their areas. The experience in these offices will be evaluated in 1995 to assess the extent to which a nationally coordinated approach to using ATO regional offices is appropriate.

There are some concerns about placing full time Agency staff within the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network. Some concerns relate to security, as staff in remote locations would be isolated and identified within that community as Agency staff, at potential personal risk. The Agency believes that the objective of providing a more accessible client service in remote locations can be achieved through the wider use of well planned and well publicised short term and rostered staff placements.
Paragraph (c)—making advisory staff available on a short term, permanent or rostered basis in remote locations in community legal aid, the Department of Social Security or other offices

The Agency will need to consult further with the Department of Social Security (DSS) and other relevant agencies before providing advice on this recommendation. The Agency will also have to consider in which offices other than the DSS it would be appropriate to place Agency staff and the practicalities of those placements. For example, the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia has advised the Agency that it may be appropriate to involve Migrant Resource Centres.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops in consultation with its clients, a code of conduct and service standards for Child Support Agency staff and ensures all Child Support Agency clients are aware of the standards of conduct and service which have been set

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces administrative procedures to ensure that clients not receiving the set standard of service have redress to higher levels of management and informs all clients of the process and procedures required to pursue complaints about conduct and service delivery
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops administrative mechanisms to monitor client complaints and solve the deficiencies in conduct and service delivery
The Agency supports recommendations 20, 21 and 22 and has begun to implement them.

On 5 December 1994, the Child Support Registrar announced his commitment to the development of a Child Support Charter. The Child Support Charter will incorporate standards of conduct and service and will set out the rights and responsibilities of the Agency's clients. The Agency, as part of the ATO, is bound by the ATO's Agency Agreement. That Agreement establishes a number of client contact principles which will also be embodied in the Child Support Charter.

The Child Support Charter will clearly set out the standards of service to which the Agency's clients are entitled and explain rights of redress where those standards are not met. To complement the Child Support Charter, the Agency will put in place an appropriate problem resolution mechanism. Principles embodied in the Child Support Charter will be included in training material and policy documents.

The Child Support Charter is being developed with wide community consultation. Submissions have been sought externally through all major national and regional newspapers as well as through the members of the Agency's Advisory Panels. Agency and other ATO staff have also been encouraged to have input into the development of the Child Support Charter. A draft Child Support Charter will be developed using this input through a workshop process and will then be refined further with additional consultation.
The Agency expects the final draft of the Child Support Charter to be presented to Government for approval early in the 1995/96 financial year.

The Agency expects that delivery of the Client Contact Skills program to all staff will reduce the number of complaints about service conduct and delivery, and the Child Support Charter will provide clients with an enhanced understanding of their rights and responsibilities in their relationship with the Agency.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops communication strategies, targeted at the various groups of Child Support Agency clients, to inform them of their rights and obligations under child support legislation and Child Support Agency administrative practices which may materially affect each group of clients
To ensure Agency clients are aware of their rights and responsibilities the Agency will commence a client education program targeted to meet the specific needs of all Agency clients.
The Agency will adopt a three-stage approach to the client education program—research, implementation and evaluation. The research phase has already commenced (see recommendation 18).
The client education program has several key components including:
specific information on the Agency's administrative practices and policies (for example, information on the Agency's policy for crediting non-agency payments)
targeted information for key client groups (for example, information targeted to the needs of clients from non-English speaking backgrounds and liable parents).

These and other strategies for the client education program will be developed in consultation with members of the Agency's advisory panels and staff. The program will link into the Agency's outreach activities.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency in consultation with the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education develop a resource package on child support and other legal responsibilities to be used by the Child Support Agency, marriage education bodies and other relationship programs

While the report recognises the work already done by the Agency to educate potential clients through a number of programs, recommendation 24 focuses on the provision of child support information to people entering new relationships.

The Agency will explore a range of options for developing a resource package for use in relationship programs (including premarriage and counselling programs). The Agency will also discuss these options with a range of interested groups including the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education.
The Agency has commenced discussions with Legal Aid and Family Service (LAFS) in the Attorney-General's Department, regarding the inclusion of child support information in their premarriage programs.

The Joint Committee recommends that an independent consultant be engaged to work with the Child Support Agency to realign management and service to the needs of clients and develop strategies aimed at achieving best practice

The Agency has already taken action to realign management and service to the needs of clients by opening up its administration to greater community involvement and developing management approaches and work practices designed to meet client needs.

To increase community involvement, the Registrar established the Registrar's Advisory Panel and regional advisory panels. These panels consist of representatives of a range of client groups, other government agencies and community organisations. Their purpose is to provide advice to the Registrar and the regional Deputy Registrars on the administration of the Scheme and to consider proposals to improve that administration. This process assists the Agency to develop practices that meet the needs of its clients and address issues of concern to the community. These groups are involved in the Agency's business planning process and the development of the Child Support Charter.

The Agency is currently undertaking a job and work design process to ensure that work practices are aligned with the needs of clients. This includes the introduction of client based teams as discussed at recommendation 13.
The Agency has put in place substantial mechanisms to deal with the change and improvement programs currently in progress as well as to manage day to day administration issues. These are:
a new senior management team consisting of a Second Commissioner with responsibility for child support and two Assistant Commissioners

one Deputy Child Support Registrar in each administrative region (New South Wales, Victoria/Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia/South Australia) has been given responsibility for child support matters within that region

the CSA Executive consisting of the Second Commissioner, the two Assistant Commissioners, the four Deputy Child Support Registrars with regional responsibility for child support and representatives from the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU)
the Business Improvement Project Co-ordination committee which is responsible for coordinating improvements and change projects nationally.

The Agency believes these measures, together with the business planning process currently underway, will better align management and service to client needs. The Agency believes it can benefit from external expertise and has already engaged a number of consultants to assist in developing strategies for a range of activities. For example, the Agency has engaged consultants to assist in:
the business planning process
planning an information technology improvement program
developing a Client Contact Skills program
market testing
client satisfaction survey.
Through these approaches, supported by the Agency's nationally coordinated continuous improvement process, the Agency is developing strategies aimed at achieving best practice.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency examines the management practices and operational standards applied to telephone communications in leading commercial operations in order to improve the management of the Child Support Agency's telephone enquiry service to clients
The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to improve its telephone performance.

The Agency conducted a national Telephone Project in early 1994 which, as part of its activities, investigated how other organisations managed their telephone enquiry workload. This investigation included the Department of Social Security and research findings from the Incoming Calls Management Institute in Maryland USA.

The Agency has achieved significant improvements in its performance in this area. In May 1994, the Agency decided, as a short term measure, to allocate 10% of all staff to telephone enquiry work in each branch in recognition of the need to provide better service to clients. Since then, the Agency has improved its telephone technology and has made better use of the management information systems which accompany that technology.
The ATO and the Agency are currently working towards having compatible telephone systems to allow calls to be managed on a regional basis from July 1996.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency sets up a separate general inquiry number so that simple and routine telephone enquiries can be handled promptly and effectively
The Agency supports this recommendation in principle.

In an effort to provide a better range of telephone services, the Agency is introducing a voice messaging service called the CSA Info Service. Once this has been fully implemented, there will be two enquiry numbers available to most clients
the general enquiry number which exists now which includes the facility for transfer to the team handling a particular case
the CSA Info Service number which will initially handle basic general enquiries relating to payment and account information and provide general information about the Scheme.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces on a national basis the voice messaging telephone service
The Agency supports this recommendation and has commenced implementation.

The phased national introduction of a voice messaging service, known as the CSA Info Service, will commence in April 1995. The CSA Info Service will provide specific accounting information to clients using a unique personal identification number.
General information about the Scheme will also be available to those clients who require it.

The CSA Info Service will not replace the Agency's general enquiry service. However, by allowing clients to quickly access basic information, it is expected to free up enquiry officers to provide a better service for these callers who require more detailed information. In time, the CSA Info Service could be further developed to provide a greater range of information.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency requires staff to identify themselves to clients unless staff believe their safety to be at risk
As part of the ATO's Agency Agreement, Agency staff have agreed to be covered by a number of client contact principles. The Agency Agreement states:

`55.3 The ATO expects that employees will provide their names when dealing with the public. Where an employee has an honestly held concern for their personal safety which could arise from them identifying themselves, the employee and the manager will jointly determine an alternative form of identification for the employee. Where this occurs, internal systems will be developed to ensure accountability and identification of the employee.'

The Agency is committed to implementing this recommendation. The proposed arrangements to give effect to this recommendation will be developed further and implemented as part of the development of the Child Support Charter which will outline some client contact principles including identification.
This issue will also be addressed in the Client Contact Skills program which is currently being piloted.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency re-writes computer generated correspondence to provide clients with the information they require in a clear, concise and user friendly fashion
The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to implement it.
The Agency has started to review all its computer generated correspondence. It has already reviewed its pre-acceptance letter and will look next at the most commonly used computer generated letters.

Whilst this review will improve computer generated letters to some extent, a long term solution will require major system changes. To this end, the Agency is developing an Information Technology improvement program.
The Joint Committee recommends that where clients raise specific issues the Child Support Agency responds on an individual basis and avoids the use of a computer generated response
The Agency recognises the need to avoid universal use of computer generated letters but believes they are appropriate in many cases.

The Agency acknowledges that uniquely drafted letters will often be more appropriate than the computer generated letters which are currently available. However, in many cases it will still be appropriate and more efficient to use computer generated letters. Some of the problems associated with using these letters will be reduced as their quality improves (see recommendation 32).
The Agency will examine the training needs of staff in effective business letter writing as part of its national training strategy.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Australian Taxation Office advertises in Tax Pack and on individual income tax return forms that information provided in tax returns may be
used by the Child Support Agency to assess liability for child support
The Agency supports the recommendation. The ATO has agreed to notify clients through Tax Pack 1995/96 about use of taxation information for child support purposes.

The Agency agrees that it is important that clients and the wider community are aware that the Agency has the authority to access taxation information and that it advises clients of purposes for which information may be used.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews and amends procedures for contacting clients and responding to client enquiries to prevent the unauthorised disclosure of personal information
The Joint Committee recommends that Child Support Agency staff be trained in the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988
The Agency supports these two recommendations and had, before the report was tabled, taken action to implement them.
The Agency acknowledges the Committee's concerns. The Agency treats its clients' privacy seriously and has already taken steps to prevent such breaches recurring.

The Agency issued a guideline to all staff in March 1994 dealing with Proof of Identity, Privacy and Secrecy. This guideline outlines the application of the secrecy provisions in the child support legislation, the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988 and establishes a procedure which staff must follow in establishing the identity of a person making an enquiry. It also describes what a client needs to do to authorise someone to act on his or her behalf so that the Agency is satisfied that a person making an enquiry does, in fact, have the authority to do so.

The requirements of the Privacy Act 1988 and its implications for collecting, storing, using and disclosing information are covered in detail in the CSA Tech 1-2-3 training program which is currently being implemented (see recommendation 11). The course material includes case studies to make the material relevant to actual Agency experience.
The Agency has accepted an offer from the Privacy Commissioner to provide advice on the content of privacy training developed by the Agency.

In addition, the Agency has introduced enhancements to its computer system to provide additional security measures. The Agency will also review its procedures for contacting employers to minimise the potential for breaches of privacy.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews its registration procedures to ensure that it registers court orders and court registered agreements correctly and does not register applications for court orders
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency revises its training programs in order to improve the ability of staff to interpret correctly court orders
The Agency supports these two recommendations and has already taken some action to address them.

The Agency acknowledges that some of the problems relating to interpretation and implementation of court orders arise due to a lack of understanding by Agency staff as to the effect of particular clauses in court orders. However, problems also arise from ambiguous or ineffective orders being made by the courts and sought by legal practitioners. The Agency is currently working with the legal profession to improve the quality of court orders by developing model orders and disseminating these with supporting information through professional associations.

The Agency issued a discussion paper in October 1994 dealing with interpretation of court orders. The paper refers to the difficulties encountered by staff in the interpretation of court orders which contain terms and expressions capable of subjective interpretation and provides a guide to interpretation of some of the most frequent areas of difficulty. The aims of the discussion paper are to improve consistency of interpretation across branches and to assist in the correct registration of court orders and court registered agreements. In response to comments received on the discussion paper, the Agency will develop a ruling aimed at achieving consistency of interpretation of those types of clauses. The Agency will issue a draft of this ruling by July 1995.
The interpretation of court orders is covered extensively in the CSA Tech 1-2-3 technical training program and will also be included in the induction training program for new starters.

The Agency expects that a combination of an increase in staff's skills in interpretation of court orders and standardisation of the wording of court orders will result in the correct interpretation and registration of all court orders.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency complies with the statutory requirements of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and allows prospective liable parents the statutory time to exercise their rights under the Acts

The Agency already complies with these requirements. The recommendation appears to be based on the Committee's misunderstanding of the Agency's current practices. The Agency's current administrative practice is consistent with the statutory requirements of the Acts which allow the Agency to collect an assessed liability whether or not an application has been made under section 107.

The Committee was concerned that a person who is notified of the Registrar's decision to accept an application for administrative assessment is not given the correct amount of time to appeal against that decision. The Committee's concern stems from the fact that the Agency issues a letter to prospective liable parents before making a decision on an assessment application (referred to as a "pre-acceptance letter"). The purpose of this letter is to inform the person named as liable parent that the application has been received and to explain what action the Agency will be taking to process it. The letter also contains a schedule indicating the amount of child support which may be payable.

This pre-acceptance letter is issued as part of the general process of administering the Scheme and not because there is a legislative requirement to do so. The letter is sent as a client service and its use has been supported by the Ombudsman.

Once an application is formally accepted, the Registrar issues a notice under section 34 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 advising the liable parent of that decision. The liable parent can apply for a declaration under section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the application should not have been accepted. The time limit for applying for such a declaration starts to run from service of the notice under section 34. It does not run from the time the pre-acceptance letter is sent.

The Committee stated that, because the notice under section 34 is not issued until, on average, 19 days after the pre-acceptance letter, the liable parent has lost over half of the time in which a declaration can be sought. For the reasons explained above, this is incorrect.

Subsection 107(2) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 states that an application to the court to dispute the Registrar's decision to accept or reject an application for assessment must be made within the time prescribed by the Rules of Court or within such further time as is allowed. The Family Court Rules (Rule 10—Application for Declaration under subsection 106(1) or 107(1) of the Assessment Act) states that an application shall be filed not later than one month after the receipt by the applicant of the notice given under section 33 or 34 of the Act, or within such further time as the court allows. It is up to the court to determine whether or not an application under one of these sections has been made within the prescribed time limit. The Agency has no part in making this decision.

Section 109 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 states that the fact that a proceeding is pending under section 107 does not interfere with or affect any administrative assessment, and that any such assessment may be registered and amounts recovered as if no proceeding were pending.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency includes the following information in the notice issued under section 34 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989:
(a)advice on what further correspondence parties will receive; and
(b)advice on making acceptable private child support collection arrangements

The Agency agrees that it needs to help clients develop a better understanding of what their future dealings with the Agency may be. However, the notice of assessment may not be the best place to include this information. It will be difficult to provide a meaningful list of correspondence the parties are likely to receive as this depends on their individual circumstances and the range of transactions which may occur in their case. The most effective way of providing information about likely future dealings with the Agency will be examined as part of the targeted client education program described at recommendation 23.
Paragraph (b) requires further consultation with the Department of Social Security to ensure clients receive consistent advice.

The Joint Committee recommends that notices of formula assessment issued under section 76 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 must clearly advise both parents that the Child Support Registrar has powers under section 75 of the Act to correct factual errors and false or misleading statements in a formula assessment

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops a national guideline on the use of the Child Support Registrar's power under section 75 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989

The Agency agrees that it needs to inform clients of the Registrar's ability to correct factual and clerical errors. The Agency is currently undertaking a study into how best to provide this information. The issue is being considered as part of the Agency's review of computer generated letters and also as part of a client education campaign.
The use of the Registrar's discretion under section 75 is also covered in the CSA Tech 1-2-3 training program.

A Child Support Ruling on the exercise of the Registrar's discretion under section 75 is being prepared and is being treated as a high priority. The first step in this process will be the issue of a discussion paper in March 1995. The Agency expects that a final ruling will issue by September 1995.
These measures will make Agency staff and clients more aware of the powers available.
The Joint Committee recommends that section 76 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to give statutory force to Child Support Agency practice
The Agency does not support this recommendation as it would limit rather than reinforce the ability to make additional disbursements.

The Committee recognised that, under section 76 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988, the Registrar is required to disburse money to the custodian by the first Wednesday of the month following collection. The Agency's practice is to make two disbursements each month—on the first and third Wednesday. The Committee approved of this practice but wanted to ensure that the Agency has the legislative authority to support it.

The Committee's recommendation that section 76 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended is not necessary. Section 76 stipulates the final date by which the Registrar must disburse money to the custodian. It does not prevent additional disbursements being made before that date. If section 76 was amended as the Committee suggested, there may be adverse consequences such as limiting the Agency's ability to make additional early disbursements in appropriate cases.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:
(a)develops national guidelines on the recovery of overpayments from custodial parents and repayment to non custodial parents;

(b)gives effect to its commitment to the Ombudsman that, prior to seeking to recover overpayments from custodial parents, the Child Support Agency informs both parties of the overpayment and provides the opportunity to negotiate the period over which an amount should be repaid; and
(c)informs parents of the content of the national guidelines and the potential collection problems created by not advising the Child Support Agency promptly of any change in circumstances
The Agency supports this recommendation and has implemented parts of it.

A draft guideline on repayment of overpayments and a discussion paper on the recovery of overpayments will be issued in March 1995. The paper on recovery of overpayments is designed to assist Agency staff in dealing with custodians when negotiating repayments.

In relation to paragraph (b), the Agency advised all staff in February 1994 that overpayments must not be recovered from custodians without first contacting them and attempting to negotiate a satisfactory repayment arrangement. The Agency will be monitoring the implementation of this direction. This will be covered in more detail in the discussion paper on recovery of overpayments. A final policy document will be developed after comments received on the discussion paper have been evaluated.
In relation to paragraph (c), this information will be as part of the targeted client education program described at recommendation 23.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces procedures to ensure that:
(a)amounts remitted by employers are promptly and accurately recorded against the correct non custodial parent's account and that amounts are credited for the correct contribution period; and

(b)amounts credited to non custodial parents' accounts which represent direct payments to custodial parents, accurately reflect the timing and amount of each transaction to assist clients and staff to understand the account with the Child Support Agency
The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to implement it.

As noted by the Committee, the Agency implemented a new accounting system in July 1994. The new system provides simpler statements each month to liable parents which show an opening balance, record payments and other changes to the account since the date of the opening balance and a closing balance which represents the new amount outstanding.

The accounting system automatically assigns payments received from an employer deducting for only one employee to the liable parent's account. This will ensure payments are promptly and accurately recorded in those cases. The Agency is currently reviewing its procedures for reconciling amounts remitted by employers against liable parents' accounts to ensure amounts are recorded accurately in all cases. This review will be completed by the end of June 1995.
The Agency will evaluate the new accounting system shortly. As part of this process, the Agency will evaluate how the new system has assisted clients in understanding their accounts.

In relation to paragraph (b), the level of information about non-agency payments to be provided on statements of account will be considered further as part of the Agency's information technology improvement program.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency takes immediate steps to inform parents in Child Support Agency correspondence of its policy on the crediting of non agency payments

The Agency is commencing a client education program, this financial year, to ensure that all clients are aware of their rights and responsibilities under the child support legislation. A key component of the proposed client education program is the provision of specific information to Agency clients about the Agency's administrative practices and policies, including those relating to crediting non-agency payments. More detail about this program is provided in the response to recommendation 23.
The Agency released a draft ruling in August 1994 outlining the policy for crediting non-agency payments. Once this ruling is finalised, the Agency will take steps to inform clients of the policy.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency provides information in multi-lingual pamphlets explaining the review avenues available and how to apply for a review

The Agency will identify the information needs of clients from non-English speaking backgrounds and clients who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people as part of the targeted client education program discussed at recommendation 23. The Agency will work closely with community organisations to determine the most effective way of providing information to these groups. The needs of all clients for information about the review process will form part of the proposed program.

In addition to the education program mentioned above, the 1994-95 ATO Corporate Plan includes a corporate activity to upgrade access and equity strategies and programs. The Agency has responded to this Plan by scheduling a research project for the 1994-95 year on current and potential clients of the Agency who are from non-English speaking backgrounds or who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people.

The intention of the project is to put the Agency in a better position to devise and implement access and equity strategies to meet the government's objectives of ensuring that all Australians can access its programs and can receive a fair share of resources delivered through those programs.
The specific objectives of the research are
to bring together the body of existing information on people from non-English speaking backgrounds and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for child support and related issues
to determine gaps in existing information and develop practical options for filling those gaps

to identify the issues which are relevant to giving people from non-English speaking backgrounds and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people access to the Agency and access to child support generally.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes uniform national procedures for determining when enforcement action should commence and the types of enforcement action which are appropriate based upon the following criteria:
(a)sources of income and assets available to the non custodial parent;
(b)the age of the debt; and
(c)the size of the debt
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops debt management and enforcement procedures consistent with the philosophy espoused in the Child Support Agency compliance policy
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops an internal reporting system that:
(a)structures debts by appropriate age intervals and size;
(b)provides accurate and timely information on debtors arrears; and
(c)identifies and classifies non custodial parents who have recently defaulted
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops a risk profile of its non custodial parent client base which enables it to assess accurately:
(a)the costs and benefits of each enforcement practice against categories of its non custodial parent population; and
(b)the short falls of existing enforcement approaches and develops alternative approaches to increase the Child Support Agency's enforcement effectiveness
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency analyses outstanding debt and classifies it into various categories to enable the Agency to understand the nature of outstanding debt
The Agency has strategies in place which address the concerns raised by the Committee in recommendations 85-89.

The Agency has developed a two-pronged strategy for debt collection and enforcement based on a review recently conducted by a debt collection expert. This involves contacting new defaulters as early as possible and dealing with long term defaulters on a project basis. Since 1 July 1994, the Agency has collected more than $30 million of the total arrears outstanding as at that date.

The Agency's Compliance Policy describes how decisions about appropriate enforcement action are to be made. The policy deals with both the decision to take enforcement action and the type of action which is appropriate in the circumstances of a particular case. The policy describes the types of enforcement action available and the hierarchy for taking action where more than one potential action is available. Decisions about whether enforcement action should commence and the most appropriate type of action are based on the liable parent's capacity to pay.

Where the liable parent has the capacity to pay the debt and a payment arrangement is not possible or breaks down, the policy states that further action will be taken. This will be either administrative action or legal action depending upon the particular circumstances. The Agency will use administrative powers before taking legal action because of the convenience and cost effectiveness of using such powers.

The Agency is addressing non-current year debt as part of the Arrears Project. In that process, sources and levels of income, and the age and size of the debt are factors considered in organising work for targeting the collection of outstanding arrears.

As part of the Arrears Project, the Agency has developed draft national procedures for dealing with cases in arrears. These procedures will be finalised by April 1995 and will then be implemented in all branch offices and their consistency will be monitored nationally.

In relation to recommendation 87, a reporting system to structure debts by appropriate age intervals and size is currently being tested. This system will further enhance the Agency's ability to manage debt.

In relation to recommendation 88, the Agency will evaluate its enforcement practices and the effectiveness of the approach described in the Compliance Policy, including a cost benefit analysis of these practices.
The Agency will assess the Arrears Project plan by the end of December 1995 to determine areas of weakness and whether or not alternative approaches should be used.

Information about the nature of outstanding debt is being collected as part of the Arrears Project. The Agency will be able to develop an effective long term strategy once the information has been collected and analysed.
The Joint Committee recommends that Child Support Agency enforcement staff be trained, as a matter of priority, in the appropriate use of existing enforcement powers
The Agency supports this recommendation and implementation has commenced.

The Agency has given a high priority to enforcement and arrears through both technical and client service training with the aim of improving service to clients through consistency in the application of the Compliance Policy and the selection of the most appropriate enforcement method.

The Agency is currently developing technical training materials on enforcement matters. Staff working on the Arrears Project and staff dedicated to enforcement work will receive this technical training as well as the Client Contact Skills program as a matter of priority to ensure enforcement powers are used professionally and fairly. The technical training on enforcement matters will be incorporated into the CSA Tech 1-2-3 package (discussed at recommendation 11).

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reports to the Assistant Treasurer within 6 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report on the costs and benefits of introducing private process servers

The Agency, either directly or through the Australian Government Solicitor's office, uses private process servers for service of initiating documents such as plaints and summonses. This is standard commercial practice and is cost effective for the Agency.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:
(a)reports to the Assistant Treasurer within 12 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report on any difficulties in enforcement which might be remedied by the granting of further powers; and
(b)reviews its enforcement strategies on a 12 monthly basis to counter changes in client behaviour which leads them to avoid liability

The Agency will report to the Assistant Treasurer within 12 months of the tabling of the Committee's report on any difficulties in enforcement which might be remedied by the granting of further powers. The Agency will also gain increased knowledge of compliance behaviour and patterns through the client profiling exercise currently underway and the Arrears Project.

The Agency has developed a two-pronged strategy for debt collection and enforcement as discussed at recommendations 85-89. This involves contacting new defaulters as early as possible and dealing with long term defaulters on a project basis.
The effectiveness of the approach to new defaulters will be evaluated by the end of December 1995.

The Arrears Project will be evaluated by the end of December 1995 to monitor the implementation of procedures developed as part of that project, assess results and re-evaluate the strategy as necessary.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency makes enforcement a high priority activity and urgently provides dedicated staff to enforcement to remedy the five years of neglect in this area

The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted on it. The Agency has put in place a national Compliance Policy which combined with additional staff resources is expected to improve and sustain its enforcement performance.

The Agency's Arrears Project will address the build up of non-current year debt. The Project will be conducted by additional staff made available by freeing up of resources as a result of Agency Agreement efficiencies across the ATO. It is expected that the project will run over three years and will work to a model where source and level of income, and age and size of the debt are factors taken into consideration in organising priorities for targeting the collection of outstanding arrears.

The standardisation of work practices to be developed as part of the Agency's Blueprint process will help to ensure that a consistent approach is taken to enforcement. For example, the Agency is creating new positions at a senior level in each branch with specific responsibility for compliance improvement and resolving complex technical issues.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar exercises the power under section 120 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to require non custodial parents with more than 3 months of arrears to attend before him to enable the Child Support Agency to reassess these debts and/or to negotiate payment of these debts
The Agency does not support this recommendation.

The exercise of the Registrar's power under section 120 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 is one of the options available in establishing a capacity to pay and negotiation of payment of arrears. Agency staff conduct interviews under section 120 as part of the process of following up on new defaulters.

The powers under section 120 will be used, where appropriate, by staff working on the collection of non-current year arrears in the Arrears Project. The principles on which the Compliance Policy is based require the Agency to understand clients and their needs, work with clients to build trust and respect and to act fairly.

There is a wide range of reasons for liable parents defaulting on their child support liabilities. It would be inequitable to treat all liable parents in the same way by conducting these interviews as a matter of course.

It would also be an inefficient use of resources to develop a procedure which required all non custodial parents to attend for reassessment or negotiation of payment of debts after 3 months of arrears, irrespective of their personal circumstances. The debt management and enforcement procedures now in place are consistent with these principles. The Agency usually contacts newly defaulting liable parents to give them the opportunity to meet their obligations voluntarily.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to remit a late payment penalty

The Registrar already has the power under section 68 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to remit a late payment penalty in certain circumstances. No further action is required in relation to this recommendation.

The Registrar has issued Child Support Ruling CSR 93/1 which deals with the exercise of this discretion. In deciding whether or not to remit a late payment penalty, the Registrar must be satisfied that the liable parent has taken reasonable action to mitigate the effect of the circumstances which led to non-payment. The Ruling states that part payment of the liability or entering into an arrangement for payment may constitute reasonable mitigating action.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar informs custodial parents about the reasons why particular enforcement activities have been unsuccessful or why a decision has been made not to proceed further with enforcement action in accordance with section 113(2) of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency as a matter of practice, regularly notifies each custodial parent with arrears of child support owing to them, of current and recent Child Support Agency enforcement activity and the results of the activity

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency advises custodial parents immediately a decision is made not to proceed with enforcement of child support debts and makes them aware of their objection and appeal rights as defined in the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988

The Agency recognises the importance of informing custodians of action taken by the Agency to enforce debts as reflected in recommendations 103-105. Where the Agency takes enforcement action, it will inform custodians of the results of that action but will not disclose any personal details about the liable parent.

The Committee stated that the Child Support Registrar has a statutory duty under subsection 113(2) of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to provide custodians with reasons why particular enforcement activities have been unsuccessful or why a decision has been made not to proceed further with enforcement action. The Agency believes that subsection 113(2) of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 provides the Registrar with the discretion to provide this information, but that it is not a statutory requirement.

The Compliance Policy states that the Registrar may inform the custodian of the outcome of action taken to collect outstanding debt, but will not disclose personal details about the liable parent or any other person (such as an address or place of employment) or any information which may hinder the progress of the collection activity. This type of information is not necessary for the purposes of keeping the custodian informed. There needs to be a balance between keeping custodians informed as to the current status of their case and protecting the rights of the non-custodial parent.

There is a significant number of cases where enforcement action is pending. As the Agency's enforcement strategies take effect, the Agency will inform custodians of the action taken, the results of that action or a decision not to take further action.

The Agency may decide not to take enforcement action either because it lacks sufficient information or because the liable parent has no capacity to pay. Where this is the case, the Agency will contact the custodian to explain why no action is being taken and to seek information which may enable the Agency either to establish the liable parent's capacity to pay or to take further action.
The Agency will include information about objection and appeal rights in the client education program referred to at recommendation 23.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces national compensation guidelines which are independent of the Australian Taxation Office guidelines

The Agency recognises that there are some situations in which decisions about compensation involve circumstances peculiar to child support. The Agency will develop compensation guidelines which are independent of the ATO guidelines. These guidelines will draw upon the principles outlined in the ATO's compensation guidelines and will address issues specific to the Agency.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency informs its clients of the existence of the compensation guidelines, clients' rights to claim for compensation and the situations in which claims can be made
The Agency supports this recommendation.
The Child Support Charter will inform clients of their rights to claim for compensation, how to apply for compensation and the situations in which claims may arise.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency undertakes research to identify the number of parents under the Child Support Scheme who receive business or investment income and the extent to which these parents minimise their child support liabilities

As part of a client profiling exercise currently underway, the Agency is collecting information about the sources of income of the majority of liable parents from whom the Registrar is collecting child support. This exercise will be complete by the end of May 1995. Through this exercise, the Agency will identify the number of liable parents who receive business or investment income. The Agency will then examine the extent to which the current basis for assessment and review of assessments results in an appropriate determination of the child support liability in these cases.
