SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994, which is currently before the parliament, is the first part of a rewrite of the Income Tax Assessment Act in plain English. Unfortunately, it has a very narrow focus that is directed only to work related expenses. In fact, it does no more than prescribe very tight conditions—they are unreasonably tight in some circumstances—for tax deductibility. They are not for business generally but for taxpayers incurring expenses relating to their work and claiming tax deductions for car expenses.

PARA.TAB: Given the time it has taken to get this first instalment of a very large program, I query the team's ability to complete the task on schedule. An interesting observation is that the section of the population that really knows the least about tax and tax implications when compared with business will, as a result of this legislation, now have standards and conditions put on it that are very tight compared with business, which generally has money to access tax advice.

I ask the Senate to remember the Evangelist case, because we could see it being well repeated. For those who do not remember it, the Evangelist case went to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which was satisfied that an expense had been incurred. But the very prescriptive nature of signing off each day's expenditure or mileage had not been followed, so the expenditure claim was denied. So I am very concerned about the ability of people to be successful in relation to this legislation.

The legislation before us shows inconsistencies between different types of taxpayers. The substantiation requirements are quite different, for example, for taxpayers who have expenses related to an award where they do not have to follow this prescription and they do not have to provide any written evidence. The problem is that the work related prescriptions are very tight compared with those for general business purposes. There are inconsistencies in that those people under an award can claim a deduction without any written prescription whereas others have to comply with the detailed letter of the law.

Those who are most at risk under this legislation are politicians. They are most at risk because of the nature of their expenditure patterns and, in many cases, their inability to get a prescriptive ticket. Those who go to a show pay $10 to go through the gate. The ticket is passed in, so there is no record of expenditure. One might say that one can claim up to $200 in this way, but $200 is eaten up very quickly. I ask the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to ensure that this $200 is lifted. We cannot do this as an opposition, because it has revenue implications. But in consideration of the needs of her back bench and others, I ask her to listen very carefully in terms of that issue.

For years, our Income Tax Assessment Act has been criticised for its complexity, language and length. This difficulty has led to unnecessary high compliance costs for taxpayers and increased administration costs to the government. In recent times, the government has been transferring many of those costs back to the business community and, in the case of this bill, to ordinary taxpayers. There has also been the problem of inaccurate compliance by taxpayers.

In the very persuasive report No. 326 entitled An assessment of tax, which is a report on an inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which I was a part, recommended that the government establish a broadly based task force for redrafting the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and that the government commit sufficient resources to the task that would allow it to complete a priority simplification redraft within two years and full simplification of the act within five years.

The project team has released a broad framework. It makes it clear that the project is not about reforming the tax system or reviewing tax policy. That in itself is a major disappointment. Its narrow objective is to focus on administrative rules that the Australian Taxation Office believes are overly complex, unnecessary or out of date with today's reality. That is an interesting statement, because these rules only came in less than seven years ago and they are alleged to be already out of date. However, the framework made clear that, when redrafting, the project team may come across provisions where the meaning is unclear. These cases may require the government to clarify the policy so that the law can be more clearly written.

What is needed to complement the tax law improvement project is for a commission to be set up to tackle the major technical issues inherent in the Income Tax Assessment Act. This is precisely what this improvement team is not doing. My approach is to look at the technical issues that are inherent in, and scattered right throughout, the Income Tax Assessment Act. Therein lies the problem. I believe that such a concentration of effort would concrete the future of Australia's taxation laws in the direction of a simpler legislative framework and not necessarily a plain English simplified version.

The bill, the first instalment, naturally has been reasonably welcomed. But, given the opportunity for time, more and more people are having concerns about its content and its scope. It was hoped to be a promising micro-economic reform at the call of the Australian economy. However, any reform is a slow and arduous project. I believe that there are major difficulties.

I must say that the project team is in capable hands. In fact, it is being led by Brian Nolan, a former second commissioner in the Australian Taxation Office who has spent more than 20 years making tax laws more complicated. He is adamant now in his near retirement years of trying to help to tidy them up. Perhaps we might need some older people in the Taxation Office who share Brian Nolan's enthusiasm. The team also includes personnel from the Australian Taxation Office, the Treasury, the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and two private sector representatives. A 14-person consultative committee has also been set up, and I think there are one or two other people involved.

We understand that the project has been based on the lessons of the wholesale sales tax, the New Zealand income tax simplification and the Australian Corporations Law simplification. As the minister may recall, this afternoon I drew attention to a particular problem arising from sales tax simplification. But the task of rewriting the wholesale sales tax will be a large project for the drafters and their advisers, as the project life is estimated to be two to three years. This might seem a long time until one realises how much time will be needed to check the changes at the stage of the exposure draft bills.

This is the first law to be brought out by the tax law improvement program. The aim is to try to make some significant savings in the cost of compliance by expressing the law in simpler and easier to understand language, and as such we welcome that. The substantiation requirements, as outlined in sections 82KT and 82KZBB, require substantiation of car expenses claimed by individuals and partnerships and substantiation of employment related expenses for salary and wage earners. I must emphasise that companies and trusts are excluded from their operation because they come under a different set of rules, principally section 62A.

Under the self-assessment system, the records do not have to be provided with a taxpayer's return but must be retained for production in the case of an audit. While the reworded bill conforms to the stated aims of the project, in that it is better structured and more easily understood, the practical application of the substantiation rules remains extremely complicated and does not deal with any underlying policy issues affecting the complexity of the law. While the changes are important, this process really must go a lot further. I would hope that the tax law improvement team take note of these concerns.
The Taxation Institute of Australia also expresses shortcomings about the tax law improvement process. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: It is acknowledged that a move to have a simpler legislative framework with a less legalistic structure is clearly the preferred approach to the future direction of tax laws. However, the change in language used in the legislation is not of itself sufficient to materially reduce the compliance burden on taxpayers in complying with the substantiation provisions.

After hearing those comments from that influential body, what have we really achieved? The government certainly has achieved a public relations plus but, in the long term, when more and more people come to realise the tight prescriptive nature of this, I think it will turn into not a plus but a minus.

PARA.TAB: I am of the opinion that the project will take a lot longer than the scheduled two to three years. I believe this whole process can be put into the context of a person on a three-week holiday. During this time, this person plans to paint the house, the gates and the surrounding fence. But, at the end of the first week, that person has done no more than, say, paint the front gate. This is the stage that we have got to in terms of the two- to three-year time frame set for the tax law improvement project. They have only brushed over the topics.

We have been told that in future we will see amendments that will amalgamate generic groupings like capital allowances and that will establish a basic framework for treating like items. This, in turn, will be followed by draft rewrites for specific areas such as mining, petroleum and quarrying activities, general depreciation and tax losses. But this is not without its problems. Concern has been raised that depreciation and tax loss issues are being reviewed by the tax office as a result of contentious draft rulings; for example, TR94/D26 and D42. A solution has been suggested that the review of the current law and its underlying policy be completed before the relevant rewrite is progressed. Without this, I can assure you there will be longer debates, there will be more changes and it will just defeat the purpose for which the tax law improvement process has been set out.

Without business insistence, the tax law improvement project will only be about form and not about substance. The major shortcoming of the project has been the narrowness of the review. The Treasurer has limited the scope of the redrafting by only specifying a commitment to plainer language, improved presentation and using the most modern drafting techniques and styles that are available. He talked of rational and sensible use of definitions. The tax office and the team have done quite a good job in terms of what has been required, given the very limited scope under which they could operate. I give a bouquet to the tax office and to Mr Nolan and his advisers and assistants.

In a nutshell, the substantiation provisions cover a number of issues. Unfortunately, my time does not permit me to go through them. We will certainly address them in the committee stage. Most measures should in some way reduce compliance costs, but there will be increased compliance costs for individual business persons who, for example, take short-term domestic travel of one to five nights. Presently, they are not required to maintain any records, but the bill will require them to obtain written evidence. Also, salary and wage earners must now retain their records for five years instead of three and a half years. This will be a burden for taxpayers. I will address this further during the committee stage of the debate.

Mr Ray Regan, a well-known commentator from the National Tax and Accounting Association, notes that it is becoming abundantly clear that our taxation system creates a far more onerous record keeping regime on individuals than for businesses. Coming from a man with such experience, whose membership is drawn basically from the smaller practitioners, this is a serious statement. It is one that needs serious consideration by the Senate and the government. It places a heavy burden on untrained individuals to comply with the double jeopardy of nexus; that is, that the taxpayer actually incurred the expense and it was directly relevant to their current income activities.

The act also superimposes burdensome substantiation guidelines which do not even apply to businesses, knowing full well that suppliers of goods and services have no obligation to in any way provide receipts in the required format. Is it any wonder that most individuals look upon the substantiation legislation as being deemed guilty until they can prove their innocence under substantiation? I put to you that the very process intimidates most individuals. At the very least it will be very costly. In nearly all cases, people will have to go to accountants to get the commissioner's discretion. It will usually be as the result of an audit.

It is worth stressing that over the last eight years primary audits on individual taxpayers consistently indicate that at least seven out of 10 individual taxpayers make errors in their returns, having to pay back not less than $1,200 each after the audit. Our taxation laws are placing a far greater responsibility on ordinary taxpayers not trained on financial matters. As indicated, they are more likely to make technical errors.

The government is rather anxious to get this through. I wonder why. Is not the government expecting to raise an extra $1 billion from tighter compliance, tighter substantiation? How did this come about? In the last budget the government thought it could get an extra $300 million, but in the previous budget it highlighted the fact that it was going to get $750 million. Where is all this money going to come from? It must come from ordinary individuals, individuals who may have problems with substantiation. Are these a targeted group? Are politicians a targeted group? I certainly hope not.

Our tax laws are placing far greater responsibility on these ordinary taxpayers, who are more likely to make technical errors. But at this early stage of the proceedings a spanner has been thrown into the works as a result of a recent decision in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal concerning a long distance truck driver's expenses on food and drink. You might recall that the driver thought he was complying with the substantiation rules by keeping a logbook. Even though the logbook is not an acceptable method by which to claim expenditure, the tribunal decided to exercise its statutory discretion. It was satisfied the expenses had been incurred and that it would be unreasonable for the substantiation provisions to apply to this taxpayer. Consequently the taxpayer was allowed a deduction of $6,240 for travel expenses.

I asked the minister to respond to the question: how is this decision going to impinge on this legislation? I think we need to answer that. It was a good decision of the tribunal but it has thrown in doubt this whole question of the credibility of these new substantiation rules that we are about to pass. Obviously the simple answer that I know they are going to give is that this applied to the previous law and not to the current law. But this has raised the sorts of issues that this legislation is designed to overcome. In essence on the approach taken by the tribunal in this case, the commissioner ought not to apply a full substantiation under the current rules if a taxpayer can provide evidence that expense was incurred and the circumstances are such that the taxpayer would otherwise be entitled to a deduction. The effect of this tribunal's decision when combined with the proposed change to be made to the law has created a degree of uncertainty about the extent to which there must be compliance with the peculiar and detailed substantiation rules.

Further problems are associated with the rewrite of this bill. Section 16-3(1) underlines a fundamental flaw. My colleague Mr Rocher in the other house drew attention to the concept of a person flying to Los Angeles for the sole purpose of attending a seven-day a conference, but if you do not record the conference on your travel record you cannot deduct the cost of the air fare. This is so even if you have written evidence that you have paid for the fare or a receipt is required by division 5. If that is correct, that is a major problem people are going to face. This sort of illustration does give a concern—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the indulgence of the Senate could I have leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter written by the Assistant Commissioner, tax law improvement project, which outlines concerns that I have in relation to substantiation where a supplier does not provide any form of documentation at all? I thank the Tax Office for giving me this because it could save quite a deal of time during the committee stage of the debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Crowley

TALK.START.PARA: —I apparently have not yet received a copy of that. But you and I have spoken and you did provide it earlier. I have not been able to chase down whether my previous colleague in the chamber who got the letter from you did give permission. But as you told me, the author is very close to hand. She is able to assure me that this is perfectly acceptable.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Further to our telephone conversation of last week about an aspect of the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994, I thought that it might be of further assistance if I explained how the substantiation provisions would apply to the fact scenario which you were concerned about.
You asked how the written evidence rules would apply to a taxpayer who purchases goods from someone who does not normally provide a receipt.

Substantiation is only required for expenses incurred in the production of salary or wages, or, for individual taxpayers and partnerships containing at least one individual taxpayer, for business travel expenses and for car expenses where the one-third of expenses method or the log book method is used.

The current legislation contains specific provisions which deal with situations where either the supplier is a person carrying on a business who does not, in the ordinary course of the business, supply a receipt, invoice or similar document, and situations where, the person who supplies the goods does so other than in the course of a business. In these situations, satisfactory evidence includes a statement or certificate supplied by the person who supplied the goods. I refer you to subsections 82KU(3) and (4) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.

The Tax Law Improvement Project considered that the law could be simplified by allowing a broader range of documentation in all cases, rather than just in these limited situations. Thus the term "receipt, invoice or similar document" has been replaced with the wider term "document". I refer you to the explanation of this change on page 33 of the Explanatory Memorandum to the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill.
Hence it is not necessary for the supplier of the goods to use a formal or printed document to evidence the purchase.

Nevertheless, if the supplier would not normally provide any form of documentation for a receipt, there are two provisions in the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill which could assist the purchaser.

First, under sections 5.6 and 5.7, if the Commissioner considers it unreasonable to expect you to have gotten written evidence of an expense, you can rely on a record of the expenses which you have made yourself instead of getting a document from the supplier. This record does not necessarily have to be a diary entry.

Second, section 8.1, allows a deduction in cases where the formal requirements have not been met, if, on the basis of the nature and quality of the evidence that the purchaser has to substantiate their claim, the Commissioner is satisfied that the purchaser incurred the expense and is entitled to a deduction. The Bill broadens the discretion in the existing law, which limits the situations in which the discretion may be applied. The Bill will remove those restrictions.
I hope that this response is of assistance. If you have any further concerns or queries, do not hesitate to ring me directly on (06) 216 1518.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is the first effort of the tax law improvement rewrite project of the Tax Office. The Democrats welcome this program and support the rewriting of the Income Tax Assessment Act in plain English. The bill runs to 31 pages across two schedules and will replace sections 82KT to 82KZBB inclusive. In the process the bulk of the text dealing with the substantiation provisions of the tax act is reduced by 50 per cent. The tax law improvement project arose out of a representation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report tabled in December 1993. The then federal Treasurer John Dawkins took up the recommendation, announced a rewrite of the tax act and then promptly resigned from parliament two hours later. It has now taken a year for this part of the review to be completed, with three even more complex phases yet to come.

PARA.TAB: I wish to commend the project team on some of the results of their endeavours. The wording of the bill is fairly user-friendly and the aim to make the tax act the primary source for assessment advice is largely met. The structure of the bill has been overhauled to make it easier for the users to find their way around it. The language is direct, with the use of the pronoun `you' as the focus point for a taxpayer's obligations. Every section stems from a key principle, with a large amount of explanatory material and the use of graphic illustrations and examples. But a more readable act does not necessarily mean lower compliance costs for taxpayers. The key failing of the review process has been the very narrow terms of reference under which the review team laboured. These terms of reference did not allow the team to consider policy issues, even policy issues directly related to compliance costs.

In keeping the terms of reference so narrow, the government has continued to ignore the problems that substantiation provisions and self-assessment have caused since their introduction in 1984. The search by the Tax Institute and the National Tax Accountants Association shows that the overwhelming majority of taxpayers whose returns are audited are found to have made errors. There remains a lack of understanding about current tax rules, with taxpayers still denied legitimate deductions even when the expense is documented if the proper form and process has not been followed. This bill does little to improve the situation. Having said that, the government has in a few minor ways moved to improve the current law. Logbook rules for car expenses have been slightly improved. All four forms of car expenses are to be exempted from the $300 substantiation threshold exemption, a move which benefits about 10 per cent of taxpayers claiming car expenses and which the government estimates suggest could cost as much as $10 million in revenue. The requirements for documented travel expenses are standardised for business and non-business users, making diary requirements on short trips a little less onerous for business users but more onerous for ordinary taxpayers.

The rules for record retention are standardised, reducing the period that business users must hold receipts from seven to five years but increasing the period for ordinary taxpayers from 3 1/2 to five years. Laundry expenses are simplified, allowing up to $150 of expenses without receipts. The rules on annotating receipts and independent advice payments are relaxed a little.

These changes are generally welcomed but they do not go far enough. The substantiation provisions on ordinary taxpayers are still too complex and the compliance costs still far too high. The beneficiaries of the changes are in most instances business taxpayers, and while that is fine, ordinary taxpayers will get little if anything out of the changes other than a more readable but more onerous tax act. This is certainly disappointing. Government has not even been prepared to retain the few concessions available to ordinary taxpayers under the present bills.

A key concern for the Democrats is the reluctance of government to preserve the benefit of the $300 exemption threshold below which substantiation receipts need not be kept. This amount has not been increased since 1986 when the self-assessment and substantiation rules were introduced. It marked a concession from government to small taxpayers and they said at the time, `We are really not after you; we are after the bigger fish.' Since 1986, the CPI has risen nearly 50 per cent, while the figure of $300 has not risen at all.

We were attempting to look at an amendment to raise the amount to $450 but apparently could not persuade either the opposition or the government to agree to it. We do ask questions about whether this government is really serious about a fairer tax system. Let us remember that, according to the 1992-93 taxation statistics, a middle income taxpayer is paying around 28c in the dollar while a millionaire is still paying around 23c in the dollar.

The government argues that its decision to exempt all four forms of travel expenses from the $300 threshold is a new concession. But, again, this will benefit only business taxpayers. Eighty-eight per cent of taxpayers who claim travel expenses do so using the cents per kilometre or 12 per cent of cost schemes which are not included now in the $300 limit.

In summary, this bill results in a better written law but does nothing for the PAYE taxpayer. There are benefits in there for business taxpayers but none for the mums and dads who continue to provide the vast bulk of revenue for this government. The Democrats will support the bill as a marginal improvement on existing law. However, we would urge the government to seriously reconsider the priority it is giving to ordinary taxpayers in the tax law improvement project, and to ensure that a fairer go for PAYE taxpayers becomes a statement of action rather than another piece of unfulfilled rhetoric.

I note that the drafting working party and consultative committee consist of lots of representatives of business interests but hardly any voice for PAYE taxpayers. I would urge the government to review this imbalance in representation before the next stage of reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill and to support my colleague Senator Watson. As has been said previously, this bill is the first product of the tax law improvement project. That project was announced by the government in December 1993, with the object of rewriting the income tax law in simple language.

PARA.TAB: The tax law improvement project proposal followed a recommendation by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in late 1993 that the government should establish a broadly based task force to redraft the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. It should be noted that this project has also released a broad framework which makes it clear that the project itself is not concerned with reforming the tax system or reviewing tax policy. The new rules are designed to be shorter, clearer, simpler and more easily readable than is now the case under the existing law.

The bill itself adopts a plain English style, including the use of the personal pronoun `you' to refer to taxpayers. A new numbering system has also been introduced which has been designed to avoid problems caused by the old system. However, the opposition has noted that there may still be areas of inconvenience in the numbering. Use is made of duplicate section numbers in two new schedules—for example, section 1-1 of schedule 2A and section 1-1 of schedule 2B. This may create a degree of inconvenience in searching for sections in electronic publications and databases.

Whilst the opposition totally supports the efforts and progress made in the simplification of the act, the narrowness of the overall review is a major shortcoming. Complex tax policy issues which need to be addressed to achieve a major simplification of the tax system have been totally ignored in this bill, with the emphasis, as it is, on the use of plain English and the adoption of a simple legislative structure.

As I mentioned, this approach is to be commended, but the opposition believes that the whole approach does not go far enough. Plain English and a better drafting of the law are, themselves, not a substitute for a simpler tax law with lower compliance costs. A simplification of the income tax law is a matter of policy which seems to be lacking from any attempt by the government to address the inherent problems in the current tax regime.

The bill provides that the new substantiation provisions will apply to expenses incurred on or after 1 July last year—that is, 1994. This compares with the original starting date of 1 July 1995, which was specified in the initial exposure draft. The opposition hopes that the Australian Taxation Office has made every effort to ensure that its regular Tax Pack publication makes taxpayers aware of the new rules as they apply to a number of the substantiation provisions in the bill. Certainly, it must be admitted that the Tax Pack publication has, on a number of occasions over the last few years, contained some significant errors of fact, which have served to create both confusion and concern amongst Australian taxpayers.

Substantiation provisions of the Income Tax Act are estimated to have an impact on 70 per cent of all taxpayers, with an estimated 5.4 million people being affected. It is imperative, therefore, that the proposed substantiation changes are fully and widely advertised to enable taxpayers to benefit fully from them.

The financial impact of this bill is expected to be minimal, with the administrative changes having no impact on revenue. The one exception will be the removal of car expenses from the $300 substantiation threshold exemption. Whilst I do not intend to go into any degree of detail on the changes which this bill introduces, I would like to say that the opposition believes that the changes themselves do not, in some cases, go far enough. We in the opposition believe that the process of income tax law simplification, with the consequential reduction in compliance costs, must go much further.

A great number of concerns have been raised about this legislation by the National Taxpayers Association of Australia, the NTAA. That association, for example, quite correctly highlights the difficulties created by many of the onerous record keeping requirements which are placed on individuals which are not placed on businesses. Whilst the opposition agrees with this particular area of concern, it would hope that many of the difficulties caused by substantiation requirements can be remedied and resolved by the discretion power placed in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation, under section 8-1 of schedule 2B of the new bill. The opposition also agrees with the criticism by the NTAA that individual taxpayers face a difficulty in substantiation in those cases where a supplier of goods and services is not legally compelled—under any state or federal provision—to provide an original receipt, invoice or statement.

Another area of concern is the increased period under which taxpayers must retain records; this has increased from three and a half months to five years. Whilst the opposition is broadly in agreement with the standardising of the period for business and individual taxpayers, there must be some concern that individual taxpayers are being burdened with additional retention procedures and the increased likelihood of losing or unintentionally disposing of substantiation receipts. Again, we in the opposition tend to agree with the NTAA that this may have the effect of further burdening taxpayers with additional compliance.

There are also a number of other similar examples, the detail of which I will not go into here. Suffice it to say, however, that the opposition believes that, whilst the rewriting and simplification of the act is to be commended, there is much more that needs to be done.

For some time the government has spoken about the need to simplify the taxation system but has done little to further that objective. It is interesting to look back to the 1985 tax summit and recall the words of the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who said:

SPEECH.PARA: A good tax system should be as simple as possible . . . to reduce the burden of record keeping . . . to increase the certainty of what is, or is not, taxable and to increase the clarity of the tax system.

That objective of the Prime Minister's got lost for a while—five years, in fact—and finally re-emerged in February 1990 in the form of the statement announcing the establishment of a review team to examine options for the simplification of the tax system. Then, over three years after that, we finally heard of the tax simplification project. Thus, it has taken us more than 10 years to proceed from the Prime Minister's original tax summit statement to the production of this simplification bill.

PARA.TAB: The government does not appear to be genuine on the question of tax simplification. Whilst the opposition supports the bill, it acknowledges many of the concerns raised by the tax association. The opposition believes that tax simplification entails much more than rewriting the Income Tax Act in simple English; it requires a concerted and genuine attempt by government to reduce the complexity and to increase the fairness of the overall tax system in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by saying that this is one of the bills that has been pushed through as a matter of urgency because it is considered to be necessary in order to change taxation for this year. I would like to make it very clear that, and I am not sure whether everybody understands this, if we go ahead and pass this bill now or if we go through the full debate—which I am hoping we will not; I am hoping we will adjourn it—we will possibly bring in some changes that are problematical. There certainly are elements to this bill which a number of people are looking for, but there are also some possible problems.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure that rushing through with this kind of haste is the best way to deal with this. If we have been waiting ten years, it is not the right thing to do to wait ten years and then put some things through which might create problems—not just problems now but problems in retrospect because this applies from 1 July 1994. It means that, if there are problems, we are already hoisting them on people for their current tax year when they would not have been aware of them.

We have before us a bill the government believes must be passed as a matter of urgency—the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill. It is another of those bills which have been rapidly pushed through the Senate. Treasury said as it presented it to us that it was introduced in the House last year and so, if it was introduced in the Senate in this sitting and debated the next, it would have taken almost a year to pass. That is stretching the truth. In point of fact this bill was introduced in the House last year. It was introduced on 8 December. The House rose on the 9th. It was not read a second time or debated until 8 February—that is, this sitting. It was introduced in the Senate on 27 February, the beginning of this last week of sitting. I would like to note that, if it went according to standing orders and was passed on the last day of the next sittings, it would have been passed in slightly more than six months.

I would also like to note that when the draft law was circulated the date for the changes was the tax year starting 1 July 1995. The bill was introduced in the House at the very end of last year's sittings with a date making it effective from 1 July 1994. In other words, the government decided to push it through and knew it would have to push it through the Senate against standing orders if it wanted to be certain it would be passed before this year's tax pack was sent to the printers. So the government knew about this before it started.

This is a bill which is intended primarily to clean up the language and vagaries of substantiation law. We were told explicitly that it was intended not as a policy review or to change law but simply to make it comprehensible with a few minor changes to eliminate the totally unreasonable. The vagaries have been with us for a while. If the bill is not intended to address policy questions or the nature of the tax system itself, I cannot understand the panic. The problem with existing law—aside from being, by their own admission, incomprehensible even to the tax officers who drafted this new bill—seems to me to be that the substantiation requirements introduced in 1984 and subsequently modified are really over the top, requiring a number of things that no-one is likely to be able to do even if they try. I understand there is broad support for changes to make this system more rational by introducing a bit of flexibility.

Aside from the principle of consideration and undue haste, I have some substantive concerns. I recognise the attempt to create greater flexibility in relation to the substantiation requirements allowing taxpayers to fill in the blanks that inevitably occur on receipts or to provide some evidence other than a signed receipt from the seller. This may be marginally better than the current system, which requires such a high level of substantiation in such a form that is virtually impossible to obtain. But I ask the Senate: why are we demanding this sort of substantiation at all? Under section 262A(1) of the tax law, there is a requirement which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a person carrying on a business must keep records that record and explain all transactions and other acts engaged in by the person that are relevant for any purpose of this Act.
The documents to be kept are clarified in 262A(2). It states:
262A(2) (documents to be kept) The records to be kept under subsection (1) include:
(a)any documents that are relevant for the purpose of ascertaining the person's income and expenditure; and

(b) documents containing particulars of any election, estimate, determination or calculation, particulars showing the basis on which and method by which the estimate, determination or calculation was made.

That sounds pretty clear and like reasonably good English. It seems to me that people running a business—BHP or whomever—are required to keep whatever documents they get to support a claim. They might be records of cheques that have gone through, invoices, receipts or whatever. They might be shop records of when a piece of equipment was first used which could support a claim that the item was purchased and received. It might be an estimate of the cost along with whatever was used in making that estimate. Basically, any record that supports a claim can be used, and then it is up to the Australian Taxation Office to believe the claim or call the business a liar, a cheat. That seems reasonable to me.

PARA.TAB: But here we have a situation where seven out of 10 people in Australia, wage and salary earners, ordinary people, are asked to keep records that go far beyond what BHP is required to keep. For wage and salary earners, this is the proposed rule:

SPEECH.PARA: 5-4(2) You must get a document from the supplier of the goods or services the expense is for. The document must set out:
(a) the name or business name of the supplier; and
(b) the amount of the expense, expressed in the currency in which it was incurred; and
(c) the nature of goods or services; and
(d) the day the expense was incurred; and
(e) the day it is made out.

No businesses are required to provide such a document, and they do not. Ordinary people normally tend to think that ordinary accounting documents are sufficient evidence to support a claim. They are not. There is the presumption of knowledge under this law. I know that under the new law people now write in these things, but they have to know they have to write them in. They have to know the tax law enough to know they have to write them in on their receipt—that is, if they get a receipt.

PARA.TAB: Both our office and I understand Senator Watson's office did straw polls to see whether senators and Senate staff understood what sorts of receipts they needed to keep and for how long. In both cases it was found that it is likely several senators and Senate staffers are unaware of the current legal requirements on substantiation and retention. We are supposed to be making the laws here, and we are putting this on everybody else. We work with the law all the time. If we do not know and cannot follow the letter of the law, do we really expect ordinary wage and salary earners to do so?

We are told there is a softening of requirements as people can fill in some of the information themselves. How many people do we really expect to do so? How many ordinary people know tax law well enough to jot down all the required information on the back of their receipt? Why are ordinary receipts, bank accounts and other papers people actually get insufficient, especially if they are sufficient for business taxpayers? To point out the stupidity and pedantic nature of the hoops we are asking people to jump through I will go to the case highlighted by Mr Rocher in the House: if someone flies on business to Los Angeles for seven days and does not keep a travel log but does keep the airline ticket, they cannot claim for that ticket if they do not try to claim for the other travel expenses.

The tax office says that in a hearing there is discretion to ignore the law. My question is: why does this sort of stupid law exist and why is sanity left to the discretion of someone doing the auditing? The tax office estimates that eight out of 10 people audited make mistakes in their tax forms. The average fine is between $1,200 and $1,500. Somehow I cannot believe that eight out of 10 people are tax cheats and madly trying to rort the system.

Included in this law is a change to the time required for record retention. It requires that records be retained for five years. It also brings retention time for businesses down to five years. So ordinary taxpayers have to keep their receipts in case they are audited for up to five years and businesses less. The government says it is imperative to make things equal but does not make the records that need to be retained equal. They are far more onerous for wage and salary earners. Why is this happening? It is my suspicion that this is just another way of making things easier for business while hitting wage and salary earners. I also think it is so that people are frightened of making claims. If they are frightened of making claims, they will not make them, especially if they think they are likely to be audited up to five years in arrears.

Today the tax office does two main kinds of audit: the desk audit and computer assisted audit. The first is done by people and usually occurs in the year a tax return is received. Computer assisted audits require that all tax returns for the year be fed into the computer as well as other items like car ownership records, land records, bank records and so on. Once the computer has this base, it can start to process the returns and find discrepancies, but it takes a couple of years to load this base into the computer. So the rest of the computer assisted audits are audits that take place two or more years after the tax return. In this context an extended period begins to make sense, especially in the light of high profile purchases of new tax super computers.

So what we have in this bill is a situation in which ordinary people are required to hold records longer and face prosecution over a longer period than they do now, to allow them to be turned up by a computer audit. At the same time, the tax requirements are put in simple language, but the requirements themselves will stay so complicated that almost no-one is likely to correctly comply with them. In this situation it is probable that once the tax office gets into gear and starts grinding up people for non-compliance, many people will give up and simply accept that an upper limit on claims is $300 for wage and salary earners since amounts under this do not have the same compliance requirements. I note that currently the average claim is $992. I think this $300 limit is the real agenda here.

This bill comes as part of a process in which, increasingly, the responsibility for correct tax reporting has been shifted to the taxpayer, especially small business and PAYE taxpayers. This might save a bit of money for the tax department, but if you did a cost benefit analysis of the time and effort required for all of that compliance around the country, I would say that it is not particularly economical.

Big business and corporations have full-time accountants and tax experts whose primary job is tax minimisation for their companies. Increased self-assessment means that small businesses and ordinary people are caught in a bind where they are responsible for doing everything right and where there is a legal assumption of knowledge. If they do not do everything right, they are slammed as tax cheats. Yet by their nature they have less documentary evidence given them, they have less specialist knowledge and they engage in practices like driving a car partly for work and partly for personal use, using a washing machine partly for work and partly for personal use and so on. Big business has a company car. If it wants to make documentation easy, the car is used only for company business. All bills, petrol and mileage are automatically business expenses.

As a consequence, we see most people now using a tax accountant, and still people are getting things wrong. The rest generally cannot afford tax agents, so there is a built-in inequity. We see small businesses spending hours every week doing tax work and still living in continual fear that they have done something wrong. We see laws so onerous that it is likely they have done something wrong, no matter how much care they take.

The Greens cannot support this bill at this time. This has been shoved through in such a rush mainly, I believe, to gag debate and stop any attempt at real amendment. We might be able to support this bill without extending the retention time limit on the basis that it really is no worse than the current situation. We might support a longer time limit if there was a real effort to properly improve the ridiculously strict requirements instead of simply making them clear. We might support this if it can be amended to allow something like a requirement for ordinary documentation on a par with what is required for business. But we cannot support this bill as it stands.

As a result, we have proposed an amendment that we consider a minimum to make this law acceptable. It is simple, really. It just reduces the substantiation requirements for wage and salary earners to the level required for business. If we are talking about a level playing field, here it is. It uses the same words as the business requirements I just quoted as 262A(2). We think if the time people are required to keep documents is increased to make everyone equal, it is only fair to decrease the requirements for ordinary documents in the form ordinarily received to put wage and salary earners on equal footing with business.

If you are having second thoughts—I hope you do—we could adjourn tonight, go home after everything else we do tonight, think about this and put some amendments tomorrow. We would be delighted to see this bill improved. As it is, all we are doing, in our opinion, is limiting the ability of wage and salary earners to make valid claims and increasing the period in which they must live in fear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994. Contrary to most tax bills I speak about in this place—I speak on most of them—this bill is one that, I believe, does improve the system of substantiation. It also cuts down on the time that may have to be spent on substantiation. That said, I am mostly speaking about cars used for work or cars used for business.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the new rules, there are four methods for calculating deductions for car expenses, unless an exemption applies. The first option, as listed in the explanatory memorandum, is cents per kilometre. The second option is 12 per cent of the original value, which I believe is as good a way as any if you continuously use a car through the year but do not do a high number of kilometres. The third option is a third of actual expenses, which is the fairest but it takes longer and more work to arrive at a very suitable figure. The fourth option is the logbook. The logbook system does not seem to have changed from the one I remember of keeping the logbook for 12 weeks when you buy a new vehicle or when you change the rate of use of a vehicle you have. That may be the case if you have a private vehicle that goes over to business use. A logbook would be kept if that happened. A vehicle does not have to be new for the logbook system to be used.

I will go through the methods one by one and address them briefly. The first method is on the basis of cents per kilometre. This system can be used if the car's business kilometres are up to 5,000 kilometres and it can be used at any time. The second method is 12 per cent of original value. You deduct 12 per cent of the car's purchase price and that is what you use for the whole year, as long as you meet certain obligations. The third option is for one-third of actual expenses. As I said before, I believe that to be the fairest to everyone, but it takes a lot more work. You can use it only if the car's business use exceeds 5,000 kilometres or if you would have used the car throughout the year of income. That is probably the fairest, but you have to be a lot more accurate.

Then there is the logbook system of keeping a logbook for 12 weeks continuously, whether you lease or buy. If you use the vehicle for less than 12 weeks, you use the logbook for less than 12 weeks. I do not think that would happen unless you had changed the vehicle's use. Of course, you have to retain the logbook for five years. Senator Watson can probably fill me in on this, but I thought that under the old system you did not retain it quite five years, but that is the way it works now. The logbook system is quite a good idea; I have used it myself. It is very easy to use, especially when there is just one driver using it.

I do not normally do this, but I commend the government on this bill. Senator Margetts was saying that in certain cases you have to keep records for longer, but I believe anyone running a good business should keep records well beyond five years, probably seven or eight years, depending on what they are.

There is one thing I would like to question the government on, though. I have never seen it in legislation before that a logbook has to be written in English. I would like to know what the government's thinking behind it is, whether it is lazy substantiation officers or something like that. In this multicultural society I think there would be a few people in Australia who can read English but not necessarily write it. Someone might look askance at that, but there are. My own father could read the West Australian from back to front till the day he died, but he could never write English. If he ever wrote any letters, he wrote them in Italian.

For the sake of the multicultural society, why are we bringing this law in in this day and age? There could be a situation of an employee of an international company coming from another country to Australia and working here for a few weeks or a few months and having to fill in the logbook. I believe that person should have the option of filling in that logbook in another language. Is the government dinkum about this multicultural society that Senator Bolkus and Senator Evans talk about all the time? I am hoping the minister at the table will address that when I sit down. Otherwise, as far as a new substantiation bill is concerned, I find it quite interesting and I look forward to seeing how it will operate in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech made by Senator Margetts relating to this matter, specifically to verification of substantiation of tax claims by workers as compared to major businesses, was very much to the point. I strongly support the amendment that is proposed to be moved by Senator Margetts in this matter. I want to canvass the matters that Senator Margetts and other honourable senators have raised. I am conscious of the fact that we have only got until 6.50 tonight and tomorrow to deal with a raft of legislative measures that have been put before the Senate by the government. Thankfully, one of them—the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4)—will not be before us until the May session.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise a very serious issue: whether or not a minister, on advice from the Australian Taxation Office, has misled this chamber in a previous debate about taxation laws. I refer to the debate which occurred on 8 December 1994 on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1994. I am not going to largely canvass the issues in this debate, but I think it is necessary for me at this point to raise this issue very clearly. I refer honourable senators to that debate. I raised the issue of the Taxation Office's ruling No. TR94/D8. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . TR94/D8 . . . argued that parliament's exemption from penalty tax of income derived by children or child maintenance trusts had been ineffective from its origin.
At that time, I raised questions in the chamber about the matter, as did Senator Reid. I continue to quote what I said on that occasion:
The government promised legislation to ensure parliament's exemption was not frustrated. I happen to believe that what we have here is frustration of that intention.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the proposed legislation fails to achieve the purpose that I just referred to and, in fact, retrospectively creates new tax detriments for children's income . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I went on to say:

Notwithstanding the professed views of the Taxation Office, it also alters the previous exemption policy by requiring that capital in both child maintenance and other trusts benefiting children pass to beneficiaries upon reaching the age of 18.

I was concerned, as I believe a whole range of people were concerned, about a case involving a footballer in Queensland. Both Senator Jones, who is present in the chamber, and you, Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds, are from Queensland. The footballer was dying of cancer and wanted to establish a trust for his children into which certain payments were to be made.

PARA.TAB: The position, as he understood it, was that the capital of that trust would not need to go to the children. His wife could become a paraplegic; why then should the capital of that trust go to the children, rather than to sustain his wife in that situation? This matter was thoroughly canvassed at that time. At the time, I said:

That is not a hypothetical question. I have received a representation from a Brisbane accountant, Mr Robert Ross, which shows that it is not hypothetical. In fact, it will cruelly affect a family in which the 40-year-old husband is dying of malignant brain tumours. He will leave a widow and five children, the youngest being only 12 weeks old. The government's bill—this bill that we are talking about—will impose penalty tax on the children's income from the trust being set up to support the children's education and maintenance and his wife's retirement.

Mr Ross states his personal outrage that this bill will affect that family. I share that outrage. I am disgusted that the government and the Taxation Office have come to the end of the International Year of the Family not only not caring about tax justice for families but not caring about people in this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I went on to say:
The Taxation Office is pushing through a change in the law by pretending that there always was a requirement to transfer capital to minors. That is not so and was never so.
I will come back to that in a moment. To continue:

It is reasonable that trusts may be established with discretion to provide for spouses as well as children. After all, it sometimes happens that a surviving spouse is injured or suffers a disease and thus requires even more support than the children do. Sometimes the trust funded through a life assurance policy may also provide for aged or invalid relatives as well as the spouse and children.

To take one example, why should penalty tax be imposed on the children just because a deceased parent set up one trust for family members instead of setting up separate trusts for the children? Why should it be fine for a discretionary trust to be set up for spouse and children through a will but not outside the will to receive the proceeds of a life assurance policy? Why should a trust set up to support the children of a deceased employee have to have the capital passing to the children on their attaining 18 years of age? Often such a trust, having attained its purpose of supporting the children, may revert back to some general welfare fund for employees.

PARA.TAB: I have been in that situation as a trade union official. When somebody on the job has dropped dead, there has been a collection on the job resulting in a substantial amount of money. Under those circumstances, the employer in many cases is anxious to ensure that this be placed in trust for the widow and the children. If it is placed in the one trust, the problem is that, unless the capital goes to the children or the last surviving child . . . there will be a penalty tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I could go on. By reading this, I remind honourable senators what was said by me and others in that debate on 8 December. I come back to the point: the Taxation Office at that stage was pushing through a change in the law by pretending that there always was a requirement to transfer capital. In volume 1 of Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin of 10 January 1995 that matter was canvassed quite thoroughly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who by?
—It was canvassed by Dr Terence M. Dwyer and Deborah R. Dwyer.
—Good people.

—Yes, they are very fine intellects. The article was entitled `Penalty taxes on children: an ATO contribution to the International Year of the Family'. In that edition there was also a response from Mr C.L. Hood, the senior tax counsel of the Australian Taxation Office. I invite honourable senators to obtain a copy of the January 1995 edition of Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin and peruse that discussion.

PARA.TAB: Now we come to the nub of the situation. The Law Council of Australia has bought into this matter and has written to the President. The lawyers make the point in that particular letter that Senator Sherry, on advice from the ATO, misled the Senate. This is a quite serious matter. I intend to take this up at some future time. Because this is the first time that taxation legislation has come back to us since then, I think it is incumbent upon me to raise the issue.

The President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Stuart Fowler, wrote to the President of the Senate on 30 January 1995 and referred to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994. His letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to bring to your attention the circumstances concerning the debate relating to the above Bill. It has been suggested that Parliament was "misled in its debate on the existing law." Whether or not this is so is primarily a matter for the Senate to determine. However, I consider the matter serious enough to bring to your attention the surroundings facts so that you may review the matter and decide what, if any, action should be taken.
Under the section headed `background' he stated:

For some time the Law Council of Australia urged the Government to amend Section 102AG of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The topic was the subject of discussions between representatives of the Law Council of Australia and the Child Support Agency at their regular meetings of the Child Support Liaison Group. Subsequently, in July 1993 the Law Council wrote to the Treasurer setting out its views and urging the Government to amend the Legislation. A copy of our letter is enclosed.

On 7 March 1994 the Assistant Treasurer issued a statement advising that amendments would be made to the Income Tax Assessment Act "which will ensure that the provisions relating to the unearned income of children under 18 operate as originally intended." The Law Council assumed from this statement that the Treasurer had accepted our submission and that amendments would be made in keeping with our submission.

In the same month Senator Harradine moved amendments to Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1993 to ensure that the amendments which had been foreshadowed by the Treasurer would have retrospective effect (that is, ensuring the validity of those transactions which had occurred between 1979 and 1994). For a variety of reasons Senator Harradine withdrew his proposed amendments but only after an indication had been given by Senator Sherry that "the government will consider retrospectivity . . . "

In December 1994 Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No.4) 1994 was introduced into the Parliament. Because the wording of the proposed amendments relating to Section 102AG was considerably different to what had been anticipated, the Law Council resolved to make a submission proposing various amendments to the Bill as tabled. Enclosed is a copy of the Law Council's letter of 5 December 1994.

Over the next couple of days Chris Crowley (who was handling the matter) had a number of discussions lobbying in support of our submission. So too did the Assistant Treasurer's advisors. They prepared a response to the Law Council's letter of 5 December. Enclosed with this letter is a copy of a letter from the Office of the Assistant Treasurer (addressed to Senator Vanstone) and a copy of the Taxation Office's comments.

The matter was debated in the Senate on Thursday, 8 December 1994. There are a number of references in the daily Hansard . . . You will note when you read the Hansard that more than one Senator queried the basis upon which the Government's amendments were being made. The response from the Government's representative in the Senate (Senator Sherry) was that, relying upon advice from ATO advisors, "the amendments restate the existing law" (page 4234), see also at page 4269, where the Senator said that, in effect, the amendments simply reflected a requirement which was "part of the Parliament's origin intention".
At page 4226 Senator Margetts, while referring to this specific topic said:

"We understand from the Tax Office that the opportunity available under law, for a child of at least 18, . . . to challenge any trust is sufficient so that the Tax Office will [sic] commit trusts even where they do not transfer assets to the children until they reach a greater age. Perhaps the representative of the Minister can assure the Senate that this is correct. We hope that it is, because it was on this basis that we support the current arrangement. If we find that it is not, we will support amendments for change."
Senator Harradine (at page 4231) said that:

"Notwithstanding the professed views of a Taxation Office, it also alters the previous exemption policy by requiring that capital in both child maintenance and other trusts benefiting child pass to beneficiaries upon reaching the age of 18."
Senator Reid (at 4233) referred to the Explanatory Memorandum which states:
"The Bill will reinstate Parliament's original intention, . . . ".
and then went on to say:
"I have seen nothing that indicates that that was the intention in, I think, 1979."

There are other portions of the debate which are relevant to this issue but no doubt you will read the whole of the debate when considering what, if any, action to take. Suffice is to say, that a number of Senators were concerned at whether the proposed amendments only clarified an ambiguity as claimed by the ATO or whether (as the Law Council has always contended) they went far beyond the intention of the Parliament in 1979.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of the letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to the debate Dr Michael Dwyer published an article in the Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin. He analysed the issue and the competing views. He concluded that:
"one can only deplore that Parliament was apparently misled in its debate on the existing law."
In support of his submission he referred to Section 102AG(8) which provides:
"For the purposes of this Section, where—
(a)any property is transferred to the Trustee of a trust estate; and

PARA.TAB: (b)the Trustee has a discretion to pay or apply the income derived from that property to or for the benefit of specified beneficiaries or beneficiaries included in a special class of beneficiaries,

SPEECH.PARA: that property shall be taken to have been transferred to the Trustee for the benefit of each of those specified beneficiaries or for each of the beneficiaries in that specified class of beneficiaries, as the case may be."

Dr Dwyer argues persuasively that the sub-section clearly supports the argument (that the thrust property did not have to be beneficially transferred to the beneficiary before a trust could be held to comply with Section 102AG.
Enclosed is a copy of Dr Dwyer's article and response by Chris Hood, Senior Tax Counsel at the Australian Taxation Office.

You will note that, in the Law Council's submission of 5 December no reference is made to sub-paragraph 8. I am not sure why this oversight occurred. I can only surmise that in the haste of attempting to prepare a submission it was overlooked. No doubt you will agree that its difficult to grasp the overall effect of a section where only parts of the section are sought to be amended. This is particularly so where the whole of the section is not dealt with in the Amendment Bill and where its necessary to cut and paste.

In any event, sub-section 8 does exist and in our submission it supports the Law Council's view that the amendments in Taxation Amendment Bill (No. 4) were not merely confirmatory of the intention of the Parliament in 1979 but indeed create more restrictive rules about what sort of trust is needed to comply with the scheme of S102AG. If you agree, the ATO advice was grievously wrong and the Senate may well have been misled.
If there is any further information you require for the purposes of considering what, if any, action to take I would be happy to assist.

As a matter of courtesy I have sent a copy of this letter to the Treasurer the Shadow Treasurer, to each of the Senators to whom I wrote in December and to Senator Sherry who represented the Government in the debate.
Please let me know the results of your deliber ations.
Yours sincerely,
STUART FOWLER
PRESIDENT
