SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994. I join my colleagues in supporting the intent of the bill. The bill is the first product of the tax law improvement project. The tax law improvement project was announced by the government in December 1993 with the object of rewriting the income tax law into simple language. That is not too different from the intent of the corporations simplification legislation, which I have also had some dealings with.

PARA.TAB: Although the legislation has moved at a very glacial pace—as Senator Watson properly pointed out—I think we all support the intent of simplifying the tax act. Very few people understand the complications of the tax act, and even fewer people have read it from cover to cover. I think Senator Watson is the only person on this side who has read the tax act from cover to cover. I see him carrying it around with him like a Bible; he even has it with him at this very moment.

The tax act has become an extremely complicated document. Interestingly enough, as Senator Watson pointed out, the complications have actually come about in the last seven years. The government is much to blame for all the complexities and different layers of the tax act that have come about in the last seven years and during the 1980s.

The complications have been broadened by the introduction of the capital gains tax, the dividend imputation, the foreign tax credit system, the foreign investment fund regime, the controlled foreign corporations tax laws and changes to superannuation. The changes are always rushed through without much thought; they are simply grafted on to the existing tax act until we get the ridiculous situation such as section 160ZGGGGP. Imagine trying to understand the following section if you had just picked up the act. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A car is a predecessor of a second car if a third car is a predecessor of a second car and the first mentioned car is a predecessor of the third car (including a case where the first-mentioned car is a predecessor of the third car by another application or application of this paragraph).

TALK.START.PARA: —What if you have two cars at the same time?

—Senator O'Chee, don't complicate it any more than it is. That is the contorted mix-up that we have got ourselves into. Thank goodness this government, even at its glacial pace, has had the wit and wisdom to set up a task force to unravel the tax act; and it has unravelled the act, to a certain degree.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson is still not happy with the bill. During the committee stage I am sure he will move many significant amendments which the minister should take on board. As an example, the wording in the act in relation to the car expenses logbook—which Senator Panizza referred to—has been reduced from about 87 words to 10 words. As Senator Watson has pointed out, that may not make it any easier. Certainly, as far as words go, it is a lot better, because there are more than two million words and 5,000 pages in the tax act. This goes part of the way to simplifying the tax act.

PARA.TAB: The section on maintaining records has been simplified across the board, and I was pleased to see that. In fact, all businesses would be interested to know this. The government has simplified across the board the length of time people are expected to keep their records. For example, for car and travel expenses, you are to keep records for seven years. For salary and wage earners, it is 3.5 years, although you would be wiser to keep them for longer than that.
Senator Watson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It says here for wages and salary it is 3.5.
—It has gone from 3 1/2 to five under this legislation.

—I can see that Senator Watson is not pleased with the simplification of the legislation. I am trying to give a little accolade to the government. If Senator Watson feels that it is not satisfactory, I yield to him because he, unquestionably, is the expert on this. I was saving some firepower for the area of fringe benefits tax and income tax. It is quite obvious that not only has the government moved at a glacial pace but its performance has been unsatisfactory overall. If nothing else, it has reduced the number of words. I just make that point.

PARA.TAB: That must go some of the way to reducing the compliance costs. One of the greatest complaints, other than paying high taxes, is compliance costs for business—and none is bigger than in the fringe benefits tax. Although the recent review on the fringe benefits tax is not directly related to this legislation, the aim was the same: to reduce the compliance cost and the complexities. That review on the fringe benefits tax was unsatisfactory and not well received within the business community.

The cost for businesses to comply with the FBT is staggeringly high. A study released two years ago by the Tax Research Foundation estimated that the FBT cost employers $127.5 million, or the equivalent of about 11 per cent of the total FBT revenue raised during the period studied. That research project may be two years old, but the situation has not improved, not even with the government's latest review.

Many other areas in business affect compliance. There are many other grievances and inequities within the tax area—for example, sales tax. The record keeping within sales tax has long been a concern of business—in particular, small businesses, because it affects their cash flow. They have to set up all the transactions with all their complexities—including different scales and marginal rates.

Businesses must pay the sales tax to the government within 21 days of the end of the month. However, as all businesses would know—and particularly small businesses—they are lucky if their invoices are paid within 30 days. While they pay the sales tax on their product within 21 days, at the very best they receive payment for that product within 30 days, and sometimes it blows out to 60 or 90 days. There is an inequity and a compliance cost there which the government also needs to address.

Another issue is provisional tax. If small business reserves its bile for one tax system, it is provisional tax. Of all the disadvantages for a business starting up in this country, provisional tax is the worst. The business gets a double whammy. At the end of the first year, not only does the business have to pay the initial tax but it has to pay provisional tax for the next year. That makes it just about impossible for a business to start up, although I suppose it could start up for a year. By the end of that year, it will have a huge tax bill.

Of course, the uplift factor is attached to that. We still have not come to a satisfactory arrangement in that area either. On this side of the house we believe that the uplift factor should be attached to the CPI, and I am sure the Greens believe that too. I remember the debate in this house last year on the uplift factor which reduced it from 10 per cent to eight per cent. That is not a satisfactory situation. We are committed to reviewing that. The aim of this side of the house is to attach the uplift factor to the CPI. Then there would be consistency and certainty for small business, and not this year by year debate on where it should stand.

There have been reports in relation to provisional tax. There may be relief upon the way but often newspaper reports are never to be believed and at the pace that the tax office moves it would seem that relief may be a long way away. But there was a particular report that I may ask the minister to clarify during the committee stage. That was a new tax plan dubbed `pay as you go' and would allow small business payers to drop out of the unpopular provisional tax system. Apparently the tax office has prepared a draft paper outlining how this new system would work.

While business, in particular small business, is facing the complexities of the tax act and attempting to unravel it, outlaying dead or wasted money in its compliance, it is also expected to take on a very hostile tax office. From the tax office 1995 corporate plan, the tax office has targeted well over 40,000 small businesses for audit in the squeeze for some $300 million in tax revenue.

That is an enormous amount of businesses targeted. They are expected to produce over 19 different forms of accounting records. The tax office has sent out memos outlining that it will need at least two weeks down time while the tax audit is being conducted. No owner/operator can afford two weeks down time while the tax office is sitting in the back of the office for one of these audits.

The Treasurer has unleashed the tax office upon small business for one reason only; that is, to solve the government's budget crisis, to squeeze those last little drops out of the system. Over 40,000 small business have been targeted for these audits over 1995. It is something that has not been lost on the accounting profession or tax agents. The headline in its own financial forum magazine is `Tougher audits tipped for `95'. All small business now has been put on notice for what is going to be a pillage type exercise by the tax office.
The new tax commissioner, Mr Carmody, gave a very warm interview to the Business Review Weekly last year about how different he is to Trevor Boucher. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The mood has changed at the Australian Taxation Office since Trevor Boucher's legendary skirmish with the business community.

What the article is talking about there of course is the legendary City Corp raid where doors were knocked down in almost a vice squad type raid. Trevor Boucher and his tax office were disciplined by the courts for that particular raid and by our own Senate committees and indeed the Auditor-General, if I understand correctly.

PARA.TAB: I happened to read something in the paper which caused me to almost fall off my chair. Trevor Boucher is being brought back from Paris to be the Auditor-General. He is one of the mooted candidates to be the Auditor-General. That may be something the minister might want to take up in the committee stage too. Just as a matter of interest, I think that would be, to say the least, a very unsatisfactory appointment. Again, it just may be paper talk.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most totalitarian public servant we have seen for a long time.

—Senator O'Chee said that he is the most totalitarian public servant we have seen for a long time. Nevertheless, I have taken it upon myself to send that newspaper clipping to Bronwyn Bishop to get the facts on the matter. Michael Carmody says that he is a man of more consensus and consultation. Consultation is the new buzz word around the tax office. Under Michael Carmody the audit programs will involve compliance improvement and taxpayer education. When you are unleashing the tax auditors upon 40,000 small businesses within a year or just a little over a year, I hardly think that is a far more consensus-like and consultative approach and hardly taxpayer education. We know the Treasurer has unleashed the tax office onto small business to raise a minimum of $300 million to meet its budget concerns.
—Three hundred million?

—Thank goodness, Senator O'Chee, we have the welcome news that there is going to be a tax ombudsman introduced in the near future. That is just what the taxpayers need, let alone a taxpayers' bill of rights! They need both against a government that is running around trying to squeeze every last tax dollar possible out of them—the business and PAYE taxpayer alike. We would at least welcome the news that they would have some redress not only from this side of the house but also from a tax ombudsman and perhaps even in the future a taxpayers' bill of rights. That is some welcome relief.

PARA.TAB: But business should be warned that every tax increase possible will be put on the table in this coming May budget. In a recent speech to business people in the ACT, Mr Willis emphasised that the government would be reducing expenditure as far as possible. We have seen the government's record on that. There has not been a year in which it has ever reduced expenditure. But he then went on to say that they will look at taxation and every single piece of taxation possible has been put on the table.

We have had company tax. That is one of the favourites of the caucus. That is the caucus that recently timidly attempted to discipline its Prime Minister. It comes to pass that that same caucus seeks one of its favourite suggestions—an increase in company tax from 33 per cent to 35 per cent. Of course, there is the hotel bed tax. That has come straight out of the Australian Council of Social Services. It is something the government is looking at but we believe not too favourably. In the paper recently, bed tax was not a recommendation of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration when it was looking into `taxing relaxing' which is obviously a catch word for a tax on the tourism industry. Maybe that one slipped through like the carbon tax has slipped through.

The Democrats, being the fifth faction of this government, are constantly putting pressure on the government. They want to put in a minimum tax on business—some 20 per cent of book profits. They have this suggestion from some wacky American state. It would prevent profitable companies from reducing their tax obligations below a prescribed minimum proportion of 20 per cent of their book profits. That is the Democrats's idea.

Of course, the wine industry is now being targeted in respect of wholesale tax. This industry is the main target in any increases in sales tax, but we have not even finished with the 1993 sales taxes yet. By the time this budget comes along it will have bypassed the increases in sales tax in 1993. Former Treasurer John Dawkins's sales taxes have yet to be completed. In July, all the general sales taxes are due to rise by one per cent as the second instalment from the 1993 budget. The wine industry escaped a sales tax implementation in that budget. However, this time it does not quite look as if that will be so.

In the short time I have left, I just want to put some figures on the record in regard to tax increases on business. When the fringe benefits tax was first introduced under the guise of an equitable tax, it was some $600 million. It has now blown out to $3.23 billion. Since 1983, when this government came to power, sales tax has increased some 326 per cent—that is, over $7.7 billion. In 1993-94, revenue from sales tax totalled $10.35 billion and in the current year it is forecast to increase to $11.1 billion.

I have not even got on to the petrol taxes yet, but everyone is quite aware of the incremental increases in petrol tax, let alone the l-a-w law increases which, unfortunately, time does not allow me to cover. Conclusively, there has been no relief to the government's spiralling tax take.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994, and we are just concluding the second reading debate. I know that often in debates on tax law honourable senators take the opportunity not to confine their remarks almost exclusively to the bill before the chamber but to make observations or political remarks about taxation. That is so ingrained a habit in this chamber that it is idle to try to call people to relevance. Nonetheless, those sorts of remarks aside, I can say quite candidly that senators have contributed to this debate in a constructive manner. I note that Senator McGauran has just given the government a spray about what might be. Let us wait, Senator McGauran, and see what is, before we get too excited, and then we can talk about something real rather than something imagined.

PARA.TAB: The Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill is, of course, the first step in the restructuring and rewriting of Australia's income tax law. Some would say that to embark on a course that this bill envisages—that is, to embark on the goal to make the law more easily understood so that taxpayers' compliance costs are reduced and compliance is improved—is conceptually sound but factually courageous in trying to achieve a reconciliation of those objectives. I understand that. Making law simple, while retaining its meaning and not visiting unintended consequences, is more like an art than a science, I suspect, but this is the objective of this exercise and, from the accounts given by honourable senators here, it is an objective that in the main has been met. It is in that context that I welcome the coalition's support of the bill.

The government has made public consultation and community support a cornerstone of the tax law improvement project. Two private sector representatives have been appointed to the leadership of the project to ensure it has a proper commercial perspective. A 14-person consultative committee will advise on the development of the new law. The members are drawn from peak bodies such as the Corporate Tax Association, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, business, the ACTU, tax agents themselves and academia.

This bill has been through an extensive public consultation process as well. Nearly 4,000 copies of the exposure draft were distributed, free of charge, to the tax industry and to the general public. Seminars on the exposure draft were held around Australia and attended by more than 1,000 members of the public. The bill as well includes important improvements suggested during the consultation process, particularly to the logbook rules, which are now much easier to understand and comply with.

The bill has received widespread support in the community. This is because, I believe, for the first time income tax law will clearly and simply state the rights and obligations of taxpayers. Further, the law will remove unnecessary requirements imposed on taxpayers; it will simplify complex rules that have proved difficult to understand; and it will bring the law more into line with commercial practice and taxpayer behaviour. A survey conducted by the tax law improvement project during the consultation process showed very encouraging results. One hundred per cent of respondents said that the rewrite was an improvement on the existing law.

TALK.START.PARA: —That wouldn't be hard.

—Indeed. It is the degree of improvement perhaps that we should be looking at, but it is certainly encouraging to know that they all thought this was better. Seventy-five per cent thought the law would reduce their compliance costs; 48 per cent said that they read the law now; and 84 per cent said that they would read the law in the future if it is to the same standard. They are some useful statistics on, if you like, market testing of the law.
—They even understand it.
—Indeed. I think Senator McGauran gave us a good example earlier in his address as to how confusing it can be. It certainly entertained Senator O'Chee, as it did me.

PARA.TAB: The new substantiation rules are only half the length of the rules that they replace. To understand the existing substantiation rules, I am advised, you would need to have the reading skills of a person who has completed two years of university. The new law should be capable of being understood by a person who has completed year 10 at high school—so my advice is.

I do not want to mention all of the changes made to the bill, but I would like to highlight one particular improvement. If taxpayers do not have the documentary evidence listed by the new law, that does not necessarily mean they will be denied a deduction. The documentary evidence rules are there so that taxpayers will know what evidence will be accepted by the commissioner as a matter of course. However, the commissioner also has a discretion to take into account other evidence to establish if an expense has been incurred and is deductible. This discretion is in the existing law, but it can only be used if the commissioner is satisfied that a taxpayer took reasonable steps to get the evidence. This has meant that the commissioner has not been able to use the discretion in some cases. The bill will remove these restrictions on the use of the discretion. In future, all that will be relevant is whether the taxpayer has reasonable evidence or not.

Some questions were addressed to me, as is usual, in the course of the speeches of some honourable senators during the second reading debate. I would like to take this opportunity, before resuming my seat and commending this bill to the Senate, to comment on and answer some of those questions.

My understanding is that Senator Panizza—and I did not hear all of his remarks—referred to the problem in a multicultural society like Australia that people whose first language is not English might have in understanding and complying with law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just filling in forms.

—Filling in forms. This issue is something that the project is well aware of. The English language requirements, I am advised, are spread throughout the act and are under review of the project. The project team includes on its consultative committee Mr Carl Harbaum, who is the head of the Ethnic Communities Council. I expect that, in the next raft of amendments to come forward in this three-step change to the Income Tax Assessment Act, something will be available after November this year so we can address the question that Senator Panizza has referred to.

PARA.TAB: As well as that, Senator Watson raised some questions in his remarks. This may not be a complete reply, Senator Watson, to all of the things that you said, but let me turn to at least a couple of the things that you raised and try to answer them now. One of them was that the project itself is going too slowly. Senator McGauran referred to glacial pace. Given the heroic objectives of this whole project, one can understand caution and concern and, indeed, conservatism in making sure that simplified language is legally expressing the same concept and is not unintentionally harming someone. But I do not think the view that you have put, Senator Watson, is widely shared when you consider that the bill was introduced into the parliament within five months of the commencement of the project's three-year time limit. That is fairly quick going when you realise that the bill has been developed as a model for all future changes. It raises more issues than just substantiation. This time span included a three-month public consultation period.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you can assure us it is going to be completed on time?

—Let me finish the scripted remarks, and I will come to that question. The team is close to finalising its exposure drafts of the losses and mining provisions. It is also finalising a discussion paper outlining a possible new structure for the income tax law, and the project is also well advanced in a number of areas, such as the very extensive provisions dealing with what is income and what is deductible.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson, the question that you posed by way of interjection, as I understood it, was whether the project will be completed on time. If I may, I will pause for a moment and summon up an answer.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that the Chairman of the Australia Indonesia Institute is the former ambassador, known to all, and former Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Richard Woolcott. He is known to us as the man who held the very powerful and influential position of ambassador to Indonesia in 1975 during the days of the Indonesian invasion of East Timor. It is common knowledge that he was the most prominent figure in mounting the case for his country and his government to allow the invasion and to turn perhaps a blind eye to it or even to justify the invasion. The Whitlam government was convinced and he has hung around long enough to convince every government subsequently.

PARA.TAB: I have had cause to clash with Mr Richard Woolcott just by way of letters to the editor, and he has published many papers defending his place in history; I claim it to be defending his error in history. I think that his chairmanship of the Australia Indonesia Institute is a slanted one. He does not give any confidence as a goodwill ambassador and, quite frankly, his presence there aggravates me to say that he is more of a stooge than a proper chairman. I think we really should have someone who does not have that type of past in this particular role.

I want to make the point that the vigorous defence of Indonesia by Mr Woolcott and many others like him over the past 20 years or so has been very influential. There is absolutely no doubt about that. He has given great pluck to many and I happen to think that he and many like him have given great pluck to our Australian military, which has equally vigorously defended the Indonesian invasion and the human rights violations.

I refer to two particular occasions—one not so long ago which I brought to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray). Air Commodore Nicholson from Darwin, a very high ranking Australian military official, claimed that talk of atrocities in East Timor was nothing more than—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is a swear word. What is your ruling on that? It is significant.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—I think, Senator McGauran, that, in keeping with the decorum of this place, it is not appropriate for you to use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right. It does not even warrant saying in this chamber, and many things have been said here. Let us say the Air Commodore compared it to bulldust. They were his comments on the East Timor situation. I and those on the other side of the fence in this particular debate were outraged—and rightly so. To the credit of Senator Ray, he acted in what I believe to be the correct way and on 25 July 1994 wrote me this letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The Air Commodore has been spoken to about his comments by an officer of the appropriate level and reminded of his responsibility under the guidelines.

That is a short version. In the very short time I have available, I want to say that if that was done last year, the military still has not learned. The Indonesian defence commander overseeing East Timor at the time of the Dili massacre was recently out here on tour. Under a blanket of security his visit included an inspection of Australian military technology at the Defence Science Organisation in Adelaide. We all know that that was his main purpose, but Brigadier Adrian D'Hage said he was out here looking at power supply, water purification and sanitation to benefit East Timor. This was proved to be utterly incorrect. That particular former defence commander was not out here for that reason. The military is still misrepresenting the position.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the adjournment debate tonight is to recount to the Senate briefly an impression that was made on me on 16 February 1995 in Melbourne and of which I was reminded again this morning at the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship. I am referring to a person who by name sounds very ordinary. His name is John Smith. But I can assure you that behind that very ordinary sounding name is a most extraordinary Australian. Indeed, if anybody were worthy of an award for service to the community, I believe it would be John Smith.

PARA.TAB: Most people may be aware of him in his stereotyping, I suppose, as a member of the God Squad. He clearly is a man of compassion, commitment, concern and care and is a great communicator. He now heads an organisation which has those words—care, concern and communication—in its title. He is clearly a very capable, perceptive and incisive social commentator. But he is not only a social commentator; he is also a social worker.

It is often said that actions speak louder than words. It is very difficult to know in John Smith's case because he does both so very powerfully. His actions speak very, very loudly, as do his incisive comments on our society. I had the opportunity to spend a day with his organisation in Melbourne on 16 February 1995. The boy within me, I suppose, recalls riding for a short period of time on the back of his Harley Davidson motorcycle around the streets of Melbourne. Whilst that was enjoyable, I must say that the side of me which I would like to think is compassionate towards those who are less fortunate in society was also deeply touched.

Mr Smith and his organisation work with those who are clearly the underprivileged within our society—young recidivists and drug addicts, the young unemployed and those who do not have parents or homes—who really are not part of what we might consider our mainstream social structure. He works with the prostitutes of St Kilda. He works a very impressive ministry. During that day, I was able to see a number of the activities in which his organisation engages.

In the afternoon, we took some time out at a bar to have a few drinks and generally have a discussion. He impressed upon me the very real need for the federal government to consider a schools program. John Smith told me whilst we were having this drink that virtually wherever he goes people say to him, `You spoke at my school and you made a lasting impression on me. You only spoke once, but you made a lasting impression.' As someone who has been in party politics, albeit not in the Senate but in my home state of Tasmania, for some time, I get cynical. I was wondering how genuine that comment was. As he finished his Guinness and I finished my beer, all of a sudden a free Guinness appeared from the other side of where we were. A young person came up and said, `You spoke at my school about 10 years ago and I was greatly impressed by it.' So his comments to me earlier about his recognition factor and the impression he has made were borne out by that coincidence.

John Smith is very strong on the point that there is a lack of moral structure or guidelines for youth in this day and age. There are no longer the absolutes, which are so helpful to young people in finding their role in life and society. Everything seems to be relative; anything seems to go. Indeed, a reading of the modern magazines indicates that the role model of Madonna is seen to be the one to aspire to rather than those who give themselves in selfless service, such as Mother Teresa. Because of the societal disintegration that we are suffering from, there are clear symptoms of that, such as youth crime, violence, drug addiction, prostitution and suicide. Basically, a lot of young people are no longer finding that there is a real meaning to life.

That, combined with a social dysfunction that occurs as a result of that, costs our community very dearly in not only social but also dollar terms. It is unfortunate that I have to put those sort of social problems into dollar terms, but I do so because of what I will be seeking the federal government to do at the end of my brief contribution tonight. Whilst many others are doing marvellous work in dealing with the symptoms of the problems, such as trying to help the recidivists mend their ways and drug addicts to rehabilitate—Lifeline tries to get people not to commit suicide but to see a meaning for life—John Smith has a burning desire within his heart to develop a preventive process so that we do not suffer from the symptoms.

I submit to this chamber and the federal government that they should give very serious consideration to funding even just a pilot program of John Smith's organisation to ascertain whether a real difference could be made. If his organisation were given what is small change in social security or law enforcement terms and a program could be established whereby the John Smith ministry could get into every high school within Australia, I would be confident in promising to the federal government that the money it would spend on that program would be returned to it tenfold. It would need to spend a lot less on social welfare and law enforcement agencies.

It is a pity when we deal with such social tragedies that we have to put them into dollar terms from time to time. The social costs and the absolutely distraught effects on individuals are things on which one can never place a dollar term. But in this situation I plead with the federal government to give serious consideration to funding such a program, because I am confident that financially it would be a very sound investment. Above and beyond that, it would create a better society for all Australians and, in particular, a lot of our young people. The next generation could be spared the trauma that so many of our young people go through.
I sincerely recommend this course of action to the federal government. I trust that it will take it upon itself to investigate the possibility I have raised this evening.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, Labor senators roundly criticised me for outlining to this chamber details of the New South Wales ALP's financial disaster. The branch's liability massively exceeds its assets. It is able to continue in business only with the support of its bankers, such as, naturally, the Commonwealth Bank.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to note that, despite the assurances and assertions from across the chamber that there was no prospect of intervention, that everything was wonderful and that the New South Wales branch was in a strong financial state and able to pay its debts as and when they fell due, there was this article in this morning's Australian newspaper:
While the branch's financial situation is not listed on the executive's agenda, members said it would be discussed during general business at Friday's meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: That is, of the federal executive of the Labor Party. It continues:

PARA.TAB: They say the most likely scenario is that the NSW branch's $10 million liabilities will be referred to the executive's executive committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Mr Della Bosca—

SPEECH.PARA: the New South Wales branch secretary—
on Sunday moved to quash lingering fears about the parlous state of the branch's finances by claiming a solution to the protracted crisis was at last in sight.
All I can say is that pigs might fly and that they need not even be Paul Keating's. It continues:

PARA.TAB: Mr Della Bosca said the ALP had found a buyer—

SPEECH.PARA: if this is the same phoney buyer it did not have the last time it said it had a buyer, it is simply a delaying tactic—
for a property owned by the AWU-FIME amalgamated union, which is central to plans to redevelop an inner-city site to gain maximum "value added".

PARA.TAB: Mr Della Bosca—

SPEECH.PARA: according to the paper—
was yesterday unavailable to comment on the deal.
I bet he is unavailable to comment; there ain't no deal. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: The ALP hopes to develop its Centenary House property by buying an AWU-FIME building and another belonging to the Seamen's Union.

But some members of the 21-strong executive—compromising 10 members from the Right, eight from the Left and 3 from the Centre-Left—are increasingly sceptical about Mr Della Bosca's ability to resurrect the property deal after a series of failures.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very wise of them to be so sceptical. I imagine that the Left and the Centre Left would be even more sceptical than some of the Right. It continues:

PARA.TAB: "I think there'll be a very suspicious national executive on Friday, you know, what's the latest rabbit that's been pulled out of the hat,' another member said.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian goes on:

PARA.TAB: The executive's executive committee was established after last year's national conference to examine issues like the NSW branch debacle.
Other sources, however, doubt the executive would countenance action against "the biggest and boldest" branch in the country.
"If it were any other State there probably would be intervention," an executive member said.

SPEECH.PARA: The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Other members, however, point out that the federal ALP has already sunk $1.5 million into the stalled project in guarantor funds—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the New South Wales stalled project—
since spent by the AWU-FIME after a settlement deadline lapsed last year.
An executive member said:

PARA.TAB: "I don't think the branch is looking at intervention, but there's a $10 million debt there and it looks like the (federal) party's already kissed goodbye $1.5 million to the AWU-FIME."
"With that debt and federal money down the drain I imagine there'd be some move towards an independent study under the auspices of the executive committee.
"That way we can avoid any messy question of intervention."
ALP sources are concerned the property deal, contingent on the purchase of the AWU-FIME property, could collapse should the union sell to another buyer.
In that case Centenary House could be worth 50 per cent less than it would as part of the property development.

SPEECH.PARA: This all seems to add up to some very good reasons why Senator Loosley, the architect—if one can call him an architect in such a non-building—of this deal, is leaving this place to pursue other matters. Clearly, he is not terribly suited to politics and certainly not to running a political party.

PARA.TAB: I very briefly want to refer to a problem that emerged in the very serious motion against me which failed to get up today. That was the government's humiliating failure to get its censure motion against me passed in the Senate. I understand that unprecedented and, as far as I am concerned, dishonourable attempts were made to encourage some members of this chamber to vote for a gag on a censure motion. As I understand it, Senator Evans sought support for a gag on the censure motion against me to prevent people on this side of the chamber mounting a defence of my actions in what is the most serious motion that can be brought before this chamber in relation to a senator. I regard that as an absolute disgrace.

I believe it is important that Senator Evans's sense of what is honourable and decent should be made readily recognisable and available for people in this chamber and outside to make their own judgments about him as a person. His motion was over the top, unbalanced and unreasonable. This has been demonstrated by the way it was amended. I suppose that tells us a fair amount about Senator Evans, apart from his lack of political judgment and his incompetence in handling the matter. It seems to me to be just incredible that there would have been a serious attempt to prevent a proper and full defence of a censure motion being mounted by Senator Evans, endeavouring to convince people—I am glad they were not convinced—that a gag should be applied. That is an absolute disgrace.

I would also like to mention briefly that I have some lingering concerns about some elements of what was decided. It is alleged that I left Dr Macdonald no opportunity to respond to what I said here. That is just absolute nonsense. The fact is that I got no electronic cover on Thursday night. The main way people in Australia get their news is through television and radio, particularly the 6.30 and 7 o'clock news programs and the 5 o'clock program on Channel 10. I got none of that on Thursday night because it was done far too late. The only cover I got for my statement was in the print media on Friday morning.

Dr Macdonald had the electronic media all day Friday, including the peak news programs on Friday evening, the peak television items on Friday evening and the print media on Saturday morning. You can check this by looking at the media and seeing what happened. Dr Macdonald's position was clearly given far greater media attention than my initial statement. I want to make that clear.

I also want to note in passing that this innocent, lovable person, Dr Macdonald, smeared Mr Fahey. He accused the premier of being part of an orchestrated campaign to smear him, saying his `fingerprints were all over this'. He said:
I believe John Fahey is responsible for in fact getting this person in Canberra to do a . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that at the time Dr Macdonald told a colleague of mine that he recognised that John Fahey had not done such a thing. Yet, on the Saturday of the election, Dr Macdonald was prepared to put that smear of John Fahey in the newspaper. I regard that as disgraceful. We also have the double standards of Labor, which says that Dr Macdonald had acted only on his accountant's advice. Yet through 1982 members of the Labor Party smeared and decried so many Liberal supporters who had also acted only on their accountants' advice when they put in tax returns which involved an understatment of their tax liabilities. We had people like Mr Dawkins and Senator Walsh abusing their privilege in this place. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw the Senate's attention to an article which appeared in the Courier-Mail on Thursday, 23 March 1995. It appeared in the home edition of the Courier-Mail but not the other edition, and that is a pity. The article in this issue concerns quite amazing hypocrisy. It is entitled `Williams fights estate'.

PARA.TAB: It seems that tourism developer Keith Williams wants the Gold Coast City Council to reject a development proposal for a residential and canal estate on the Gold Coast. Not only does he want to protect his old motor sport raceway, but it seems he wants to get involved in a redevelopment project on the site himself. The developers said that Mr Williams's study of the site did not stack up and so they dropped it. Now Mr Williams wants the whole proposal rejected by the council.

It is interesting to note that one of the reasons cited for not developing the area into a residential and canal estate—presumably by Mr Williams, although the quote is not enclosed in inverted comas—is that the site also formed an important flood plain and would perform its natural function indefinitely if allowed to do so. Mr Williams also insisted in the article that he was not anti-development.

My fullest sympathies go out to Mr Williams in this instance. I can tell him that I know just what it is like to want a municipal authority to reject an inappropriate development proposal. I know what it is like to be concerned that a natural waterway may forever be altered by a large proposal of this sort. I know what it is like to believe that the local authority may be acting in haste, supporting a developer with the promise of jobs, without necessarily examining all of the facts. I know what it is like for someone to question one's attitude to development overall, just because one thinks that a particular proposal could be built in the wrong way, on the wrong piece of coast and affect the natural heritage of the area.

Of course, I am not the only one to have this concern. Many people have been working hard for two years and more in connection with a particular development in North Queensland—which is also thoroughly inappropriate. Along with others involved in the campaign, I would like to offer Mr Williams some support. I can let him know a few techniques in fighting his Gold Coast proposal—for example, how to get hold of the reports and have all of the parameters of the development independently analysed; how to lobby government and bureaucrats; how to organise and participate in a demonstration; and how to write letters to the media and conservation magazines to educate other people about the problems with the issue. Finally, we could help Mr Williams with his emotional stress—that is, his emotional stress caused by seeing a heartless process where the greed for pie in the sky bucks is the basis for constant irrational decision making and abuse of process.

We know what it is like to try to preserve a piece of our natural heritage—not for any monetary gain but because we know in our hearts it is wrong. We know it is wrong to rip the heart out of an area and never have a full and proper environmental impact statement which would enable the effects of the development to be properly understood.

I say to Mr Williams, `I sympathise with you in your fight to stop your Gold Coast development. If we can offer any piece of advice, please let us know. You see, we are quite experienced now. We've been highlighting problems with your own Port Hinchinbrook development in the north, hoping to have your development proposal in its current form rejected—and, no, we aren't anti-development either.'

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What relationship does Bruce Lyon Real Estate Pty Ltd have with the Defence Housing Authority.
(2) Is Bruce Lyon Real Estate a member of the Rouse Hill Consortium.

(3) With reference to an advertisement by Bruce Lyon Real Estate Pty Ltd on page 55 of the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November 1994, does the Defence Housing Authority maintain the featured leased homes.
(4) Are these homes built on housing development sites, for example, Lancom Estates; if so, were these estates given special land rezoning privileges.
(5) With reference to one house which featured a rental of $2 200 per week in Carlingford, is this rent subsidised by the Defence Housing Authority.
(6) What is the rank of the lessee of this particular house.
(7) What contribution does the lessee make to the weekly rental.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Bruce Lyon Real Estate Pty Ltd has no ongoing relationship with the Defence Housing Authority. The Authority is in the business of acquiring homes and may from time to time enter into business relationships with any real estate agency which has suitable properties to offer. There may have been such dealings with Bruce Lyon Real Estate Pty Ltd at some time.
(2) I am not able to advise whether Bruce Lyon Real Estate Pty Ltd is a member of the Rouse Hill Infrastructure Consortium. The Defence Housing Authority has no involvement in the consortium.
(3) Insofar as can be ascertained from the advertisement, the Defence Housing Authority has leased all the properties which are for sale.

(4) Lessors to the Defence Housing Authority are solely responsible for the acquisition of the land and the construction of the houses they wish to lease. The Defence Housing Authority conducts enquiries to assure itself that lessors have good title to the properties.

(5) The rental of $2 200 per week featured in the advertisement is referring to the total rent for a group of five houses. These leases are typical of a number of yield-based 10 year rental contracts entered into by the Defence Housing Authority. Given funding constraints on the Authority, in the high interest rate climate of the late 1980's these arrangements provided an alternative way for the Authority to rapidly meet its goal of upgrading the accommodation available to service families. No new commitments to yield-based leases are being entered into by the Authority.

The Defence Housing Authority does not subsidise rents. It charges the Department of Defence full rents plus, in the case of leased houses, a management fee of 5 percent of the lease rent. The rents charged to Defence Force members who tenant the houses provided by the Authority are set by the Government. Rents for Defence personnel are standardised across Australia according to rank.
(6) The ranks of the sub lessees of the five houses are Able Seaman in two instances, Petty Officer in two instances and Lieutenant in one instance.
(7) The weekly rents paid by the tenants are:
Able Seaman—$80.90
Petty Officer—$96.70
Lieutenant—$109.50

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 30 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was a United Nations 1951 questionnaire regarding standards of institutional care for children issued from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet by letter dated 30 October 1951 (reference 742/1/4) addressed to the Premier of Western Australia (WA).
(2) Were replies to the questionnaire forwarded to the Prime Minister in a letter dated 30 June 1951.

(3) (a) Did question 23 of the questionnaire refer to institutions providing for vocational training; and (b) did the Premier's answer state that in some cases boys were taught carpentry, metalwork and farming and girls were taught dressmaking and domestic work.

(4) (a) Did question 24 of the questionnaire ask whether children were required to perform any work (besides that in connection with their vocational training) for the institutions and if so, did they receive payment for this work; and (b) did the Premier answer in the negative.

(5) Do the following archival papers show that work was done by inmates of the Christian Brothers WA St Joseph's Farm and Trade School, Bindoon: if so, will the Minister table the documents: (a) minute W48/H.403 dated 3 August 1948 to Commonwealth Migration Officer; (b) note 1949/H/1168 dated 21 September 1948 from F Mather to WA Under-Secretary for Lands; (c) letter 4186/46 dated 13 September 1948 from WA Under-Secretary for Lands and Immigration to Industrial Registrar Arbitration Court of WA; (d) letter RAW/AY dated 20 September 1948 from WA Arbitration Court to WA Under-Secretary for Lands and Immigration; (e) report ACC 541 An 3/3 4186 Volume 2 dated 21 March 1949 from Office in Charge, Applications and Inspections Branch, to the WA Under-Secretary Lands and Immigration Department; (f) inspection report dated 24 June 1949 on Bindoon signed by F Mather; (g) an undated 1947 report on Bindoon referring to the building activities there; (h) note dated 21 August 1950 from Under-Secretary for Lands and Immigration WA referring to the funding of building at Bindoon; (i) letter 697/48 dated 23 May 1951 from WA Under-Secretary for Lands and Immigration addressed to the acting Commonwealth Migration Officer, Perth; (j) letter JBF dated 20 February 1951 from the acting Under-Secretary of State for Lands and Immigration; (k) letter Mc/B dated 11 August 1947 from Secretary H F McMinn to Hon Minister for Social Services; and (l) letter FEM/b dated 3 July 1946 from F Meacham to the Hon Minister for Child Welfare.
(6) Does the evidence show that the WA Government misled the United Nations as to the state of institutional care for children in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. Technically, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet did not issue the questionnaire referred to. The United Nations issued a questionnaire which dealt with the institutional care of children, which is a state government responsibility. A copy of the questionnaire was sent to all premiers, including the Premier of Western Australia, under cover of a letter from the Prime Minister dated 30 October 1951. The Premier of Western Australia was asked to supply the necessary information for Western Australia. In dealing with this matter the Commonwealth's role was as a collation point for information from the states, which it then passed to the United Nations.

(2) No. Input from the Western Australian Premier was submitted in a letter to the Prime Minister dated 30 June 1952. The Premier provided two copies of his Government's response to the questionnaire under cover of a letter dated 30 June 1952, and this letter is held in file 742/1/4. That file does not include a copy of the WA response, although it is noted that one copy was provided to "EA" (the former Department of External Affairs). The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has advised that an External Affairs file indicates that two copies of the questionnaire response were received from Western Australia via the Prime Minister's Department. One was sent to the Australian Mission to the United Nations in New York to be handed over to the United Nations. The other was sent to the then Department of Social Services. The Social Services file about the questionnaire (file A911 of Commonwealth Record Series A884) was eventually destroyed in accordance with General Disposal Authority 14, paragraph 24.2.2 which provides for the destruction of material which is essentially copies of documents from other agencies. The only possible surviving copies of the West Australian reply to the questionnaire would appear to be with the Western Australian Government or the United Nations.
(3)(a) Yes.

(3)(b) Because only the covering letter from the Premier of Western Australia to the Prime Minister, but not the Premier's response to the questionnaire, has been located on the file (742/1/4) referred to by Senator Chamarette in part (1) of her question, it is not possible for the Commonwealth to respond definitively. Previous correspondence from a member of the public to the Prime Minister, dated 2 October 1993, on what may be the same matter includes a purported quote from the Western Australian response to the questionnaire which appears to verify the claims. But the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has not been able to independently confirm this.
(4)(a) Yes.

(4)(b) As noted in the response to (3)(b), it is not possible for the Commonwealth to reply definitively on the basis of the information available. Previous correspondence from a member of the public to the Prime Minister, dated 2 October 1993, on what may be the same matter includes a purported quote from the Western Australian response to the questionnaire which appears to verify the claims. But the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has not been able to independently confirm this.

(5) The archival papers referred to in part (5) of the question are more than 30 years old. As Senator Chamarette has only supplied minute or letter numbers and not complete file reference numbers, it has not been possible to locate the documents on files held by the Commonwealth.

If they could be located these papers would be in the `open period' under the Archives Act 1983. But the Act provides for a range of exemptions covering material such as records the release of which would damage international relations and records containing information of a personal or confidential nature. If a record could adversely affect the interest of a state or territory, the Archives Act requires consultation between the Commonwealth and that state or territory. Without examining the papers therefore it is not possible to confirm whether they would be open to public access.

However, previous correspondence to the Prime Minister from a member of the public dated 4 October 1994 provided copies of documents which appear to match the descriptions provided by Senator Chamarette. It appears that these documents may have been obtained from the State Archives of Western Australia and, given they were provided by a member of the public, have presumably been deemed open for public access under the arrangements of that body.

(6) In light of the response to part (5) above, it is not possible to answer part (6) in specific terms. Even if it is assumed that the purported quotes from the Western Australian response referred to in parts (4) and (5) above are accurate, to provide any opinion on whether the Western Australian response was, at the time it was sent, inaccurate, would require a measure of speculation. It is not possible to state with certainty how the Western Australian Premier, or the officers who prepared the response, interpreted the question or what information they relied on in developing the response. Given the passage of more than forty years, it is unlikely that those involved would be able to shed much light on the issue, even if they were still alive and could be located. Furthermore, the documents referred to by Senator Chamarette in part (5) of her question antedate by months or years the submission of the Western Australian response; it may be that the situation identified in the documents had altered so that the response was accurate at the time it was passed to the United Nations. The Special Minister of State suggests that as the content of the Western Australian response was a matter for the Western Australian Government, it is to that Government that any further queries should be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 14 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: Which States have developed plans for the changeover to non-organochlorine methods of termite control in mid 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The changeover to non-organochlorine methods of termite control is essentially a matter to be addressed by the relevant industry sectors. The phase out timetable was developed on the basis of advice as to the availability of alternatives and has allowed for the further development of such alternatives and their increased acceptance in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the risks of exposure to HIV for Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel serving in Rwanda.
(2) What procedures are in place for the testing of ADF personnel serving in Rwanda for HIV, before, during and after their tours of duty in the country.
(3) What guidelines and procedures are in place to minimise the risk of HIV exposure for ADF personnel while serving in Rwanda.
(4) What special briefings or training have been given on the risks of exposure to HIV for ADF personnel serving with the 1st or 2nd ADF contingents to Rwanda.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The prevalence of HIV in Rwanda is high and this fact was acknowledged in the predeployment risk assessment. The risk is greatest for those personnel who deal with casualties and are likely to come into contact with infected blood.

(2) All ADF personnel who deploy to Rwanda are tested for HIV (as well as other blood borne diseases) before they leave Australia. It is policy that they are also tested on their return and again twelve weeks later. The ADF medical contingent in Rwanda has the facilities to test for HIV if there is a clinical need.

(3) All members of the ADF who are deployed to Rwanda receive appropriate training regarding recognition of the HIV risk and how to minimise their exposure and risk of contracting the disease. Any member who is exposed to potentially infected blood is given appropriate counselling and offered AZT therapy.

(4) ADF health care personnel are trained in the application of "Universal Precautions Against Blood And Body Fluids" in the course of their professional training. The non-medical members of the contingent receive specific training relating to the risk from contact with blood, prior to deployment.

ANSWER.PARA: This is reinforced in country as each group of servicemen and women is attached to the hospital at Kigali, and several times during their tour of duty. All members receive a comprehensive health brief prior to leaving Australia which covers all the diseases of operational significance, including HIV. Appropriate equipment is provided for minimising contact with blood and body fluids, and for contaminated waste disposal. For example, even the non-medical personnel are required to carry latex gloves in case they have to assist in first aid or casualty management at short notice.
